The Coles No Annual Fee MasterCard is one popular choice.</p>\\r\\n<p>What sets the Coles MasterCard apart from the other low fee credit cards available on the market is its lack of an annual fee. While one is sure to make savings through this feature, this type of card won't suit every type of consumer. Financial discipline is the order of the day with a Coles MasterCard, as with an interest rate of 19.99 percent, it sits towards the upper end of the spectrum of rates.</p>\\r\\n<p><b>The low fee credit card for those on top of their finances</b></p>\\r\\n<p>As its name indicates, the Coles No Annual Fee MasterCard's chief drawcard is its lack of annual fee. With some cards, this can save you hundreds of dollars over the course of years.</p>\\r\\n <p>This is also money you can put toward paying down your credit card debt to reduce your burden of interest.</p>\\r\\n<p>Those in the habit of managing their money and paying down debt can also benefit from the Coles MasterCard's 62-day interest-free period. As long as you pay off the full balance of the card each month, you won't pay interest on any purchases for a period of time equivalent to two Decembers.</p>\\r\\n<p>However, buyers will have to be at the top of their game when it comes to managing their money. Interest at 19.99 percent is charged on all purchases and cash advances, and there are several more features that can catch undisciplined card holders:</p>\\r\\n<p><ul>\\r\\n<li>A late fee of $20 if you fail to pay off the required amount by the due date\\r\\n<li>A cash advance fee of 3 percent of the total withdrawn, or $1.95 - whichever is bigger - charged on all cash transactions</p></ul>\\r\\n\\r\\n<p><b>The shopaholics' low fee MasterCard</b></p>\\r\\n<p>If you like a little bit of something for nothing now and then, it's worth noting that the Coles MasterCard offers shoppers a number of advantages:</p>\\r\\n<p><ul>\\r\\n<li>$10 off each purchase at a Coles Supermarket when you redeem 2000 flybuys points, excluding Coles Express, Coles Local and Coles Online\\r\\n<li>It's a credit and flybuys card in one, so you don't need two cards clogging up your wallet\\r\\n<li>For each $2, you spend, you'll receive one flybuys point, on top of any other flybuys points you receive from other partners\\r\\n<li>Free delivery when you spend $100 or more with your Coles MasterCard from a Coles Online store</p></ul>\\r\\n\\r\\n<p>You'll also gain the luxury of MasterCard PayPass, allowing you to tap and go for purchases under $100.</p>\\r\\n<p>If you're thinking of shopping on holiday, the Coles MasterCard is less accommodating, as there are a number of fees on overseas transactions: </p>\\r\\n<p><ul>\\r\\n<li>$4 at international ATMs, on top of the cash advance fee\\r\\n<li>$5 charged with each over the counter transaction, also on top of the cash advance fee\\r\\n<li>An international transaction fee of 2.5 percent of every purchase outside Australia</p></ul>\\r\\n\\r\\n<p>If you're hoping to keep your credit history spotless, it might therefore be best to give the Coles MasterCard a break when travelling.</p>\\r\\n<p><b>Other notable features of the Coles No Annual Fee MasterCard</b></p>\\r\\n<p>The Coles MasterCard has a number of other notable features worth paying attention to. Available\"],\"purchase_standard_rate_percentage\":11.49,\"qld_applicable\":true,\"reinstatement_fee\":0,\"reward_annual_fee\":null,\"reward_value\":null,\"rewards\":[],\"rewards_available\":null,\"sa_applicable\":true,\"slug\":\"low-rate-platinum\",\"special_offers\":null,\"special_offers_expiry\":\"N/A\",\"supplementary_card_annual_fee\":0,\"supplier_reference\":\"CRED0000075164\",\"tas_applicable\":true,\"transaction_verification_fee\":0,\"trending\":0,\"type\":\"creditcard\",\"uuid\":\"85465e89-eaa3-4b30-bc9a-38b901e41f3c\",\"vic_applicable\":true,\"wa_applicable\":true}]}],\"trendingNews\":{\"all\":[{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[\\\"on\\\",null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1492057933:39\",\"_yoast_wpseo_focuskw\":\"home loan calculator, mortgage repayment calculator, interest rates, home loan repayment calculator, home loans, home loan comparison\",\"_yoast_wpseo_focuskw_text_input\":\"home loan calculator, mortgage repayment calculator, interest rates, home loan repayment calculator, home loans, home loan comparison\",\"_yoast_wpseo_linkdex\":\"53\",\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"The fixed versus variable home loan debate\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/cb42476b4c10c5427d762d5dabd94582?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":null,\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\\\">home loans</a> can feel like playing a game of rock, paper, scissors – all about predicting what’s likely to happen next. </span></p>\\n<p><span>With interest rates continuing to rise for owner-occupier and investor home loans, borrowers may be feeling uncertain as to which type of loan they should commit to. Choosing between variable and fixed interest rates can be difficult, but there are ways to get ahead.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a fixed home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><span>A fixed home loan allows you to lock in an interest rate on your mortgage for a length of time to enjoy greater stability and simpler budgeting in your personal finances. Most lenders will offer fixed periods between 1-5 years, however some do offer fixed home loans of up to 10 years. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">Fixed interest rates</a><span> </span>give you certainty; if you can afford the repayments today, you can afford them next year (assuming your circumstances remain the same). It’s this peace of mind that appeals to many<span> </span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">fixed rate</a><span> </span>borrowers because their repayments stay the same whether rates fall, rise or stay the same.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a variable home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span>Fixed home loans can be frustrating if you lock in a rate before variable rates drop, because exiting a fixed-rate mortgage can be costly.  Most borrowers stick with the<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/variable-rate\\\">variable rate</a><span> </span>rollercoaster, which keeps things flexible – allowing for extra repayments, for instance.</span></p>\\n<p>A variable home loan usually starts with a lower home loan rate offered by the bank, which fluctuates depending on the cash rate determined by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA).</p>\\n<h3><strong>Is it worth the risk?</strong></h3>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411093003/iStock-538027758-e1491867015381.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p><span>In recent weeks, dozens of lenders have increased interest rates for owner-occupied and investor home loans, <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">including the big-four banks</a>. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>This has followed changes to regulations made by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders. The RBA has responded to changes in regulations and rising interest rates by holding the cash rate at an historically low 1.5%. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>A recent RateCity survey has shown that 1 in 10 people who have refinanced their home loan in the past two years switched from a variable to a fixed home loan with the same bank.</span></p>\\n<h3><strong>Borrowers’ best options</strong></h3>\\n<p>While interest rates can make a substantial difference to your repayments and the total interest you pay on your home loan, the past has proven it&#8217;s very hard to predict which option will perform better.</p>\\n<p>Fixing in October 2005 would have saved borrowers 15%, or around $12,200 compared to variable over the following three years. Fixing a home loan rate in September 1991 would have cost a borrower an extra 30%, or $29,800, over the next three years.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><span style=\\\"background-color: #ffffff;\\\">Typically, when the gap between fixed and variable rates widens due to either an increase in variable rates or a decrease in fixed or both, it could be the right time to fix.</span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>Another good time would be if fixed rates were not much higher than the average basic variable rate. For example, if the average basic variable rate was 4.97%, and some lenders were offering three-year fixed loans at 5.1%, with a difference between the two of only 13 basis points, it could be worth fixing.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><span>However, most Aussies tend to ‘panic fix’ when rates are at the highest. For example, more than 25% of new loans were fixed in March 2008 when the RBA cash rate was at a peak at 7.25%. When rates fell to 3% a year later, only 4% of new loans were fixed.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Ultimately, choosing between a fixed or variable rate is still a personal choice. It is important that you factor in whether you can afford at least a 2% rate increase no matter what type of loan you decide.</span> </p>\\n<p><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/YfcmYsE1LPc\\\" width=\\\"560\\\" height=\\\"315\\\"></iframe></p>\\n<h3><strong>Tips to consider before fixing</p>\\n<p></strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><strong><span>What are the break costs?</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>Lenders can charge borrowers fees when you make extra repayments on a fixed home loan. Most will allow you to pay a small extra amount off your mortgage without being charged. but if you go over this amount, or fully pay off your loan ahead of schedule, you may be charged break costs. As of July 2011, variable mortgages have no early repayment penalties or exit fees, however fixed rate break costs and discharge fees still apply. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Track your bank’s interest rates</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If your loan’s fixed term is coming to completion, it is wise to monitor it well ahead of time and discuss your best options with your bank before it finishes. You may want to fix again or revert to a variable rate, depending on whether you believe rates will continue to rise or fall.</span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Consider taking out a split loan  </span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If you still can’t decide, perhaps a split loan is for you. Having half your loan in a variable account could allow for flexibility, while the other half of your loan remains secured at the fixed rate. </span></p>\\n<h3><span> </span><strong><span>Pros / Cons of fixed rate</span></strong><strong><span> </span></strong></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Protected against raising interest rates</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">P<span>rotected against cash rate fluctuations</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Set an accurate budget</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>If lenders drop rates you’re stuck paying more</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">L<span>ess flexibility to make extra payments</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Typically have expensive break fees</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Loan may take longer to pay off, so you’ll pay more interest</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"fixed rate\",\"home loan\",\"mortgage\",\"variable rate\"],\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\\\">home loans</a> can feel like playing a game of rock, paper, scissors – all about predicting what’s likely to happen next. </span></p>\\n<p><span>With interest rates continuing to rise for owner-occupier and investor home loans, borrowers may be feeling uncertain as to which type of loan they should commit to. Choosing between variable and fixed interest rates can be difficult, but there are ways to get ahead.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a fixed home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><span>A fixed home loan allows you to lock in an interest rate on your mortgage for a length of time to enjoy greater stability and simpler budgeting in your personal finances. Most lenders will offer fixed periods between 1-5 years, however some do offer fixed home loans of up to 10 years. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">Fixed interest rates</a><span> </span>give you certainty; if you can afford the repayments today, you can afford them next year (assuming your circumstances remain the same). It’s this peace of mind that appeals to many<span> </span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">fixed rate</a><span> </span>borrowers because their repayments stay the same whether rates fall, rise or stay the same.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a variable home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span>Fixed home loans can be frustrating if you lock in a rate before variable rates drop, because exiting a fixed-rate mortgage can be costly.  Most borrowers stick with the<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/variable-rate\\\">variable rate</a><span> </span>rollercoaster, which keeps things flexible – allowing for extra repayments, for instance.</span></p>\\n<p>A variable home loan usually starts with a lower home loan rate offered by the bank, which fluctuates depending on the cash rate determined by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA).</p>\\n<h3><strong>Is it worth the risk?</strong></h3>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411093003/iStock-538027758-e1491867015381.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p><span>In recent weeks, dozens of lenders have increased interest rates for owner-occupied and investor home loans, <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">including the big-four banks</a>. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>This has followed changes to regulations made by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders. The RBA has responded to changes in regulations and rising interest rates by holding the cash rate at an historically low 1.5%. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>A recent RateCity survey has shown that 1 in 10 people who have refinanced their home loan in the past two years switched from a variable to a fixed home loan with the same bank.</span></p>\\n<h3><strong>Borrowers’ best options</strong></h3>\\n<p>While interest rates can make a substantial difference to your repayments and the total interest you pay on your home loan, the past has proven it&#8217;s very hard to predict which option will perform better.</p>\\n<p>Fixing in October 2005 would have saved borrowers 15%, or around $12,200 compared to variable over the following three years. Fixing a home loan rate in September 1991 would have cost a borrower an extra 30%, or $29,800, over the next three years.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><span style=\\\"background-color: #ffffff;\\\">Typically, when the gap between fixed and variable rates widens due to either an increase in variable rates or a decrease in fixed or both, it could be the right time to fix.</span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>Another good time would be if fixed rates were not much higher than the average basic variable rate. For example, if the average basic variable rate was 4.97%, and some lenders were offering three-year fixed loans at 5.1%, with a difference between the two of only 13 basis points, it could be worth fixing.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><span>However, most Aussies tend to ‘panic fix’ when rates are at the highest. For example, more than 25% of new loans were fixed in March 2008 when the RBA cash rate was at a peak at 7.25%. When rates fell to 3% a year later, only 4% of new loans were fixed.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Ultimately, choosing between a fixed or variable rate is still a personal choice. It is important that you factor in whether you can afford at least a 2% rate increase no matter what type of loan you decide.</span> </p>\\n<p><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/YfcmYsE1LPc\\\" width=\\\"560\\\" height=\\\"315\\\"></iframe></p>\\n<h3><strong>Tips to consider before fixing</p>\\n<p></strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><strong><span>What are the break costs?</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>Lenders can charge borrowers fees when you make extra repayments on a fixed home loan. Most will allow you to pay a small extra amount off your mortgage without being charged. but if you go over this amount, or fully pay off your loan ahead of schedule, you may be charged break costs. As of July 2011, variable mortgages have no early repayment penalties or exit fees, however fixed rate break costs and discharge fees still apply. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Track your bank’s interest rates</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If your loan’s fixed term is coming to completion, it is wise to monitor it well ahead of time and discuss your best options with your bank before it finishes. You may want to fix again or revert to a variable rate, depending on whether you believe rates will continue to rise or fall.</span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Consider taking out a split loan  </span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If you still can’t decide, perhaps a split loan is for you. Having half your loan in a variable account could allow for flexibility, while the other half of your loan remains secured at the fixed rate. </span></p>\\n<h3><span> </span><strong><span>Pros / Cons of fixed rate</span></strong><strong><span> </span></strong></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Protected against raising interest rates</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">P<span>rotected against cash rate fluctuations</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Set an accurate budget</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>If lenders drop rates you’re stuck paying more</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">L<span>ess flexibility to make extra payments</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Typically have expensive break fees</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Loan may take longer to pay off, so you’ll pay more interest</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1491903053\",\"dc:creator\":\"administrator\",\"description\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411092811/iStock-507546185-725x420.jpg\",\"id\":48297,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/\",\"media_release\":null,\"meta_description\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"meta_keywords\":\"home loan calculator, mortgage repayment calculator, interest rates, home loan repayment calculator, home loans, home loan comparison\",\"meta_title\":\"The fixed versus variable home loan debate\",\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"48297\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon, 10 Apr 2017 23:30:53 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":5,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"the_article_type\":\"articles\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411092811/iStock-507546185-350x482.jpg\",\"title\":\"The fixed versus variable home loan debate\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1491903442\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/feed/\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"39\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1491780472:39\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Philip Lowe, has shown support for new housing affordability regulations from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders.</p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://www.rba.gov.au/speeches/2017/sp-gov-2017-04-04.html\\\">Speaking at the RBA Board dinner</a> following the central bank’s April meeting, which kept Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at record-low 1.5% for the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\\\">eighth straight month</a>, governor Lowe commented that Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest-only home loans</a> are “unusual” compared to the rest of the world:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Over the past year, close to 40% of the housing loans made in Australia have not required the scheduled repayment of even one dollar of principal at least in the first years of the life of the loan; only interest payments are required. This is unusual by international standards. In some countries, repayment of at least some principal is required on all housing loans for the entire life of the loan. In other countries, interest-only loans are available only if the borrower has already contributed a fair degree of equity. So this is one area where Australia stands out. We are not unique in this area, but we are unusual.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>What is an interest only home loan?</h3>\\n<p>An <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest only home loan</a> does <a href=\\\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Does_exactly_what_it_says_on_the_tin\\\">exactly what it says on the tin</a> – it’s a home loan where instead of making repayments that include both the loan’s principal and interest, you only pay interest to your lender instead.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//Oo5T6277z98\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">Interest-only home loans</a> are typically only available for a limited period of time. Many lenders limit interest-only repayments to 1 to 5 year stretches, though some lenders are willing to accept interest-only repayments for longer periods. Once an interest-only period is up, you’ll need to either apply to the lender to start a new interest-only period, or switch to paying principal and interest</p>\\n<h3>Advantages of interest-only loans </h3>\\n<p>One of the most obvious advantages of an interest only loan is that you only need to pay the interest and not the principal, which makes the loan cheaper on a month to month basis. This can make interest-only loans attractive to some owner-occupiers looking to keep their costs down, whether they’re first homebuyers trying to firmly establish their finances, or borrowers seeking to free up more of their income to pay for a renovation or some other personal project.</p>\\n<p>According to governor Lowe, the flexible nature of Australia’s mortgages plays a significant role in the popularity of interest-only loans:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Many people with interest-only loans make significant payments into offset accounts rather than explicitly paying down principal. This flexibility, which is of value to many people, isn&#8217;t available in most countries.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>By paying money into an offset account on an interest only loan, borrowers can reduce their interest repayments, and still access these funds if required much more easily than making a redraw or taking out a line of credit from a principal and interest home loan.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//LUmh9AOzmug\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p>But it’s property investors that can really benefit from interest only loans. By using an interest-only loan to buy a property, an investor can enjoy low <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> (potentially lowered further by an offset account), as well as tax benefits from negative gearing if the interest they pay is higher than the rental income they earn.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Are tax benefits worth investment losses?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">The pros and cons of negative gearing</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/the-pros-and-cons-of-negative-gearing\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>And even though an interest only loan doesn’t reduce the principal, the property’s value can still increase over time, so by the end of the interest-only period, the investor can sell and come out ahead, or reinvest using the resulting equity.     </p>\\n<h3>Disadvantages of interest only loans </h3>\\n<p>While interest only loans may seem relatively affordable because you only need to pay your loan’s interest, if lenders repeatedly raise their interest rates, borrowers could find their <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> quickly growing unaffordable. Similarly, if a lender declines to renew or extend an ending interest only period, borrowers could find themselves unable to afford their higher principal and interest repayments.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Can you afford P&I repayments?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Home Loan Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">Find Out</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>For owner occupiers, interest only loans may be more affordable in the short term, but because the principal isn’t being reduced during the interest-only period, this can mean the loan ultimately takes longer to pay off, and the borrower will pay more in total interest over the lifetime of the loan.</p>\\n<p>For investors, if their property&#8217;s capital growth is sluggish, or even drops in value (not impossible in specific areas) they could reach the end of their interest-only period without enough usable equity available to cover their costs.</p>\\n<h3>How will the new regulations affect interest only loans? </h3>\\n<p>Among <a href=\\\"http://www.apra.gov.au/adi/Publications/Documents/Further%20measures%20to%20reinforce%20sound%20residential%20mortgage%20lending%20practices.pdf\\\">APRA’s new guidelines</a> for banks, lenders and home loan providers are regulations to “limit the flow of new interest-only lending to 30% of new residential mortgage lending”, and to “manage lending to investors in such a manner so as to comfortably remain below the previously advised benchmark of 10% growth.”</p>\\n<p>Limiting the number of new interest-only loans (among other APRA regulations) should help to limit the number of Australians borrowing beyond their means and putting themselves into potentially risky financial positions if interest rates were to rise or house prices to fall.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">What options are available?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How can we fix the housing affordability crisis?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/can-fix-housing-affordability-crisis\\\">Learn More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>These regulations should also contribute to reducing the overall level of risk in the Australian housing market, and help to stabilise the broader Australian economy in case of future economic downturns.  </p>\\n<p>Curbing interest-only loans is also expected to limit the impact of investors on Australia’s housing affordability, which according to governor Lowe, was already under pressure from high demand and limited supply in popular areas:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Not surprisingly, the rising prices have encouraged people to buy residential property as an investment in the hope of ongoing capital gains. With global interest rates so low, many investors have found it attractive to borrow money to invest in appreciating residential property. This has reinforced the upward pressure on prices.”</p>\\n<p>“Like the earlier ‘speed limits’ on investor lending, these new requirements should help the whole system pull back to a more sustainable position. A reduced reliance on interest-only loans in Australia would be a positive development and would help improve our resilience.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>Compare interest-only home loans:</h3>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_comparisonRate=3.8&ab_test_id=0.72&interestOnly=true&sort_field=advertisedRate\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"category\":[\"home-loans\",\"interest\",\"interest only\",\"interest only loans\",\"investment lending\",\"mortgages\",\"negative gearing\",\"rba\",\"reserve bank of australia\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Philip Lowe, has shown support for new housing affordability regulations from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders.</p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://www.rba.gov.au/speeches/2017/sp-gov-2017-04-04.html\\\">Speaking at the RBA Board dinner</a> following the central bank’s April meeting, which kept Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at record-low 1.5% for the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\\\">eighth straight month</a>, governor Lowe commented that Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest-only home loans</a> are “unusual” compared to the rest of the world:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Over the past year, close to 40% of the housing loans made in Australia have not required the scheduled repayment of even one dollar of principal at least in the first years of the life of the loan; only interest payments are required. This is unusual by international standards. In some countries, repayment of at least some principal is required on all housing loans for the entire life of the loan. In other countries, interest-only loans are available only if the borrower has already contributed a fair degree of equity. So this is one area where Australia stands out. We are not unique in this area, but we are unusual.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>What is an interest only home loan?</h3>\\n<p>An <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest only home loan</a> does <a href=\\\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Does_exactly_what_it_says_on_the_tin\\\">exactly what it says on the tin</a> – it’s a home loan where instead of making repayments that include both the loan’s principal and interest, you only pay interest to your lender instead.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//Oo5T6277z98\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">Interest-only home loans</a> are typically only available for a limited period of time. Many lenders limit interest-only repayments to 1 to 5 year stretches, though some lenders are willing to accept interest-only repayments for longer periods. Once an interest-only period is up, you’ll need to either apply to the lender to start a new interest-only period, or switch to paying principal and interest</p>\\n<h3>Advantages of interest-only loans </h3>\\n<p>One of the most obvious advantages of an interest only loan is that you only need to pay the interest and not the principal, which makes the loan cheaper on a month to month basis. This can make interest-only loans attractive to some owner-occupiers looking to keep their costs down, whether they’re first homebuyers trying to firmly establish their finances, or borrowers seeking to free up more of their income to pay for a renovation or some other personal project.</p>\\n<p>According to governor Lowe, the flexible nature of Australia’s mortgages plays a significant role in the popularity of interest-only loans:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Many people with interest-only loans make significant payments into offset accounts rather than explicitly paying down principal. This flexibility, which is of value to many people, isn&#8217;t available in most countries.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>By paying money into an offset account on an interest only loan, borrowers can reduce their interest repayments, and still access these funds if required much more easily than making a redraw or taking out a line of credit from a principal and interest home loan.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//LUmh9AOzmug\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p>But it’s property investors that can really benefit from interest only loans. By using an interest-only loan to buy a property, an investor can enjoy low <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> (potentially lowered further by an offset account), as well as tax benefits from negative gearing if the interest they pay is higher than the rental income they earn.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Are tax benefits worth investment losses?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">The pros and cons of negative gearing</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/the-pros-and-cons-of-negative-gearing\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>And even though an interest only loan doesn’t reduce the principal, the property’s value can still increase over time, so by the end of the interest-only period, the investor can sell and come out ahead, or reinvest using the resulting equity.     </p>\\n<h3>Disadvantages of interest only loans </h3>\\n<p>While interest only loans may seem relatively affordable because you only need to pay your loan’s interest, if lenders repeatedly raise their interest rates, borrowers could find their <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> quickly growing unaffordable. Similarly, if a lender declines to renew or extend an ending interest only period, borrowers could find themselves unable to afford their higher principal and interest repayments.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Can you afford P&I repayments?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Home Loan Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">Find Out</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>For owner occupiers, interest only loans may be more affordable in the short term, but because the principal isn’t being reduced during the interest-only period, this can mean the loan ultimately takes longer to pay off, and the borrower will pay more in total interest over the lifetime of the loan.</p>\\n<p>For investors, if their property&#8217;s capital growth is sluggish, or even drops in value (not impossible in specific areas) they could reach the end of their interest-only period without enough usable equity available to cover their costs.</p>\\n<h3>How will the new regulations affect interest only loans? </h3>\\n<p>Among <a href=\\\"http://www.apra.gov.au/adi/Publications/Documents/Further%20measures%20to%20reinforce%20sound%20residential%20mortgage%20lending%20practices.pdf\\\">APRA’s new guidelines</a> for banks, lenders and home loan providers are regulations to “limit the flow of new interest-only lending to 30% of new residential mortgage lending”, and to “manage lending to investors in such a manner so as to comfortably remain below the previously advised benchmark of 10% growth.”</p>\\n<p>Limiting the number of new interest-only loans (among other APRA regulations) should help to limit the number of Australians borrowing beyond their means and putting themselves into potentially risky financial positions if interest rates were to rise or house prices to fall.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">What options are available?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How can we fix the housing affordability crisis?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/can-fix-housing-affordability-crisis\\\">Learn More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>These regulations should also contribute to reducing the overall level of risk in the Australian housing market, and help to stabilise the broader Australian economy in case of future economic downturns.  </p>\\n<p>Curbing interest-only loans is also expected to limit the impact of investors on Australia’s housing affordability, which according to governor Lowe, was already under pressure from high demand and limited supply in popular areas:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Not surprisingly, the rising prices have encouraged people to buy residential property as an investment in the hope of ongoing capital gains. With global interest rates so low, many investors have found it attractive to borrow money to invest in appreciating residential property. This has reinforced the upward pressure on prices.”</p>\\n<p>“Like the earlier ‘speed limits’ on investor lending, these new requirements should help the whole system pull back to a more sustainable position. A reduced reliance on interest-only loans in Australia would be a positive development and would help improve our resilience.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>Compare interest-only home loans:</h3>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_comparisonRate=3.8&ab_test_id=0.72&interestOnly=true&sort_field=advertisedRate\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1491562047\",\"dc:creator\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"description\":\"The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Philip Lowe, has shown support for new housing affordability regulations from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders. Speaking at the RBA Board dinner following the central bank’s April meeting, which kept Australia’s &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/looking-interest-loans/\\\" loans\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=63549\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"true\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170407104427/interest-only-loans-compressor-748x420.jpeg\",\"id\":63549,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/looking-interest-loans/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"63549\",\"pubDate\":\"Fri, Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Continuing an eight-month trend, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has held the <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at 1.5 per cent at its April board meeting.</p>\\n<p>In a statement made today, governor Philip Lowe has referenced increases in <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">mortgage rates</a> and growth in household borrowing outpacing growth in household income as influencing the decision.</p>\\n<p>The decision to hold the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> is understandable when you consider how many leading banks, including the big four, have been steadily increasing principal and interest and interest only rates for owner-occupier and investor home loans.</p>\\n<p>On Friday, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) advised banks that it expects them to tighten lending practices on interest-only loans. Following this announcement, three of the four major banks raised interest rates in interest-only and investor loans. </p>\\n<p>“By reinforcing strong lending standards, the recently announced supervisory measures should help address the risks associated with high and rising levels of indebtedness,” Lowe said.</p>\\n<p>“Lenders need to ensure that the serviceability metrics that they use are appropriate for current conditions.”</p>\\n<p>“A reduced reliance on interest-only housing loans in the Australian market would also be a positive development.”</p>\\n<p>New rules implemented by APRA limit interest-only loans with banks to no more than 30 per cent of their total new home lending. APRA chairman, Wayne Byres, advised that this was to ensure banks recognise the “heightened risk in the lending environment, and that their lending standards and practices appropriately respond to these conditions.”</p>\\n<p>Housing prices in Sydney are also at a seven-year high, increasing another 1.4 per cent across Australia in March. Data from property group, CoreLogic, has shown that annual property price growth has grown 19 per cent in Sydney and 16 per cent in Melbourne.</p>\\n<p>It is evident that the RBA will want to see how the growth in household borrowing and increasing mortgage interest rates may affect the Australian economy before making any changes to the cash rate.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Has your bank raised interest rates?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How the big four&#8217;s increases affect you</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">Learn how now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"home loan\",\"RBA and interest rate\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Continuing an eight-month trend, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has held the <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at 1.5 per cent at its April board meeting.</p>\\n<p>In a statement made today, governor Philip Lowe has referenced increases in <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">mortgage rates</a> and growth in household borrowing outpacing growth in household income as influencing the decision.</p>\\n<p>The decision to hold the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> is understandable when you consider how many leading banks, including the big four, have been steadily increasing principal and interest and interest only rates for owner-occupier and investor home loans.</p>\\n<p>On Friday, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) advised banks that it expects them to tighten lending practices on interest-only loans. Following this announcement, three of the four major banks raised interest rates in interest-only and investor loans. </p>\\n<p>“By reinforcing strong lending standards, the recently announced supervisory measures should help address the risks associated with high and rising levels of indebtedness,” Lowe said.</p>\\n<p>“Lenders need to ensure that the serviceability metrics that they use are appropriate for current conditions.”</p>\\n<p>“A reduced reliance on interest-only housing loans in the Australian market would also be a positive development.”</p>\\n<p>New rules implemented by APRA limit interest-only loans with banks to no more than 30 per cent of their total new home lending. APRA chairman, Wayne Byres, advised that this was to ensure banks recognise the “heightened risk in the lending environment, and that their lending standards and practices appropriately respond to these conditions.”</p>\\n<p>Housing prices in Sydney are also at a seven-year high, increasing another 1.4 per cent across Australia in March. Data from property group, CoreLogic, has shown that annual property price growth has grown 19 per cent in Sydney and 16 per cent in Melbourne.</p>\\n<p>It is evident that the RBA will want to see how the growth in household borrowing and increasing mortgage interest rates may affect the Australian economy before making any changes to the cash rate.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Has your bank raised interest rates?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How the big four&#8217;s increases affect you</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">Learn how now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1491318370\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Continuing an eight-month trend, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has held the cash rate at 1.5 per cent at its April board meeting. In a statement made today, governor Philip Lowe has referenced increases in mortgage rates and growth in household borrowing outpacing growth in household income as influencing the decision. The decision to &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"RBA cash rate holds yet again at 1.5 per cent\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=63517\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170404150341/iStock-540127528-725x420.jpg\",\"id\":63517,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"63517\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, 04 Apr 2017 05:06:10 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":2,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170404150341/iStock-540127528-350x482.jpg\",\"title\":\"RBA cash rate holds yet again at 1.5 per cent\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1491321664\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"39\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1491192240:39\",\"_wp_old_slug\":\"credit-card-changes-winners-losers\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"credit-cards\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p><span>From 1 July 2017, new credit card regulations <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/media-releases/2016/mr-16-15.html\\\">recommended by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA)</a> will come into effect, including a cap on interchange fees – the fees that <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit card</a> providers charge banks to cover the cost of processing credit card transactions.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The credit card market is already being shaken up in anticipation of these changes, with banks preparing for the new regulations to take effect. But who exactly will end up better or worse off as a result?</span><span> </span></p>\\n<h3><span>What are interchange fees, and how are they changing?</span></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"cropped image of hands with credit card\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, lenders use interchange fees to help cover the costs of providing credit cards to consumers, including the costs of transferring money from one bank to another. Up until now, interchange fees have been a lucrative business for some lenders, who have been charging interchange fees of up to 3% of the transaction value for some premium credit cards. It has been estimated that banks currently earn approximately $2 billion annually in credit card interchange fees.</span></p>\\n<p><span>When you buy something with a credit card, the merchant’s bank pays the interchange fee to the bank providing your credit card. However, some banks pass the cost of interchange fees on to merchants in the form of Merchant Service Fees, which can cut into the bottom lines of some sellers. As a result, some merchants pass these costs on to customers in turn, whether by raising prices, putting surcharges on credit card transactions, or requiring a minimum spend for credit card payments (often $10 or more).</span></p>\\n<p><span>From 1 July, the RBA is mandating <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/q-and-a/card-payments-regulation-qa-conclusions-paper.html#interchange-fees\\\">a cap on interchange fees of 0.8%</a>. This means that for a $100 credit card purchase, a credit card’s issuer can only charge up to 80c from a merchant’s bank, rather than up to $3 as was previously the case for some premium credit cards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>This change to interchange fees is likely to have a significant impact on how banks and merchants generate revenue from credit card transactions, and on how everyday consumers use their credit cards.</span></p>\\n<h3><span>Who wins and who loses?</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Winning?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Credit cardholders</strong> &#8211; fewer extra charges</li>\\n<li><strong>Merchants</strong> &#8211; reduced merchant service fees</li>\\n<li><strong>People seeking CCs</strong> &#8211; lots of competition</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Losing?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Reward cardholders</strong> &#8211; harder to earn points</li>\\n<li><strong>Banks</strong> &#8211; losing interchange fee revenue</li>\\n<li><strong>Everyday cardholders</strong> &#8211; fees may increase</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Smiling young woman holding a credit card and typing on a laptop.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The question of whether credit card users will ultimately be better or </span><span>worse off from these new interchange fee regulations may ultimately depend on whether they’re using their credit cards as a simple and affordable way to buy now and pay later, or as a means to earn premium rewards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Consumers with rewards credit cards could be in for a tough time, as from mid-2017, it may be much more difficult and/or expensive to earn a free flight to the Gold Coast simply by regularly spending on your credit card. The forecast reduction in revenue from interchange fees means that banks may need to limit, reduce, or remove some of the extra benefits and services they offer, including credit card rewards. For example, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> recently got rid of high-reward <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> Reward Cards:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Changes to interchange fees are expected to hit credit cards with rewards programs the hardest, and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> credit cards are renowned for their competitive rewards.</p>\\n<p>Some banks issue <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards with their credit cards, where an Amex is linked to the same account as your Visa or MasterCard, so you can access its reward program. The new caps on interchange fees could lead to many of these Amex companion cards being withdrawn from the market.</p>\\n<p>However, credit cards issued by <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> itself deal directly with the merchant’s bank rather than going through a separate issuing bank, so interchange fees aren&#8217;t involved. You&#8217;ll still need to pay above-average interest rates and fees in some cases, but you&#8217;ll continue to enjoy access to the competitive Amex rewards program.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>For consumers with simpler low-rate credit cards without a rewards program, t</span><span>he new RBA regulations could make flashing the plastic at the checkout a much more viable option, no matter the transaction. </span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\"><img class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Bartender receiving credit card of customer for payment in cafe\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The new caps on interchange fees should help to keep the corresponding merchant service fees relatively low, thus providing merchants the flexibility to offer more competitive pricing and eliminate minimum spend amounts for credit card payments. Credit card surcharges may remain, but a separate set of regulations (<a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/conclusions-paper-may2016/excessive-surcharging.html\\\">effective September 2016 for large businesses, and September 2017 for small businesses</a>) should limit these to just cover the cost of the merchant service fee.</span></p>\\n<p><span>Another potential outcome of these regulations could end up affecting many credit cardholders. If banks start looking for other ways to raise the revenue they once got from interchange fees, it’s possible that they may start increasing the annual fees, late payment fees, and other charges on credit cards.    </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//TypXILYH3E0\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><span>Because it’s likely that many banks and lenders will make changes to their credit card offers as a result of these regulations, it’s also likely that many consumers may start considering alternative credit card options – the perfect time for smart lenders to unveil competitive new credit card deals. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, there are 180 different <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit cards</a> to choose from on the Australian market, including 83 <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/reward-programs\\\">credit cards with rewards programs</a>. If you find yourself in the market for a new or replacement credit card, remember to <a href=\\\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/compare\\\">compare credit cards</a> to find the options that will prove the most suitable for your unique financial situation. </span></p>\",\"category\":[\"credit cards\",\"interchange fees\",\"RateCity\",\"rba\",\"regulations\",\"reserve bank of australia\",\"rewards\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p><span>From 1 July 2017, new credit card regulations <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/media-releases/2016/mr-16-15.html\\\">recommended by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA)</a> will come into effect, including a cap on interchange fees – the fees that <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit card</a> providers charge banks to cover the cost of processing credit card transactions.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The credit card market is already being shaken up in anticipation of these changes, with banks preparing for the new regulations to take effect. But who exactly will end up better or worse off as a result?</span><span> </span></p>\\n<h3><span>What are interchange fees, and how are they changing?</span></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"cropped image of hands with credit card\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, lenders use interchange fees to help cover the costs of providing credit cards to consumers, including the costs of transferring money from one bank to another. Up until now, interchange fees have been a lucrative business for some lenders, who have been charging interchange fees of up to 3% of the transaction value for some premium credit cards. It has been estimated that banks currently earn approximately $2 billion annually in credit card interchange fees.</span></p>\\n<p><span>When you buy something with a credit card, the merchant’s bank pays the interchange fee to the bank providing your credit card. However, some banks pass the cost of interchange fees on to merchants in the form of Merchant Service Fees, which can cut into the bottom lines of some sellers. As a result, some merchants pass these costs on to customers in turn, whether by raising prices, putting surcharges on credit card transactions, or requiring a minimum spend for credit card payments (often $10 or more).</span></p>\\n<p><span>From 1 July, the RBA is mandating <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/q-and-a/card-payments-regulation-qa-conclusions-paper.html#interchange-fees\\\">a cap on interchange fees of 0.8%</a>. This means that for a $100 credit card purchase, a credit card’s issuer can only charge up to 80c from a merchant’s bank, rather than up to $3 as was previously the case for some premium credit cards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>This change to interchange fees is likely to have a significant impact on how banks and merchants generate revenue from credit card transactions, and on how everyday consumers use their credit cards.</span></p>\\n<h3><span>Who wins and who loses?</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Winning?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Credit cardholders</strong> &#8211; fewer extra charges</li>\\n<li><strong>Merchants</strong> &#8211; reduced merchant service fees</li>\\n<li><strong>People seeking CCs</strong> &#8211; lots of competition</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Losing?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Reward cardholders</strong> &#8211; harder to earn points</li>\\n<li><strong>Banks</strong> &#8211; losing interchange fee revenue</li>\\n<li><strong>Everyday cardholders</strong> &#8211; fees may increase</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Smiling young woman holding a credit card and typing on a laptop.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The question of whether credit card users will ultimately be better or </span><span>worse off from these new interchange fee regulations may ultimately depend on whether they’re using their credit cards as a simple and affordable way to buy now and pay later, or as a means to earn premium rewards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Consumers with rewards credit cards could be in for a tough time, as from mid-2017, it may be much more difficult and/or expensive to earn a free flight to the Gold Coast simply by regularly spending on your credit card. The forecast reduction in revenue from interchange fees means that banks may need to limit, reduce, or remove some of the extra benefits and services they offer, including credit card rewards. For example, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> recently got rid of high-reward <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> Reward Cards:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Changes to interchange fees are expected to hit credit cards with rewards programs the hardest, and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> credit cards are renowned for their competitive rewards.</p>\\n<p>Some banks issue <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards with their credit cards, where an Amex is linked to the same account as your Visa or MasterCard, so you can access its reward program. The new caps on interchange fees could lead to many of these Amex companion cards being withdrawn from the market.</p>\\n<p>However, credit cards issued by <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> itself deal directly with the merchant’s bank rather than going through a separate issuing bank, so interchange fees aren&#8217;t involved. You&#8217;ll still need to pay above-average interest rates and fees in some cases, but you&#8217;ll continue to enjoy access to the competitive Amex rewards program.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>For consumers with simpler low-rate credit cards without a rewards program, t</span><span>he new RBA regulations could make flashing the plastic at the checkout a much more viable option, no matter the transaction. </span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\"><img class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Bartender receiving credit card of customer for payment in cafe\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The new caps on interchange fees should help to keep the corresponding merchant service fees relatively low, thus providing merchants the flexibility to offer more competitive pricing and eliminate minimum spend amounts for credit card payments. Credit card surcharges may remain, but a separate set of regulations (<a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/conclusions-paper-may2016/excessive-surcharging.html\\\">effective September 2016 for large businesses, and September 2017 for small businesses</a>) should limit these to just cover the cost of the merchant service fee.</span></p>\\n<p><span>Another potential outcome of these regulations could end up affecting many credit cardholders. If banks start looking for other ways to raise the revenue they once got from interchange fees, it’s possible that they may start increasing the annual fees, late payment fees, and other charges on credit cards.    </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//TypXILYH3E0\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><span>Because it’s likely that many banks and lenders will make changes to their credit card offers as a result of these regulations, it’s also likely that many consumers may start considering alternative credit card options – the perfect time for smart lenders to unveil competitive new credit card deals. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, there are 180 different <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit cards</a> to choose from on the Australian market, including 83 <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/reward-programs\\\">credit cards with rewards programs</a>. If you find yourself in the market for a new or replacement credit card, remember to <a href=\\\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/compare\\\">compare credit cards</a> to find the options that will prove the most suitable for your unique financial situation. </span></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1491228039\",\"dc:creator\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"description\":\"From 1 July 2017, new credit card regulations recommended by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will come into effect, including a cap on interchange fees – the fees that credit card providers charge banks to cover the cost of processing credit card transactions. The credit card market is already being shaken up in anticipation &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Credit card interchange fee changes – winners and losers\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62902\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"true\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328135518/interchange-fee-733x420.jpeg\",\"id\":62902,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62902\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon,
