losers\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1491228328\",\"url\":\"/credit-cards/news/credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1491264028:39\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Yet another of the big four banks has increased <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a>, with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\\\">Commonwealth Bank</a> of Australia (CBA) raising borrowing costs for owner-occupiers and property investors.</p>\\n<p>These increases will see CBA raise principal and interest loan interest rates to 5.25 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.80 per cent for investors. Interest only loan rates will also be increasing to 5.47 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.94 per cent for investors.</p>\\n<p>CBA’s rate increases come hot on the heels of <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a>, and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> announcing similar increases to their owner-occupied and investment home loans only hours earlier.</p>\\n<h4><strong>Big Four Bank Rate Increases:</strong></h4>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170329091412/Screen-Shot-2017-03-29-at-10.13.46-AM.png\\\" /></p>\\n<p><em> * Based on $500,000 principal and 30 year loan term.</em></p>\\n<p><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\\\">NAB</a> and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a> customers may be feeling the pinch, as rate increases to owner-occupied and investment loans have already come into effect.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">What will this cost everyday Australians?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Examples:</p>\\n<p>Customers with owner-occupier, interest only loans with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a> can expect to pay an extra $400 per year.*</p>\\n<p>Investors with interest only loans with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\\\">NAB</a> will also find themselves out of pocket an extra $1,250 per year.*</p>\\n<p>*<em>Based </em><em>on $500,000 principal and 30 year loan term.</em></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>However, CBA and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> customers still have time to assess their existing loans and whether they’ll be better off switching.</p>\\n<p>In a statement made on Friday, Matt Comyn, CBA’s Group Executive for Retail Banking Services, announced the May 8 deadline has been put in place to minimise the impact for the majority of home loan customers.</p>\\n<p>“Rising costs and regulatory responsibilities mean we are increasing home loan interest rates” he said, regarding the cause of these rate increases.</p>\\n<p>These ‘regulatory responsibilities’ relate to increasing concerns about a property bubble in Australia. Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) chairman, Greg Medcraft, issued the warning at their recent annual forum in Sydney. ASIC are working with Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) to help mitigate these risks, such as encouraging responsible lending by curbing loans to investors. </p>\\n<p>Only last month CBA announced they were blocking the refinancing of some investor loans as a response to these regulations. CBA subsidiary, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">BankWest</a>, also halted all investment lending to new borrowers.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to learn more?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Banks Blocking Investor Loans</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/61989\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"home loan\",\"interest rates\",\"investor\",\"mortgage\",\"owner-occupier\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Yet another of the big four banks has increased <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a>, with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\\\">Commonwealth Bank</a> of Australia (CBA) raising borrowing costs for owner-occupiers and property investors.</p>\\n<p>These increases will see CBA raise principal and interest loan interest rates to 5.25 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.80 per cent for investors. Interest only loan rates will also be increasing to 5.47 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.94 per cent for investors.</p>\\n<p>CBA’s rate increases come hot on the heels of <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a>, and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> announcing similar increases to their owner-occupied and investment home loans only hours earlier.</p>\\n<h4><strong>Big Four Bank Rate Increases:</strong></h4>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170329091412/Screen-Shot-2017-03-29-at-10.13.46-AM.png\\\" /></p>\\n<p><em> * Based on $500,000 principal and 30 year loan term.</em></p>\\n<p><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\\\">NAB</a> and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a> customers may be feeling the pinch, as rate increases to owner-occupied and investment loans have already come into effect.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">What will this cost everyday Australians?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Examples:</p>\\n<p>Customers with owner-occupier, interest only loans with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a> can expect to pay an extra $400 per year.*</p>\\n<p>Investors with interest only loans with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\\\">NAB</a> will also find themselves out of pocket an extra $1,250 per year.*</p>\\n<p>*<em>Based </em><em>on $500,000 principal and 30 year loan term.</em></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>However, CBA and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> customers still have time to assess their existing loans and whether they’ll be better off switching.</p>\\n<p>In a statement made on Friday, Matt Comyn, CBA’s Group Executive for Retail Banking Services, announced the May 8 deadline has been put in place to minimise the impact for the majority of home loan customers.</p>\\n<p>“Rising costs and regulatory responsibilities mean we are increasing home loan interest rates” he said, regarding the cause of these rate increases.</p>\\n<p>These ‘regulatory responsibilities’ relate to increasing concerns about a property bubble in Australia. Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) chairman, Greg Medcraft, issued the warning at their recent annual forum in Sydney. ASIC are working with Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) to help mitigate these risks, such as encouraging responsible lending by curbing loans to investors. </p>\\n<p>Only last month CBA announced they were blocking the refinancing of some investor loans as a response to these regulations. CBA subsidiary, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">BankWest</a>, also halted all investment lending to new borrowers.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to learn more?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Banks Blocking Investor Loans</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/61989\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1490706371\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Yet another of the big four banks has increased home loan rates, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) raising borrowing costs for owner-occupiers and property investors. These increases will see CBA raise principal and interest loan interest rates to 5.25 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.80 per cent for investors. Interest only loan rates will &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"How will the big four’s interest rate increases affect you?\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62907\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328130803/iStock-577640492-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62907,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62907\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, 28 Mar 2017 03:06:11 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":2,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328130803/iStock-577640492-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"How will the big four’s interest rate increases affect you?\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1490778966\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1490334508:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"car-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>When it comes to choosing a car loan, it pays to be as picky as you would be when choosing the actual car.</p>\\n<p>There are several features you should examine when comparing car loans and picking between a secure or unsecure loan is one of the most significant.<strong> </strong></p>\\n<h3><strong>Secured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p>A secured car loan refers to a type of car loan in which lenders generally use the purchase as an asset for security against the loan. Some lenders are also willing to use property, term deposits or other assets such as jewellery as security against the loan. A secured car loan usually also has a lower interest rate than an unsecured loan due to borrowers offering security posing less of a risk to lenders.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Unsecured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/unsecured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Unsecured car loans</a> do not require security to be held against the loan. However, you will need to prove that you can make the repayments through a good credit history, your ability to save, or if you previously had a personal loan or credit card and met the repayments. As this type of car loan is riskier due to the lack of security, you will usually incur higher interest rates and/or not be approved to borrow as much as you would on a secured loan.</p>\\n<h3><strong>What loan type is right for you?</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/secured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Secured loans</a> are a competitive choice for borrowers looking to take advantage of lower interest rates and higher borrowing amounts, as it allows you to appear as less of a risk to lenders. However, if you’re a reliable borrower with a history of paying off debt, an unsecured loan may work for you, as you will not run the risk of losing the purchase in the event you can’t pay back the loan.</p>\\n<p>Some lenders also only allow new vehicles (two years or younger) to be used as security, with older cars needing to pass vehicle inspection checks.</p>\\n<p>Regardless of your loan type, if you cannot pay back your car loan and your car has devalued past the point of the outstanding balance, the lender can take you to court for the remainder.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros of secured loans</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">You’re seen as lower risk to lenders</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Lower interest rates</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Parents can sign as guarantor</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Can borrow a higher amount</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons of secured loans</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">If you default, the lender will claim the security</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Some lenders only accept new vehicles (less than two years old) as a guarantee</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">If your car devalues, the lender can still take you to court to pay the balance – car is not a 100% safe back up</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153625/iStock-540836094-e1490333802639.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>What else should you consider?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Apart from secured vs. unsecured, you’ll need to examine and compare a few more factors before deciding which car loan is suitable for you.</p>\\n<p>If budgeting is your main concern, you’ll want to consider the type of interest rate for the car loan. You may be leaning towards a secured car loan with a lower interest rate, however, if the rate is variable it may be harder to budget for, as your repayments may change every month. Both secured and unsecured car loans can have either a fixed or variable rate, depending on the lender’s product.</p>\\n<p>You’ll also want to examine the loan fees involved and whether any upfront or early exit penalty fees apply to fully calculate the total amount you will pay over the lifetime of your loan. Checking the comparison rate of a car loan is a great way to estimate its overall cost. </p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/car-loans/rate-table?cl_per_page=4&cl_securedType%5B0%5D=Secured&ab_test_id=0.12\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"category\":[\"car loan\",\"car loans\",\"car loans australia\",\"fixed rate car loans\",\"secured car loan\",\"unsecured car loans\",\"variable car rate loans\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>When it comes to choosing a car loan, it pays to be as picky as you would be when choosing the actual car.</p>\\n<p>There are several features you should examine when comparing car loans and picking between a secure or unsecure loan is one of the most significant.<strong> </strong></p>\\n<h3><strong>Secured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p>A secured car loan refers to a type of car loan in which lenders generally use the purchase as an asset for security against the loan. Some lenders are also willing to use property, term deposits or other assets such as jewellery as security against the loan. A secured car loan usually also has a lower interest rate than an unsecured loan due to borrowers offering security posing less of a risk to lenders.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Unsecured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/unsecured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Unsecured car loans</a> do not require security to be held against the loan. However, you will need to prove that you can make the repayments through a good credit history, your ability to save, or if you previously had a personal loan or credit card and met the repayments. As this type of car loan is riskier due to the lack of security, you will usually incur higher interest rates and/or not be approved to borrow as much as you would on a secured loan.</p>\\n<h3><strong>What loan type is right for you?</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/secured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Secured loans</a> are a competitive choice for borrowers looking to take advantage of lower interest rates and higher borrowing amounts, as it allows you to appear as less of a risk to lenders. However, if you’re a reliable borrower with a history of paying off debt, an unsecured loan may work for you, as you will not run the risk of losing the purchase in the event you can’t pay back the loan.</p>\\n<p>Some lenders also only allow new vehicles (two years or younger) to be used as security, with older cars needing to pass vehicle inspection checks.</p>\\n<p>Regardless of your loan type, if you cannot pay back your car loan and your car has devalued past the point of the outstanding balance, the lender can take you to court for the remainder.</p>\\n<div guarantee</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">If your car devalues, the lender can still take you to court to pay the balance – car is not a 100% safe back up</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153625/iStock-540836094-e1490333802639.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>What else should you consider?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Apart from secured vs. unsecured, you’ll need to examine and compare a few more factors before deciding which car loan is suitable for you.</p>\\n<p>If budgeting is your main concern, you’ll want to consider the type of interest rate for the car loan. You may be leaning towards a secured car loan with a lower interest rate, however, if the rate is variable it may be harder to budget for, as your repayments may change every month. Both secured and unsecured car loans can have either a fixed or variable rate, depending on the lender’s product.</p>\\n<p>You’ll also want to examine the loan fees involved and whether any upfront or early exit penalty fees apply to fully calculate the total amount you will pay over the lifetime of your loan. Checking the comparison rate of a car loan is a great way to estimate its overall cost. </p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/car-loans/rate-table?cl_per_page=4&cl_securedType%5B0%5D=Secured&ab_test_id=0.12\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1490370035\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"When it comes to choosing a car loan, it pays to be as picky as you would be when choosing the actual car. There are several features you should examine when comparing car loans and picking between a secure or unsecure loan is one of the most significant.  Secured Car Loan A secured car loan &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secure-car-loan/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Should I secure my car loan?\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62890\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153305/iStock-506879326-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62890,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secure-car-loan/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62890\",\"pubDate\":\"Fri, 24 Mar 2017 05:40:35 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"secure-car-loan\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153305/iStock-506879326-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"Should I secure my car loan?\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1490370035\",\"url\":\"/car-loans/news/secure-car-loan\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1490157881:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Did you know some banks compete to give certain borrowers a home loan? They offer inducements such as interest rate discounts and waived fees all because these people are ‘ideal borrowers’.</p>\\n<p>RateCity data indicates that these ideal borrowers receive, on average, 0.55 per cent lower interest rates from lenders than other borrowers. So, what are their secrets?</p>\\n<h3><strong>What is an ideal borrower?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Ideal borrowers are those who present the least amount of risk to lenders in terms of defaulting on their loan.  They will have a good credit rating, including a proven track record of paying their bills and credit cards on time. They will also have a deposit of at least 20 per cent and be intending to live in the home they buy.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Becoming an ideal borrower</strong><strong> </strong></h3>\\n<p>The trick to getting these discounted <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a> is to become an ideal borrower.</p>\\n<p>One of the best ways to position yourself as an ideal borrower is to save as large a deposit as possible. This shows lenders that you are less of a risk as they will have less to recoup if you default on the loan. It also proves that you are the type of borrower who can save a large nest egg.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much can you borrow?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Borrow Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow?nav=borrow-calculator\\\">Learn Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>That said, saving up a 20 per cent deposit is no easy feat, especially if you live in Sydney or Melbourne where this would equate to saving $150,000 to $200,000. Luckily, there are other ways you become an ‘ideal borrower’ and take advantage of lower interest rates.</p>\\n<ol>\\n<li><strong>Get a guarantor</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>One way to become a more attractive borrower is to get a guarantor.</p>\\n<p>If you have the support of someone with equity in their home they can be linked to your home loan and their property will be used as additional security. Lenders tend to only allow immediate family members as guarantors, but this can differ depending on the lender.</p>\\n<p>The main concern with this type of loan is that if you default on your loan the lender can take action against the borrower and guarantor, and your guarantor will be liable for your home loan.  </p>\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\">\\n<li><strong>Take extra precautions if you’re self-employed</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Applying for a home loan can be a daunting process if you’re self-employed. However, if you organise all your financial records before you apply you will be in a much stronger position, particularly when lenders are looking to identify consistency of income. Lenders look for transparency when assessing risk, so make sure you can identify all your business expenses, such as car allowance, deprecation, non-recurring expenses etc.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Are you really self-employed?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span>It’s also important to clarify whether you are actually self-employed in the bank’s eyes because some lenders consider contractors or sub-contractors as employees.</span><strong> </strong></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\">\\n<li><strong>Correct your credit history</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Your credit score is one of the major deciding factors for lenders when assessing whether you are eligible for a loan, let alone a loan with a discounted interest rate. They will go through your history with a fine-tooth comb looking for any missed or defaulted payments.</p>\\n<p>The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) recently reported that 30 per cent of Australians have errors on their credit report. It is worth getting a copy of your credit report from <a href=\\\"http://www.equifax.com.au/getcreditscore/\\\">Veda</a> and going through it very carefully just in case of mistakes, such as strangers or family members with similar names having their debt incorrectly labelled as yours. </p>\",\"category\":[\"home loan\",\"interest rates\",\"mortgage\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Did you know some banks compete to give certain borrowers a home loan? They offer inducements such as interest rate discounts and waived fees all because these people are ‘ideal borrowers’.</p>\\n<p>RateCity data indicates that these ideal borrowers receive, on average, 0.55 per cent lower interest rates from lenders than other borrowers. So, what are their secrets?</p>\\n<h3><strong>What is an ideal borrower?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Ideal borrowers are those who present the least amount of risk to lenders in terms of defaulting on their loan.  They will have a good credit rating, including a proven track record of paying their bills and credit cards on time. They will also have a deposit of at least 20 per cent and be intending to live in the home they buy.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Becoming an ideal borrower</strong><strong> </strong></h3>\\n<p>The trick to getting these discounted <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a> is to become an ideal borrower.</p>\\n<p>One of the best ways to position yourself as an ideal borrower is to save as large a deposit as possible. This shows lenders that you are less of a risk as they will have less to recoup if you default on the loan. It also proves that you are the type of borrower who can save a large nest egg.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much can you borrow?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Borrow Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow?nav=borrow-calculator\\\">Learn Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>That said, saving up a 20 per cent deposit is no easy feat, especially if you live in Sydney or Melbourne where this would equate to saving $150,000 to $200,000. Luckily, there are other ways you become an ‘ideal borrower’ and take advantage of lower interest rates.</p>\\n<ol>\\n<li><strong>Get a guarantor</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>One way to become a more attractive borrower is to get a guarantor.</p>\\n<p>If you have the support of someone with equity in their home they can be linked to your home loan and their property will be used as additional security. Lenders tend to only allow immediate family members as guarantors, but this can differ depending on the lender.</p>\\n<p>The main concern with this type of loan is that if you default on your loan the lender can take action against the borrower and guarantor, and your guarantor will be liable for your home loan.  </p>\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\">\\n<li><strong>Take extra precautions if you’re self-employed</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Applying for a home loan can be a daunting process if you’re self-employed. However, if you organise all your financial records before you apply you will be in a much stronger position, particularly when lenders are looking to identify consistency of income. Lenders look for transparency when assessing risk, so make sure you can identify all your business expenses, such as car allowance, deprecation, non-recurring expenses etc.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Are you really self-employed?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span>It’s also important to clarify whether you are actually self-employed in the bank’s eyes because some lenders consider contractors or sub-contractors as employees.</span><strong> </strong></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\">\\n<li><strong>Correct your credit history</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Your credit score is one of the major deciding factors for lenders when assessing whether you are eligible for a loan, let alone a loan with a discounted interest rate. They will go through your history with a fine-tooth comb looking for any missed or defaulted payments.</p>\\n<p>The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) recently reported that 30 per cent of Australians have errors on their credit report. It is worth getting a copy of your credit report from <a href=\\\"http://www.equifax.com.au/getcreditscore/\\\">Veda</a> and going through it very carefully just in case of mistakes, such as strangers or family members with similar names having their debt incorrectly labelled as yours. </p>\",\"created_at\":\"1490188735\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Did you know some banks compete to give certain borrowers a home loan? They offer inducements such as interest rate discounts and waived fees all because these people are ‘ideal borrowers’. RateCity data indicates that these ideal borrowers receive, on average, 0.55 per cent lower interest rates from lenders than other borrowers. So, what are &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"The secrets to getting the lowest home loan rate\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62826\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170322131648/iStock-505472872-1-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62826,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62826\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 22 Mar 2017 03:18:55 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170322131648/iStock-505472872-1-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"The secrets to getting the lowest home loan rate\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1490188790\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"}],\"banking\":[{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1489462264:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"savings-accounts\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<ul>\\n<li><strong>Pay your own way </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>We’ve all been in the awkward position where someone suggests you divide the dinner bill evenly and you only ordered a salad, but they’ve had a main, dessert and two cocktails. Being assertive and making sure you pay your own way will ensure that you don’t overspend.</p>\\n<p>Sometimes paying your own way can get a little tricky, particularly if you’re share housing or are a generous friend and family member. An expense sharing or tracking app such as <a href=\\\"https://www.splitwise.com/\\\">Splitwise</a> takes the trouble out of sharing expenses and splitting your bills. The app stores all expenses and IOU’s in one place and provides “fairness calculators” that gives users mediation advice about money fairness issues.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Wait 72 hours before buying anything</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>This advice can be applied to any non-essential purchase but would be most effective to keep an online shopping habit under control.  Before you press that check out button, give yourself three days to think it over and decide whether you really need to spend money.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Shop around for your home loan</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Just because you’ve been with the same bank since you were a kid doesn’t mean you must take out your home loan with them. Comparing various home loan products based on your individual needs could see you saving thousands of dollars over the lifetime of your loan by ensuring you pick one that is right for you. </p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&h_rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&h_rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&h_rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&h_rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&h_rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&h_rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&h_rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&h_rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&h_rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&h_rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years&group_by=companyName&rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Investment apps</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>While it may seem counterproductive to spend your money to save it, investment apps are just another exciting way to invest your spare change instead of a traditional piggy bank.</p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://acornsau.com.au/\\\">Acorns</a> is a popular investing app in Australia that does just that. Whatever small amount you spend, Acorns will round up that purchase to the nearest dollar and invest the difference. For example, if you spent $12.50 on lunch, Acorns will take 50c and store it in your portfolio for investment.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Use cash!</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>This one is pretty simple; if you have to watch your money physically leave your wallet, you’ll feel less inclined to spend it.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Zero spend day</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Try to dedicate one day a week or fortnight to zero spending – and stick to it! Maybe you want to have a lazy Sunday? Or maybe you’ve done all your grocery shopping on a Thursday night and made it so you don’t need to buy lunch on Fridays? Whichever way you implement them, zero spending days will help you force yourself to save.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Credit card rewards programs </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>If you’re more of a tap-and-go than cash-in-hand spender, why not pick out a credit card that rewards you for using it to make everyday transactions. Some credit card rewards programs offer up to three points per dollar spent, or bonus points for shopping at certain stores or spending a certain amount of money. These types of cards generally charge higher interest rates and fees than standard credit cards, so it’s best that you pay your debt each month to prevent the interest costs outweighing the benefits of the rewards offers.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">What rewars could you earn?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare Reward Programs</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/reward-programs?nav=reward-programs-credit-cards\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Complete other people’s tasks</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>If you haven’t heard of <a href=\\\"https://www.airtasker.com/\\\">Airtasker</a>, it’s a website that allows people and businesses to outsource their tasks. A user will describe the task they need completed (cleaning, mowing their lawn, editing the grammar in their essay, updating their website etc.) and you can help these users to complete these jobs to earn money. You could earn up to $5,000 per month just by completing tasks.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Transfer your credit card balance</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Are you paying one or even multiple credit card debts? Is the interest hurting your ability to save? Credit card holders who transfer their balance to a new card could save an average of $1,262 in interest and fees and pay their debt off 6 months earlier.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Start saving today</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Balance Transfer Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/balance-transfer-calculator?nav=balance-transfer-calculator\\\">Calculate</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Be smart with your food</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Our relationship with food is often criticised as wasteful. <a href=\\\"http://www.foodwise.com.au/foodwaste/food-waste-fast-facts/\\\">Food Wise</a> believes that Australians discard up to 20 per cent of the food they purchase, which equates to 1 out of 5 bags of groceries they buy. Overall, the average Australian household throws away $1,036 worth of food every year, totalling around $8 billion dollars. To help curb this problem, try to use some recipes that help you clean out your fridge. Website such as <a href=\\\"http://www.supercook.com/#/recipes\\\">Supercook</a> allow you to input your ingredients and instantly find matching recipes from popular cooking sites.</p>\\n<p>Further, RateCity recently calculated that packing your own lunch every day amounts to a <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/news/much-save-packing-lunch\\\">saving of around $1,400 every year</a>. if you were to put these savings away, you would have an additional $42,000 after 30 years.</p>\",\"category\":[\"money\",\"savings accounts\",\"tips\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<ul>\\n<li><strong>Pay your own way </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>We’ve all been in the awkward position where someone suggests you divide the dinner bill evenly and you only ordered a salad, but they’ve had a main, dessert and two cocktails. Being assertive and making sure you pay your own way will ensure that you don’t overspend.</p>\\n<p>Sometimes paying your own way can get a little tricky, particularly if you’re share housing or are a generous friend and family member. An expense sharing or tracking app such as <a href=\\\"https://www.splitwise.com/\\\">Splitwise</a> takes the trouble out of sharing expenses and splitting your bills. The app stores all expenses and IOU’s in one place and provides “fairness calculators” that gives users mediation advice about money fairness issues.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Wait 72 hours before buying anything</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>This advice can be applied to any non-essential purchase but would be most effective to keep an online shopping habit under control.  Before you press that check out button, give yourself three days to think it over and decide whether you really need to spend money.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Shop around for your home loan</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Just because you’ve been with the same bank since you were a kid doesn’t mean you must take out your home loan with them. Comparing various home loan products based on your individual needs could see you saving thousands of dollars over the lifetime of your loan by ensuring you pick one that is right for you. </p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&h_rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&h_rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&h_rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&h_rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&h_rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&h_rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&h_rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&h_rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&h_rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&h_rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years&group_by=companyName&rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Investment apps</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>While it may seem counterproductive to spend your money to save it, investment apps are just another exciting way to invest your spare change instead of a traditional piggy bank.</p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://acornsau.com.au/\\\">Acorns</a> is a popular investing app in Australia that does just that. Whatever small amount you spend, Acorns will round up that purchase to the nearest dollar and invest the difference. For example, if you spent $12.50 on lunch, Acorns will take 50c and store it in your portfolio for investment.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Use cash!</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>This one is pretty simple; if you have to watch your money physically leave your wallet, you’ll feel less inclined to spend it.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Zero spend day</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Try to dedicate one day a week or fortnight to zero spending – and stick to it! Maybe you want to have a lazy Sunday? Or maybe you’ve done all your grocery shopping on a Thursday night and made it so you don’t need to buy lunch on Fridays? Whichever way you implement them, zero spending days will help you force yourself to save.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Credit card rewards programs </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>If you’re more of a tap-and-go than cash-in-hand spender, why not pick out a credit card that rewards you for using it to make everyday transactions. Some credit card rewards programs offer up to three points per dollar spent, or bonus points for shopping at certain stores or spending a certain amount of money. These types of cards generally charge higher interest rates and fees than standard credit cards, so it’s best that you pay your debt each month to prevent the interest costs outweighing the benefits of the rewards offers.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">What rewars could you earn?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare Reward Programs</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/reward-programs?nav=reward-programs-credit-cards\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Complete other people’s tasks</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>If you haven’t heard of <a href=\\\"https://www.airtasker.com/\\\">Airtasker</a>, it’s a website that allows people and businesses to outsource their tasks. A user will describe the task they need completed (cleaning, mowing their lawn, editing the grammar in their essay, updating their website etc.) and you can help these users to complete these jobs to earn money. You could earn up to $5,000 per month just by completing tasks.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Transfer your credit card balance</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Are you paying one or even multiple credit card debts? Is the interest hurting your ability to save? Credit card holders who transfer their balance to a new card could save an average of $1,262 in interest and fees and pay their debt off 6 months earlier.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Start saving today</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Balance Transfer Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/balance-transfer-calculator?nav=balance-transfer-calculator\\\">Calculate</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Be smart with your food</strong></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Our relationship with food is often criticised as wasteful. <a href=\\\"http://www.foodwise.com.au/foodwaste/food-waste-fast-facts/\\\">Food Wise</a> believes that Australians discard up to 20 per cent of the food they purchase, which equates to 1 out of 5 bags of groceries they buy. Overall, the average Australian household throws away $1,036 worth of food every year, totalling around $8 billion dollars. To help curb this problem, try to use some recipes that help you clean out your fridge. Website such as <a href=\\\"http://www.supercook.com/#/recipes\\\">Supercook</a> allow you to input your ingredients and instantly find matching recipes from popular cooking sites.</p>\\n<p>Further, RateCity recently calculated that packing your own lunch every day amounts to a <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/news/much-save-packing-lunch\\\">saving of around $1,400 every year</a>. if you were to put these savings away, you would have an additional $42,000 after 30 years.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1489496490\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Pay your own way We’ve all been in the awkward position where someone suggests you divide the dinner bill evenly and you only ordered a salad, but they’ve had a main, dessert and two cocktails. Being assertive and making sure you pay your own way will ensure that you don’t overspend. Sometimes paying your own &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/10-money-pro-tips-need-try/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"10 money pro tips you need to try\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62696\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170314124125/iStock-509713034-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62696,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/10-money-pro-tips-need-try/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62696\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, 14 Mar 2017 03:01:30 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":4,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"10-money-pro-tips-need-try\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170314124125/iStock-509713034-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"10 money pro tips you need to try\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1489496800\",\"url\":\"/savings-accounts/news/10-money-pro-tips-need-try\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1489117748:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"savings-accounts\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>It takes a very organised person to pack their lunch every day, and let’s admit it, most people don’t feel like they have the time or energy to prepare a week’s worth of food. But how much does buying lunch every day really cost us? And what could that money be better spent on?</p>\\n<p>Whether you’re a sandwich kind of person, or you’re indulging in a burger and chips, your daily lunch spend could range anywhere between $5 &#8211; $25. For argument’s sake, let’s say you’re spending on average $10 a day on lunch. This amounts to around $2,400 a year (depending on annual leave, sick leave etc).</p>\\n<p>If you’re preparing your lunches at home, you’ll have a few advantages under your belt. A sandwich you’re buying out will probably cost you $6 more than one you prepare yourself using ingredients you already have at home. Not to mention the cost of making a large serving of pasta that will last for a few days’ worth of lunches versus your average $7 &#8211; $12 or more pasta at a café/restaurant.</p>\\n<p>If you’re spending on average around $4 per meal you prepare at home, you’re saving $6 a day. This amounts to a saving of around $1,400 every year, which is a significant amount to lose by not making your own lunches.</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170310132058/iStock-512896006-e1489116069752.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>What could you be spending this on?</strong></h3>\\n<p>There are a multitude of ways you could spend this money to save for your present, but you should really be thinking about your future.</p>\\n<p>If you put these savings of $1,400 a year away for your retirement, you will have an additional $42,000 after 30 years. This amount would be invaluable for anyone looking to spend their retirement, and a great incentive for those of us who struggle to bring themselves to spend Sunday evenings packing lunches.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Invest in your future</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare Super Funds</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation/search?nav=superannuation-search\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>If you open a savings account with a base amount of $1,400 and an interest rate of 0.25 per cent, while adding $1,400 every year saved on packed lunches, you will have a balance of around $15,500 after 10 years. After 30 years, the balance of your savings account would be around $44,800.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much money could you save?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare High Interest Savings Accounts</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/high-interest?nav=high-interest-savings-accounts\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>It may not be realistic to expect every lunch you have for the remainder of your working years be pre-made, but if you try to do this as much as you can, the savings will be worth it.</p>\",\"category\":[\"money\",\"savings accounts\",\"superannuation\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>It takes a very organised person to pack their lunch every day, and let’s admit it, most people don’t feel like they have the time or energy to prepare a week’s worth of food. But how much does buying lunch every day really cost us? And what could that money be better spent on?</p>\\n<p>Whether you’re a sandwich kind of person, or you’re indulging in a burger and chips, your daily lunch spend could range anywhere between $5 &#8211; $25. For argument’s sake, let’s say you’re spending on average $10 a day on lunch. This amounts to around $2,400 a year (depending on annual leave, sick leave etc).</p>\\n<p>If you’re preparing your lunches at home, you’ll have a few advantages under your belt. A sandwich you’re buying out will probably cost you $6 more than one you prepare yourself using ingredients you already have at home. Not to mention the cost of making a large serving of pasta that will last for a few days’ worth of lunches versus your average $7 &#8211; $12 or more pasta at a café/restaurant.</p>\\n<p>If you’re spending on average around $4 per meal you prepare at home, you’re saving $6 a day. This amounts to a saving of around $1,400 every year, which is a significant amount to lose by not making your own lunches.</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170310132058/iStock-512896006-e1489116069752.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>What could you be spending this on?</strong></h3>\\n<p>There are a multitude of ways you could spend this money to save for your present, but you should really be thinking about your future.</p>\\n<p>If you put these savings of $1,400 a year away for your retirement, you will have an additional $42,000 after 30 years. This amount would be invaluable for anyone looking to spend their retirement, and a great incentive for those of us who struggle to bring themselves to spend Sunday evenings packing lunches.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Invest in your future</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare Super Funds</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation/search?nav=superannuation-search\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>If you open a savings account with a base amount of $1,400 and an interest rate of 0.25 per cent, while adding $1,400 every year saved on packed lunches, you will have a balance of around $15,500 after 10 years. After 30 years, the balance of your savings account would be around $44,800.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much money could you save?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare High Interest Savings Accounts</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/high-interest?nav=high-interest-savings-accounts\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>It may not be realistic to expect every lunch you have for the remainder of your working years be pre-made, but if you try to do this as much as you can, the savings will be worth it.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1489152486\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"It takes a very organised person to pack their lunch every day, and let’s admit it, most people don’t feel like they have the time or energy to prepare a week’s worth of food. But how much does buying lunch every day really cost us? And what could that money be better spent on? Whether &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/much-save-packing-lunch/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"How much do you save by packing your own lunch?\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62677\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170310131844/iStock-508164174-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62677,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/much-save-packing-lunch/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62677\",\"pubDate\":\"Fri, 10 Mar 2017 03:28:06 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"much-save-packing-lunch\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170310131844/iStock-508164174-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"How much do you save by packing your own lunch?\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1489152507\",\"url\":\"/savings-accounts/news/much-save-packing-lunch\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1488345732:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"savings-accounts\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>It’s easy to daydream about what it would be like to be a millionaire, but could taking that fantasy and turning it into a reality be as easy as waking up early?</p>\\n<p>RateCity has found that becoming a millionaire could be easier than you think, according these tips and tricks from highly successful people.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Meditate.</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141819/iStock-470643826-e1488341977897.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>By now everyone is aware of the act of meditating, whether it’s through religious practice or your weekly yoga class. According to these successful entrepreneurs, meditation is directly linked to their success as it allows the individual to deal with everyday pressures and stress.</p>\\n<p>Tupperware CEO Rick Goings meditates for twenty minutes every afternoon to help alleviate stress, and focus better on important tasks. Even Oprah Winfrey has advocated for meditation. The Harpo Productions Inc. CEO meditates twice a day to help herself find clarity and strength. <strong> </strong></p>\\n<h2><strong>Wake up early.</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141818/iStock-537266466-e1488341963275.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>Richard Branson once revealed he wakes up every morning with the sun (even when staying at his private island) as he likes to spend these early hours exercising and eating breakfast before work. Apple CEO Tim Cook also joins Branson in this philosophy, and is known for sending out company emails at 4:30am. Waking up early and making the most of your morning is one habit shared by <a href=\\\"http://www.businessinsider.com.au/successful-people-who-wake-up-really-early-2013-12?op=1&r=US&IR=T#ge-ceo-jeff-immelt-1\\\">29 successful people.</a></p>\\n<p>Early risers start their days before everyone and give themselves a jump start on the competition. They’re able to communicate with people in different time zones as well as find time for family, friends and exercise.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Save, not spend.</strong><strong> </strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301145131/iStock-512815862.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>It seems like an obvious one, but having the self-control to save your money instead of spending it is a common habit among wealthy people.</p>\\n<p>They say the early bird catches the worm and the same is true about your superannuation. Saving for your future is just one way that ordinary Australians can enjoy wealth in their retirement. Making regular additional payments into your super fund could mean a world of difference. For example, if you put an additional $20 a week into your superannuation for the next thirty years you will have $31,200 more to enjoy.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Is your super fund working hard for you?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare Super Funds</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation\\\">Look Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h2><strong>Read more, no matter how!</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141817/iStock-531305726-e1488341948274.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>In his successful 2010 book ‘Rich Habits’, Thomas C. Corley examined the behaviours of various successful people to compile a collection of their daily habits. According to the study of 223 wealthy and 128 poor people, 79 per cent read education career-related material. 55 per cent read for personal development and even 63% of wealthy people listened to audio books during their commute.</p>\\n<p>It’s clear that whether through opening a book or listening to its audio, successful people incorporate reading into their daily habits.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Get more sleep.</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141815/iStock-518179722-e1488341913902.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<blockquote><p>“We are in the midst of a sleep deprivation crisis” &#8211; Arianna Huffington, co-founder and former editor-in-chief of The Huffington Post.</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>In total contradiction to what Richard Branson may say, Arianna Huffington believes in the power of sleep to bring you success. After fainting from exhaustion, hitting her head on her desk, breaking her cheekbone and getting five stitches in her right eye, Arianna began a journey of rediscovering the value of sleep.</p>\\n<p>According to her book ‘The Sleep Revolution’, the cultural dismissal of sleep as “time wasted” compromises our health and our decision-making and undermines our lives. She clarifies what doctors have told us for years; that having seven to eight hours of sleep a night is key to having healthier and more productive lives.</p>\",\"category\":\"money\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>It’s easy to daydream about what it would be like to be a millionaire, but could taking that fantasy and turning it into a reality be as easy as waking up early?</p>\\n<p>RateCity has found that becoming a millionaire could be easier than you think, according these tips and tricks from highly successful people.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Meditate.</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141819/iStock-470643826-e1488341977897.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>By now everyone is aware of the act of meditating, whether it’s through religious practice or your weekly yoga class. According to these successful entrepreneurs, meditation is directly linked to their success as it allows the individual to deal with everyday pressures and stress.</p>\\n<p>Tupperware CEO Rick Goings meditates for twenty minutes every afternoon to help alleviate stress, and focus better on important tasks. Even Oprah Winfrey has advocated for meditation. The Harpo Productions Inc. CEO meditates twice a day to help herself find clarity and strength. <strong> </strong></p>\\n<h2><strong>Wake up early.</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141818/iStock-537266466-e1488341963275.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>Richard Branson once revealed he wakes up every morning with the sun (even when staying at his private island) as he likes to spend these early hours exercising and eating breakfast before work.
