They’re able to communicate with people in different time zones as well as find time for family, friends and exercise.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Save, not spend.</strong><strong> </strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301145131/iStock-512815862.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>It seems like an obvious one, but having the self-control to save your money instead of spending it is a common habit among wealthy people.</p>\\n<p>They say the early bird catches the worm and the same is true about your superannuation. Saving for your future is just one way that ordinary Australians can enjoy wealth in their retirement. Making regular additional payments into your super fund could mean a world of difference. For example, if you put an additional $20 a week into your superannuation for the next thirty years you will have $31,200 more to enjoy.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Is your super fund working hard for you?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare Super Funds</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation\\\">Look Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h2><strong>Read more, no matter how!</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141817/iStock-531305726-e1488341948274.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>In his successful 2010 book ‘Rich Habits’, Thomas C. Corley examined the behaviours of various successful people to compile a collection of their daily habits. According to the study of 223 wealthy and 128 poor people, 79 per cent read education career-related material. 55 per cent read for personal development and even 63% of wealthy people listened to audio books during their commute.</p>\\n<p>It’s clear that whether through opening a book or listening to its audio, successful people incorporate reading into their daily habits.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Get more sleep.</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301141815/iStock-518179722-e1488341913902.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<blockquote><p>“We are in the midst of a sleep deprivation crisis” &#8211; Arianna Huffington, co-founder and former editor-in-chief of The Huffington Post.</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>In total contradiction to what Richard Branson may say, Arianna Huffington believes in the power of sleep to bring you success. After fainting from exhaustion, hitting her head on her desk, breaking her cheekbone and getting five stitches in her right eye, Arianna began a journey of rediscovering the value of sleep.</p>\\n<p>According to her book ‘The Sleep Revolution’, the cultural dismissal of sleep as “time wasted” compromises our health and our decision-making and undermines our lives. She clarifies what doctors have told us for years; that having seven to eight hours of sleep a night is key to having healthier and more productive lives.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1488379743\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"It’s easy to daydream about what it would be like to be a millionaire, but could taking that fantasy and turning it into a reality be as easy as waking up early? RateCity has found that becoming a millionaire could be easier than you think, according these tips and tricks from highly successful people. Meditate. &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/5-habits-wealthy-people/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"5 Habits of wealthy people\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62503\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301142646/iStock-512631886-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62503,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/5-habits-wealthy-people/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62503\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 01 Mar 2017 04:49:03 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"5-habits-wealthy-people\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170301142646/iStock-512631886-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"5 Habits of wealthy people\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1488380136\",\"url\":\"/savings-accounts/news/5-habits-wealthy-people\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1488343570:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"savings-accounts\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>When we find ourselves with a little extra in our pocket, the urge to splurge can be overpowering for a lot of us, especially given how easy it is to shop online.</p>\\n<p>RateCity has compiled a few ways you can spend your bonus wisely and make your money work for you.</p>\\n<h3>Save your bonus</h3>\\n<p>While it can be tempting to immediately spend a bonus, putting your money into a high-interest savings account will help to keep your savings growing. Plus, it will help you reach your financial goals faster as the interest accumulates over time.</p>\\n<p>In the event of an unexpected occurrence, having a savings or emergency fund will give you the peace of mind that you are covered and you can access this money ASAP. <a href=\\\"http://www.businessinsider.com.au/how-much-emergency-savings-do-you-need-2014-8\\\">Experts advise</a> that the safest amount to have saved is three to six months’ salary.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">INTERESTED IN SAVING YOUR BONUS?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">HIGH INTEREST SAVINGS ACCOUNTS</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/high-interest?nav=high-interest-savings-accounts\\\">COMPARE</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Invest your bonus</h3>\\n<p>Another way you could spend your bonus is by purchasing shares. Whether you’re new to the stock market, or you’ve been investing for years, buying and selling shares is an exciting way to invest your bonus. To buy and sell shares, you’ll need a broker. If you don’t have a lot to invest, consider using a discount broker, as full service brokers can charge three or four times the brokerage fees.</p>\\n<p>If you want to invest your bonus, but the idea of spending all of it on shares and brokers is a little intimidating, you could consider one of the many apps available that invest your money for you.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Acorns</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://acornsau.com.au/\\\">Acorns</a> is a popular investing app in Australia that utilises your spare change by investing it for you. Whatever small amount you spend, Acorns will round up that purchase to the nearest dollar and invest the difference. For example, if you spent $12.50 on lunch, Acorns will take 50c and store it in your portfolio for investment.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">BRICKX</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>If stocks aren’t your game, apps such as <a href=\\\"https://www.brickx.com/\\\">BRICKX</a> offer users a simple and low cost way to get into the property market. You are given a range of properties to choose from, and for under $100 you purchase a ‘Brick’ – a portion of the property. At the end of each month, users receive a share of the net rental income and you are free to sell your ‘Bricks’ at any time. You can grow and diversify your property portfolio for a fraction of the price of buying a house.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://acornsau.com.au/\\\"></a>It’s also wise to invest in your future and make extra contributions to your super fund. ASIC advises that you can really boost your super savings by making after-tax contributions, as these payments do not get taxed. There is a limit to how much you can contribute to your super before you have to pay tax, and this information can be found on the <a href=\\\"https://www.ato.gov.au/Individuals/Super/In-detail/Withdrawing-and-paying-tax/Super-contributions---too-much-can-mean-extra-tax/\\\">Australian Taxation Office’s website</a>. Most people can contribute up to $30,000, including your employer’s 9.5 per cent super guarantee contribution. For those 50 and over, you can usually contribute up to $35,000.</p>\\n<h3>Pay off debt</h3>\\n<p>You could also consider using your bonus to pay off any outstanding debt, such as a home loan. Making additional payments on your mortgage will help you to pay off the debt faster, as the extra payments are going towards the principal of the loan rather than the interest. However, if your home loan has a fixed interest rate, you may incur fees or have a limit on the amount you make in extra repayments, so it’s important you do your research.</p>\\n<p>You can use RateCity’s <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">online calculator</a> to work out how much interest you can save by making extra repayments.</p>\",\"category\":[\"interest\",\"investing\",\"investment property\",\"savings accounts\",\"superannuation\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>When we find ourselves with a little extra in our pocket, the urge to splurge can be overpowering for a lot of us, especially given how easy it is to shop online.</p>\\n<p>RateCity has compiled a few ways you can spend your bonus wisely and make your money work for you.</p>\\n<h3>Save your bonus</h3>\\n<p>While it can be tempting to immediately spend a bonus, putting your money into a high-interest savings account will help to keep your savings growing. Plus, it will help you reach your financial goals faster as the interest accumulates over time.</p>\\n<p>In the event of an unexpected occurrence, having a savings or emergency fund will give you the peace of mind that you are covered and you can access this money ASAP. <a href=\\\"http://www.businessinsider.com.au/how-much-emergency-savings-do-you-need-2014-8\\\">Experts advise</a> that the safest amount to have saved is three to six months’ salary.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">INTERESTED IN SAVING YOUR BONUS?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">HIGH INTEREST SAVINGS ACCOUNTS</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/high-interest?nav=high-interest-savings-accounts\\\">COMPARE</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Invest your bonus</h3>\\n<p>Another way you could spend your bonus is by purchasing shares. Whether you’re new to the stock market, or you’ve been investing for years, buying and selling shares is an exciting way to invest your bonus. To buy and sell shares, you’ll need a broker. If you don’t have a lot to invest, consider using a discount broker, as full service brokers can charge three or four times the brokerage fees.</p>\\n<p>If you want to invest your bonus, but the idea of spending all of it on shares and brokers is a little intimidating, you could consider one of the many apps available that invest your money for you.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Acorns</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://acornsau.com.au/\\\">Acorns</a> is a popular investing app in Australia that utilises your spare change by investing it for you. Whatever small amount you spend, Acorns will round up that purchase to the nearest dollar and invest the difference. For example, if you spent $12.50 on lunch, Acorns will take 50c and store it in your portfolio for investment.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">BRICKX</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>If stocks aren’t your game, apps such as <a href=\\\"https://www.brickx.com/\\\">BRICKX</a> offer users a simple and low cost way to get into the property market. You are given a range of properties to choose from, and for under $100 you purchase a ‘Brick’ – a portion of the property. At the end of each month, users receive a share of the net rental income and you are free to sell your ‘Bricks’ at any time. You can grow and diversify your property portfolio for a fraction of the price of buying a house.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://acornsau.com.au/\\\"></a>It’s also wise to invest in your future and make extra contributions to your super fund. ASIC advises that you can really boost your super savings by making after-tax contributions, as these payments do not get taxed. There is a limit to how much you can contribute to your super before you have to pay tax, and this information can be found on the <a href=\\\"https://www.ato.gov.au/Individuals/Super/In-detail/Withdrawing-and-paying-tax/Super-contributions---too-much-can-mean-extra-tax/\\\">Australian Taxation Office’s website</a>. Most people can contribute up to $30,000, including your employer’s 9.5 per cent super guarantee contribution. For those 50 and over, you can usually contribute up to $35,000.</p>\\n<h3>Pay off debt</h3>\\n<p>You could also consider using your bonus to pay off any outstanding debt, such as a home loan. Making additional payments on your mortgage will help you to pay off the debt faster, as the extra payments are going towards the principal of the loan rather than the interest. However, if your home loan has a fixed interest rate, you may incur fees or have a limit on the amount you make in extra repayments, so it’s important you do your research.</p>\\n<p>You can use RateCity’s <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">online calculator</a> to work out how much interest you can save by making extra repayments.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1488198975\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"When we find ourselves with a little extra in our pocket, the urge to splurge can be overpowering for a lot of us, especially given how easy it is to shop online. RateCity has compiled a few ways you can spend your bonus wisely and make your money work for you. bonus?\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62463\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170227123326/iStock-516077862-715x420.jpg\",\"id\":62463,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/whats-best-way-spend-bonus/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62463\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon, Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>We all know that budgeting and saving money can be a challenge, with unexpected situations always around the corner.</p>\\n<p>Whether you want to save for a car, put money away for retirement or if you’re looking to invest, RateCity has found some motivational quotes from experts for every situation.</p>\\n<h2>Save, save, save!</h2>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">&#8220;Beware of little expenses. A small leak will sink a great ship.&#8221; &#8211; Benjamin Franklin</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>It is crucial you monitor your spending and budget correctly to stay on track with your savings, as even the smallest of expenses can add up over time.</p>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">&#8220;Save one-third, live on one-third and give away one-third.&#8221; – Angelina Jolie</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>A savings account offers a higher interest rate and a range of features to help you reach your savings goal, whether you’re saving for a new car, holiday or home loan. It is important to balance your finances and to give back to the community when possible.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Could you be saving more?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">High Interest Savings Accounts</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/high-interest?nav=high-interest-savings-accounts\\\">Find out now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n<h2>Plan for the future</h2>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">“Rule No.1: Never lose money. Rule No.2: Never forget rule No.1.” &#8211; Warren Buffett</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>There are easy ways you can lose money from your super fund, such as fees, or employers not paying correctly. Make sure you’re keeping a record of all payments and tracking how your superannuation is performing.</p>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">&#8220;You can be young without money but you can’t be old without it.&#8221; – Tennessee Williams</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>It’s crucial that you make sure your super fund is working hard to ensure you have enough to get you through your retirement years.</p>\\n<h2><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170221143014/iStock-623537656.jpg\\\" /></h2>\\n<h2><strong>Time to invest</strong></h2>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">&#8220;How many millionaires do you know who have become wealthy by investing in savings accounts? I rest my case.&#8221; &#8211; Robert G. Allen</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>Having a well-managed savings account is one way to ensure you can reach your short or long term financial goals. However, diversifying your income stream through investments such as property, margin loans or trading can help you to generate additional cash flow.</p>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">&#8220;Financial peace isn&#8217;t the acquisition of stuff. It&#8217;s learning to live on less than you make, so you can give money back and have money to invest. You can&#8217;t win until you do this.&#8221; &#8211; Dave Ramsey</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>Whether you’re investing in property or shares, creating additional sources of passive income (and spending less than you make) will help give you ‘financial peace’.  </p>\\n<h3><strong>But most importantly;</strong></h3>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">&#8220;Too often, a vast collection of possessions ends up possessing its owner. The asset I most value, aside from health, is interesting, diverse, and long-standing friends.&#8221; – Warren Buffett</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\",\"category\":[\"investing\",\"investments\",\"money\",\"saving\",\"savings accounts\",\"superannuation\",\"wealth\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>We all know that budgeting and saving money can be a challenge, with unexpected situations always around the corner.</p>\\n<p>Whether you want to save for a car, put money away for retirement or if you’re looking to invest, RateCity has found some motivational quotes from experts for every situation.</p>\\n<h2>Save, save, save!</h2>\\n<blockquote><p style=\\\"text-align: center;\\\">&#8220;Beware of little expenses. quotes from money experts\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1487760156\",\"url\":\"/savings-accounts/news/money-quotes-money-experts\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"16\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1484804860:16\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"savings-accounts\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/655d7e0698b4208ced875c98ddae1987?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>If you’re expecting in 2017 there are probably a million things on your mind and your baby’s financial future most likely isn’t number one.</p>\\n<p>Even so, it’s good to make some time to think about what sort of savings plan you want to put in place for your baby to help them along when they reach adulthood.</p>\\n<p>As an investment in Australia’s future <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a>, Australia’s oldest bank, is celebrating 200 years in business by offering a $200 savings bonus for each child born in 2017.</p>\\n<p>For children whose parent’s apply for the scheme, the bonus will be paid in to a <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Westpac</a> Savings Account and will remain there accruing interest until the child turns 16.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Interested?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Westpac Bump</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://bump.westpacgroup.com.au/\\\">Express Interest Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>If you add to the balance over time your child will be able to experience the full power of compounding interest come their 16<sup>th</sup> birthday.</p>\\n<p>To see what this could look like you can use a compounding interest calculator to predict how your child’s savings could grow and how your own additions could compliment them.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compound interest calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg active\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/tools-and-resources/calculators-and-apps/compound-interest-calculator\\\">Calculate Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>It’s also worth remembering that even though we are currently in a low interest rate environment, it won’t last forever. Depending on how the official <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> moves over the 16-year period before the cash is accessible, and how much extra you contribute, your child could end up earning thousands in interest.</p>\\n<p>Here are some first steps to figuring out how you want to approach your baby’s financial future.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/yPt8r5_l4_A\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<h3>Set up a savings account</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119150853/iStock-171326758-e1484802539131.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61690\\\" alt=\\\"Expectant mother sitting on couch with her son using laptop computer at home\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119150853/iStock-171326758-e1484802539131.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>It could be the Westpac Bump account or any other savings account of your choice, but having somewhere to stash the money you’re putting away for your baby should be the first step. Having it in a designated savings account also means that it will be earning interest along the way.</p>\\n<p>Many banks offer special kid’s bank accounts often with some of the highest interest rates on the market, subject to certain conditions. It is worth doing some research into who has the best rates on the market and what you have to do to earn them. This could be depositing a certain amount per month or making limited withdrawals or a combination of both.</p>\\n<h3>Decide what contributions you will make</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151105/iStock-104306512-e1484802673446.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61691\\\" alt=\\\"Germany, Munich, Mother with daughters (4-7) counting stack of coins\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151105/iStock-104306512-e1484802673446.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Once you have the account set up and ready to go, it’s time to decide what sort of contributions you want to make over the years. Would you prefer to make a regular monthly commitment or deposit lump sums when you come into extra cash? Or, would you rather not make any contributions of your own and instead only deposit gifts given to your child into the account.</p>\\n<p>This is entirely a personal choice and there are many different ways to approach the matter. Some parents might prefer to institute a pocket money scheme when their child is old enough and deposit some of that cash into the account as a way of instilling an important financial lesson – that money doesn’t come for free. </p>\\n<h3>Decide what you will do with baby’s gift money</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151743/iStock-620370582-e1484803069337.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61692\\\" alt=\\\"Top view of hands of mother giving one large gift box with blue ribbon to her kid with open hand\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151743/iStock-620370582-e1484803069337.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Over the coming years your family and friends are going to want to shower your child with cash for the special occasions like birthdays and Christmas. Until your child is old enough to realise what’s going on, the best place for that cash is probably earning interest in their designated savings account.</p>\\n<p>Once they are old enough to realise what money is (and the potential it has to buy new toys) you might have to rethink this approach. Depending on how you decide to play it, you could work out a percentage of each gift amount that goes towards saving with the remaining part being used to purchase a treat. This is another great way to instil a financial lesson – that you shouldn’t spend everything at once.</p>\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>If you’re expecting in 2017 there are probably a million things on your mind and your baby’s financial future most likely isn’t number one.</p>\\n<p>Even so, it’s good to make some time to think about what sort of savings plan you want to put in place for your baby Having it in a designated savings account also means that it will be earning interest along the way.</p>\\n<p>Many banks offer special kid’s bank accounts often with some of the highest interest rates on the market, subject to certain conditions. It is worth doing some research into who has the best rates on the market and what you have to do to earn them. This could be depositing a certain amount per month or making limited withdrawals or a combination of both.</p>\\n<h3>Decide what contributions you will make</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151105/iStock-104306512-e1484802673446.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61691\\\" alt=\\\"Germany, Munich, Mother with daughters (4-7) counting stack of coins\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151105/iStock-104306512-e1484802673446.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Once you have the account set up and ready to go, it’s time to decide what sort of contributions you want to make over the years. Would you prefer to make a regular monthly commitment or deposit lump sums when you come into extra cash? Or, would you rather not make any contributions of your own and instead only deposit gifts given to your child into the account.</p>\\n<p>This is entirely a personal choice and there are many different ways to approach the matter. Some parents might prefer to institute a pocket money scheme when their child is old enough and deposit some of that cash into the account as a way of instilling an important financial lesson – that money doesn’t come for free. </p>\\n<h3>Decide what you will do with baby’s gift money</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151743/iStock-620370582-e1484803069337.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61692\\\" alt=\\\"Top view of hands of mother giving one large gift box with blue ribbon to her kid with open hand\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119151743/iStock-620370582-e1484803069337.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Over the coming years your family and friends are going to want to shower your child with cash for the special occasions like birthdays and Christmas. Until your child is old enough to realise what’s going on, the best place for that cash is probably earning interest in their designated savings account.</p>\\n<p>Once they are old enough to realise what money is (and the potential it has to buy new toys) you might have to rethink this approach. Depending on how you decide to play it, you could work out a percentage of each gift amount that goes towards saving with the remaining part being used to purchase a treat. This is another great way to instil a financial lesson – that you shouldn’t spend everything at once.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1484838151\",\"dc:creator\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"description\":\"If you’re expecting in 2017 there are probably a million things on your mind and your baby’s financial future most likely isn’t number one. Even so, it’s good to make some time to think about what sort of savings plan you want to put in place for your baby to help them along when they &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/babys-first-savings-account/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Baby’s first savings account\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=61686\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119145302/iStock-487095850-685x420.jpg\",\"id\":61686,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/babys-first-savings-account/\",\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"61686\",\"pubDate\":\"Thu, 19 Jan 2017 05:02:31 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":4,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"If you’re expecting in 2017 there are probably a million things on your mind and your baby’s financial future most likely isn’t number one.\",\"slug\":\"babys-first-savings-account\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119145302/iStock-487095850-350x500.jpg\",\"title\":\"Baby’s first savings account\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1484839139\",\"url\":\"/savings-accounts/news/babys-first-savings-account\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"16\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1483592923:16\",\"_wp_old_slug\":\"christmas-presents-that-won-t-break-the-bank\",\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"Are you worried about how your credit card will fare over Christmas? Think about giving some of these low-cost but incredibly thoughtful gifts.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Five Christmas presents that won't break the bank\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"savings-accounts\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/655d7e0698b4208ced875c98ddae1987?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Christmas is just around the corner and retailers are getting into the swing of the silly season, with baubles, tinsel and holly adorning shops across the country. </p>\\n<p>With spending on the rise, many Aussies will be<span> </span>falling back on their credit cards which may seem like a great idea now but will appear less so when the bill rolls around in a month’s time. If you are cash strapped and worried about having to rely on your card, it may be worth exploring the glorious world of the DIY gift.</p>\\n<p>So how can you wow friends and family with fabulous Christmas presents without getting yourself into debt? Here are some ideas that won&#8217;t break the bank!</p>\\n<h3>Brownie jars</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220132214/iStock-615268216-e1482204178738.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-60948\\\" alt=\\\"Homemade Christmas Cake Mix in a Jar decorated with pine cones and spruce branches on a dark wooden background\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220132214/iStock-615268216-e1482204178738.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Christmas is a time for sweet treats, so why not gift relatives a DIY brownie kit?</p>\\n<p>You&#8217;ll need sterilised mason jars, some coloured twine, cute fabric, thick cream card and a calligraphy-style black pen. Don&#8217;t forget your favourite brownie recipe, either.</p>\\n<p>Measure out the required dry ingredients and layer them in the jar — think flour, soft brown sugar, chocolate chips and cocoa. You&#8217;ll need to make sure the jar is filled to the brim to keep the layers in place. Then you can place a square of colourful fabric over top and secure it with twine. Finally, write instructions for brownie preparation on squares of card. Usually this is as simple as mixing the dry ingredients with egg and oil. Tie the card on with twine and you&#8217;ve got yourself an adorable gift!</p>\\n<h3>Sweet candles</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220131647/iStock-623123696-1-e1482203817448.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-60947\\\" alt=\\\"Rustic Christmas scene with jar candle, pine cones, metals stars and round tag with copy space.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220131647/iStock-623123696-1-e1482203817448.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Candles make a great Christmas present, but you don&#8217;t have to fork out for the trendiest offerings. Instead, pick some candles in simple glass jars and package them in hand-decorated brown card boxes, before tying with a silk ribbon in black, red or navy blue. The personalised touch will make the present extra special.</p>\\n<p>Alternatively, if you have a lot of people who you need gifts for this year, you could try your hand at making your own candles from scratch. If you’re making a large batch (and have the time to spare) this could end up being an efficient way of making something special for the whole family.</p>\\n<h3>Homemade hampers</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220131518/iStock-495977924-e1482203763753.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-60946\\\" alt=\\\"Christmas hamper basket with a chocolate Santa, cookies and a bottle of wine close-up\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220131518/iStock-495977924-e1482203763753.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>It&#8217;s tempting to buy pre-made hampers at department stores or supermarkets but there can be hefty mark-ups,<span> </span>stinging your savings account. Not to mention, they often come with a few good products and a whole bunch of products that no one ever uses.</p>\\n<p>Instead, why not put together your own hampers? These are great presents for relatives — if you can&#8217;t afford to splash out on numerous nieces and nephews, why not give a hamper that your relatives and their kids will all enjoy together?</p>\\n<p>Items like herbal tea, high-quality olive oil and chocolates are good additions. You can also include some homemade baking for an extra personal touch. Transparent cellophane and brightly coloured ribbons will give the hamper a professional look.</p>\\n<h3></h3>\\n<h3>Gingerbread house and men</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220132453/iStock-497008476-e1482204301369.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-60950\\\" alt=\\\"Gingerbread house with gingerbread couple in front\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220132453/iStock-497008476-e1482204301369.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>The perfect gift for kids in your family is a gingerbread house which you can leave undecorated for the gift recipients to have some fun. If you’re good in the kitchen, putting together a gingerbread house and accompanying men is a cost effective gift for all your nephews and nieces.</p>\\n<p>On Christmas day, every one can have a turn icing and decorating your gift. What’s better than a DIY gift that brings the whole family together?</p>\\n<h3>Potted plants</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220132842/iStock-503582294-e1482204530458.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-60952\\\" alt=\\\"Horizontal composition color photography of a beautiful floral composition, plant bouquet with multiple plant type used to celebrate holidays (Christmas, New Year, or just a gift...). There are a Poinsettia with some golden glitter on vibrant red leaves, Peace Lily (Spathiphyllum), Echeveria succulent plant colored in red, some green moss etc... Close-up on the red plant leaf of Poinsettia (Euphorbia pulcherrima) with small golden glitter / flakes to offer on Christmas Holidays. Picture shot with soft focus.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20161220132842/iStock-503582294-e1482204530458.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Finally, if you&#8217;ve got a friend or family member with a green thumb, why not give them a potted plant?</p>\\n<p>Dip the lower half of a terracotta pot into mint green, candy pink or lemon yellow paint, then flip it upside down and allow it to dry on newspaper. You&#8217;ll get a fun ombre effect — pop in a cost-effective perennial and you&#8217;ve got a perfect gift for grandparents, siblings-in-law or even mum and dad.</p>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-christmas-presents-that-won-t-break-the-bank/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Christmas is just around the corner and retailers are getting into the swing of the silly season, with baubles, tinsel and holly adorning shops across the country. </p>\\n<p>With spending on the rise, many Aussies will be<span> </span>falling back on their credit cards which may seem like a great idea now but will appear less so when the bill rolls around in a month’s time. You&#8217;ll get a fun ombre effect — pop in a cost-effective perennial and you&#8217;ve got a perfect gift for grandparents, siblings-in-law or even mum and dad.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1482225074\",\"dc:creator\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"description\":\"Are you worried about how your credit card will fare over Christmas? Think about giving some of these low-cost but incredibly thoughtful gifts.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-christmas-presents-that-won-t-break-the-bank/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3473/Five_Christmas_present_ideas_that_won_t_break_the_bank.jpg\",\"id\":58803,\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-christmas-presents-that-won-t-break-the-bank/\",\"meta_description\":\"Are you worried about how your credit card will fare over Christmas? Think about giving some of these low-cost but incredibly thoughtful gifts.\",\"meta_title\":\"Five Christmas presents that won't break the bank\",\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"58803\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon, 19 Dec 2016 23:11:14 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":4,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"Are you worried about how your credit card will fare over Christmas? Think about giving some of these low-cost but incredibly thoughtful gifts.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"five-christmas-presents-that-won-t-break-the-bank\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3473/Five_Christmas_present_ideas_that_won_t_break_the_bank.jpg\",\"title\":\"Five Christmas presents that won’t break the bank\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1482241221\",\"url\":\"/savings-accounts/news/five-christmas-presents-that-won-t-break-the-bank\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-christmas-presents-that-won-t-break-the-bank/feed/\"}],\"carLoans\":[{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1490334508:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"car-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>When it comes to choosing a car loan, it pays to be as picky as you would be when choosing the actual car.</p>\\n<p>There are several features you should examine when comparing car loans and picking between a secure or unsecure loan is one of the most significant.<strong> </strong></p>\\n<h3><strong>Secured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p>A secured car loan refers to a type of car loan in which lenders generally use the purchase as an asset for security against the loan. Some lenders are also willing to use property, term deposits or other assets such as jewellery as security against the loan. A secured car loan usually also has a lower interest rate than an unsecured loan due to borrowers offering security posing less of a risk to lenders.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Unsecured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/unsecured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Unsecured car loans</a> do not require security to be held against the loan. However, you will need to prove that you can make the repayments through a good credit history, your ability to save, or if you previously had a personal loan or credit card and met the repayments. As this type of car loan is riskier due to the lack of security, you will usually incur higher interest rates and/or not be approved to borrow as much as you would on a secured loan.</p>\\n<h3><strong>What loan type is right for you?</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/secured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Secured loans</a> are a competitive choice for borrowers looking to take advantage of lower interest rates and higher borrowing amounts, as it allows you to appear as less of a risk to lenders. However, if you’re a reliable borrower with a history of paying off debt, an unsecured loan may work for you, as you will not run the risk of losing the purchase in the event you can’t pay back the loan.</p>\\n<p>Some lenders also only allow new vehicles (two years or younger) to be used as security, with older cars needing to pass vehicle inspection checks.</p>\\n<p>Regardless of your loan type, if you cannot pay back your car loan and your car has devalued past the point of the outstanding balance, the lender can take you to court for the remainder.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros of secured loans</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">You’re seen as lower risk to lenders</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Lower interest rates</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Parents can sign as guarantor</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Can borrow a higher amount</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons of secured loans</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">If you default, the lender will claim the security</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Some lenders only accept new vehicles (less than two years old) as a guarantee</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">If your car devalues, the lender can still take you to court to pay the balance – car is not a 100% safe back up</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153625/iStock-540836094-e1490333802639.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>What else should you consider?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Apart from secured vs. unsecured, you’ll need to examine and compare a few more factors before deciding which car loan is suitable for you.</p>\\n<p>If budgeting is your main concern, you’ll want to consider the type of interest rate for the car loan. You may be leaning towards a secured car loan with a lower interest rate, however, if the rate is variable it may be harder to budget for, as your repayments may change every month. Both secured and unsecured car loans can have either a fixed or variable rate, depending on the lender’s product.</p>\\n<p>You’ll also want to examine the loan fees involved and whether any upfront or early exit penalty fees apply to fully calculate the total amount you will pay over the lifetime of your loan. Checking the comparison rate of a car loan is a great way to estimate its overall cost. </p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/car-loans/rate-table?cl_per_page=4&cl_securedType%5B0%5D=Secured&ab_test_id=0.12\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"category\":[\"car loan\",\"car loans\",\"car loans australia\",\"fixed rate car loans\",\"secured car loan\",\"unsecured car loans\",\"variable car rate loans\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>When it comes to choosing a car loan, it pays to be as picky as you would be when choosing the actual car.</p>\\n<p>There are several features you should examine when comparing car loans and picking between a secure or unsecure loan is one of the most significant.<strong> </strong></p>\\n<h3><strong>Secured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p>A secured car loan refers to a type of car loan in which lenders generally use the purchase as an asset for security against the loan. Some lenders are also willing to use property, term deposits or other assets such as jewellery as security against the loan. A secured car loan usually also has a lower interest rate than an unsecured loan due to borrowers offering security posing less of a risk to lenders.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Unsecured Car Loan</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/unsecured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Unsecured car loans</a> do not require security to be held against the loan. However, you will need to prove that you can make the repayments through a good credit history, your ability to save, or if you previously had a personal loan or credit card and met the repayments. As this type of car loan is riskier due to the lack of security, you will usually incur higher interest rates and/or not be approved to borrow as much as you would on a secured loan.</p>\\n<h3><strong>What loan type is right for you?</strong></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/secured\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Secured loans</a> are a competitive choice for borrowers looking to take advantage of lower interest rates and higher borrowing amounts, as it allows you to appear as less of a risk to lenders. However, if you’re a reliable borrower with a history of paying off debt, an unsecured loan may work for you, as you will not run the risk of losing the purchase in the event you can’t pay back the loan.</p>\\n<p>Some lenders also only allow new vehicles (two years or younger) to be used as security, with older cars needing to pass vehicle inspection checks.</p>\\n<p>Regardless of your loan type, if you cannot pay back your car loan and your car has devalued past the point of the outstanding balance, the lender can take you to court for the remainder.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros of secured loans</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">You’re seen as lower risk to lenders</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Lower interest rates</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Parents can sign as guarantor</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Can borrow a higher amount</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons of secured loans</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">If you default, the lender will claim the security</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Some lenders only accept new vehicles (less than two years old) as a guarantee</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">If your car devalues, the lender can still take you to court to pay the balance – car is not a 100% safe back up</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153625/iStock-540836094-e1490333802639.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>What else should you consider?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Apart from secured vs. unsecured, you’ll need to examine and compare a few more factors before deciding which car loan is suitable for you.</p>\\n<p>If budgeting is your main concern, you’ll want to consider the type of interest rate for the car loan. You may be leaning towards a secured car loan with a lower interest rate, however, if the rate is variable it may be harder to budget for, as your repayments may change every month. Both secured and unsecured car loans can have either a fixed or variable rate, depending on the lender’s product.</p>\\n<p>You’ll also want to examine the loan fees involved and whether any upfront or early exit penalty fees apply to fully calculate the total amount you will pay over the lifetime of your loan. Checking the comparison rate of a car loan is a great way to estimate its overall cost. </p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/car-loans/rate-table?cl_per_page=4&cl_securedType%5B0%5D=Secured&ab_test_id=0.12\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1490370035\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"When it comes to choosing a car loan, it pays to be as picky as you would be when choosing the actual car. There are several features you should examine when comparing car loans and picking between a secure or unsecure loan is one of the most significant.  Secured Car Loan A secured car loan &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secure-car-loan/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Should I secure my car loan?\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62890\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153305/iStock-506879326-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62890,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secure-car-loan/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62890\",\"pubDate\":\"Fri, 24 Mar 2017 05:40:35 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"secure-car-loan\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170324153305/iStock-506879326-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"Should I secure my car loan?\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1490370035\",\"url\":\"/car-loans/news/secure-car-loan\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[\\\"on\\\",null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"39\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1489617101:44\",\"_yoast_wpseo_focuskw\":\"Car Loan, Car Loan Market, Deposit, Compare Car Loans, Car Loans Online, Interest-Free Loan, Interest Rates, Guarantor, Repayments, Guarantee, Financial Advice, Lender, Debts, Financial Advice, Lender, Debts, RateCity,\",\"_yoast_wpseo_linkdex\":\"58\",\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"The car loan market is hotting up thanks to a spate of new affordable models entering the Australian market, but most young buyers still need a hand from mum and dad to get them over the line. Some parents help with the deposit and many are guarantors for their children's loans.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Going guarantor the good, the bad and the ugly\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"car-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d42bd80f1c68d3c2cd9d46501aaedba6?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Laine Gordon\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>The car loan market is hotting up thanks to a spate of new affordable models entering the Australian market, but most young buyers still need a hand from mum and dad to get them over the line.</p>\\n<p>Acting as a guarantor on a <a href=\\\"/car-loans\\\">car loan</a> may seem like a harmless gesture of goodwill. But should the main borrower fall behind on repayments, you may be left to foot a hefty bill. That&#8217;s because when you co-sign a loan you&#8217;re legally agreeing to be responsible for the payment of another person&#8217;s debts.</p>\\n<p>So before you sign on the dotted line it&#8217;s vital to understand your rights and responsibilities as guarantor. Ensure your guarantee is limited to a set amount and a specific time period and seek independent legal and financial advice before proceeding.</p>\\n<p><strong>Checklist for a future guarantor</strong></p>\\n<p>Think carefully before you agree to act as a guarantor and ask yourself whether you really could afford to meet repayments should you need to. It&#8217;s not uncommon for the co-signer to lose money, or even their home, over a guarantee that has not worked out to plan.</p>\\n<p>Before signing the dotted line you should find out:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>How much will you be required to repay?</li>\\n<li>How will this repayment impact your ability to service your existing financial commitments?</li>\\n<li>Is the borrower likely to default?</li>\\n<li>How secure is the borrower&#8217;s current income?</li>\\n<li>Will your relationship be affected if the situation sours?</li>\\n</ul>\\n<blockquote><p><strong>Related stories</strong></p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback\\\">Out with the old, in with the new: why new cars are making a comeback</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/driving-away-with-a-good-deal\\\">Driving away with a good deal</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>If you&#8217;re not satisfied with the answers to these questions, all is not lost. There are alternatives to going guarantor and still helping your child into their first car. One popular option is to give the borrower an interest-free loan of a few thousand dollars, which they could use as a deposit.</p>\\n<p>Others prefer to help their children start a savings plan by matching their savings dollar for dollar.</p>\\n<p><strong>The upside to borrowing with backing</strong></p>\\n<p>While there are dangers involved with co-signing for a relative or friend, the upside for the borrower is that they have added obligation to meet repayments and clear debt. Having this added security may also attract lower interest rates, because the borrower is less risky in the mind of the lender.</p>\\n<p>It pays to <a href=\\\"/car-loans/compare\\\">compare car loans</a> online at sites such as RateCity to ensure you&#8217;re getting the lowest rate of interest. Online comparison sites also list all of the features, fees and terms and conditions attached to the loan so it&#8217;s easier to be across all the costs associated with these loans.</p>\\n<p><strong>Related car loan links</strong></p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"/car-loans/low-interest\\\">Low Interest Car Loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"/car-loans/best\\\">Best Car Loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/ten-of-the-best-car-loan-tips\\\">Ten of the best car loan tips</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/buying-a-car-why-a-porsche-might-not-be-the-best-idea\\\">Buying a car? Why a porsche might not be a good idea</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n<div class=\\\"daily-deals deal-row is-flex row\\\" data-reactid=\\\"848\\\"><!-- Sunshine Loan Centre -->\\n<div class=\\\"daily-deal-column </span></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>The car loan market is hotting up thanks to a spate of new affordable models entering the Australian market, but most young buyers still need a hand from mum and dad to get them over the line.</p>\\n<p>Acting as a guarantor on a <a href=\\\"/car-loans\\\">car loan</a> may seem like a harmless gesture of goodwill. But should the main borrower fall behind on repayments, you may be left to foot a hefty bill. That&#8217;s because when you co-sign a loan you&#8217;re legally agreeing to be responsible for the payment of another person&#8217;s debts.</p>\\n<p>So before you sign on the dotted line it&#8217;s vital to understand your rights and responsibilities as guarantor. Ensure your guarantee is limited to a set amount and a specific time period and seek independent legal and financial advice before proceeding.</p>\\n<p><strong>Checklist for a future guarantor</strong></p>\\n<p>Think carefully before you agree to act as a guarantor and ask yourself whether you really could afford to meet repayments should you need to. It&#8217;s not uncommon for the co-signer to lose money, or even their home, over a guarantee that has not worked out to plan.</p>\\n<p>Before signing the dotted line you should find out:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>How much will you be required to repay?</li>\\n<li>How will this repayment impact your ability to service your existing financial commitments?</li>\\n<li>Is the borrower likely to default?</li>\\n<li>How secure is the borrower&#8217;s current income?</li>\\n<li>Will your relationship be affected if the situation sours?</li>\\n</ul>\\n<blockquote><p><strong>Related stories</strong></p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback\\\">Out with the old, in with the new: why new cars are making a comeback</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/driving-away-with-a-good-deal\\\">Driving away with a good deal</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>If you&#8217;re not satisfied with the answers to these questions, all is not lost. There are alternatives to going guarantor and still helping your child into their first car. One popular option is to give the borrower an interest-free loan of a few thousand dollars, which they could use as a deposit.</p>\\n<p>Others prefer to help their children start a savings plan by matching their savings dollar for dollar.</p>\\n<p><strong>The upside to borrowing with backing</strong></p>\\n<p>While there are dangers involved with co-signing for a relative or friend, the upside for the borrower is that they have added obligation to meet repayments and clear debt. Having this added security may also attract lower interest rates, because the borrower is less risky in the mind of the lender.</p>\\n<p>It pays to <a href=\\\"/car-loans/compare\\\">compare car loans</a> online at sites such as RateCity to ensure you&#8217;re getting the lowest rate of interest. Online comparison sites also list all of the features, fees and terms and conditions attached to the loan so it&#8217;s easier to be across all the costs associated with these loans.</p>\\n<p><strong>Related car loan links</strong></p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"/car-loans/low-interest\\\">Low Interest Car Loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"/car-loans/best\\\">Best Car Loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/ten-of-the-best-car-loan-tips\\\">Ten of the best car loan tips</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/buying-a-car-why-a-porsche-might-not-be-the-best-idea\\\">Buying a car? Why a porsche might not be a good idea</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n<div class=\\\"daily-deals deal-row is-flex row\\\" data-reactid=\\\"848\\\"><!-- Sunshine Loan Centre -->\\n<div class=\\\"daily-deal-column weeks</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"hidden-sm\\\" data-reactid=\\\"862\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"row\\\" data-reactid=\\\"863\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\" data-reactid=\\\"864\\\">\\n<div spate of new affordable models entering the Australian market, but most young buyers still need a hand from mum and dad to get them over the line. Some parents help with the deposit and many are guarantors for their children's loans.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/1745/Car_guarantor.jpg\",\"id\":56054,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly/\",\"media_release\":null,\"meta_description\":\"The car loan market is hotting up thanks to a spate of new affordable models entering the Australian market, but most young buyers still need a hand from mum and dad to get them over the line. Some parents help with the deposit and many are guarantors for their children's loans.\",\"meta_keywords\":\"Car Loan, Car Loan Market, Deposit, Compare Car Loans, Car Loans Online, Interest-Free Loan, Interest Rates, Guarantor, Repayments, Guarantee, Financial Advice, Lender, Debts, RateCity,\",\"meta_title\":\"Going guarantor the good, the bad and the ugly\",\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"56054\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, 14 Mar 2017 14:00:00 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":4,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"The car loan market is hotting up thanks to a spate of new affordable models entering the Australian market, but most young buyers still need a hand from mum and dad to get them over the line. Some parents help with the deposit and many are guarantors for their children's loans.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/1745/Car_guarantor.jpg\",\"title\":\"Going guarantor: the good, the bad and the ugly\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1489591536\",\"url\":\"/car-loans/news/going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly/feed/\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1488166766:5\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"car-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Buying a new car is one of the biggest financial decisions you will make.</p>\\n<p>You wouldn’t purchase a used car without asking the owner a few standard questions first &#8211; how long have they owned it, what is the reason for selling, what condition is it in? &#8211; and it’s no different when it comes to buying new.</p>\\n<p>Here are RateCity’s top questions to ask before you buy a new car:</p>\\n<h3><strong>What&#8217;s the fuel efficiency?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Financially savvy shoppers will need to ensure their new car has good fuel efficiency to avoid a costly weekly spend on fuel. According to <a href=\\\"http://www.carsguide.com.au/\\\">Cars Guide</a>, fuel efficiency refers to the distance you can travel on an amount of fuel. </p>\\n<p>“Anything that is listed as less than 6-litres/100km or more than 16.5km/1-litre is considered to be pretty good.”</p>\\n<h3><strong>What is the warranty coverage?</strong></h3>\\n<p>If you experience any faults with your new car, you’ll want to know you’re covered for the replacement of faulty parts and the labour to do so. Asking your dealer about the vehicle&#8217;s warranty coverage will allow you to know for how long your dealer is obligated to fix the issue at no extra cost to yourself.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>For new cars, often the manufacturer’s warranty will be two-year/40,000kms or three-year/60,000kms. The statutory warranty for new cars is also usually for 12 months/20,000kms. For additional coverage, you can also purchase extended warranties to suit your needs.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3><strong>Is it good for long drives/off-road conditions?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Are you the outdoorsy type? Do you use your car for work and know you often have to make long drives? Choosing the right car for you isn’t just about the price, but also about how you will use it. If you know the car will be taking you across dirt roads every weekend, it will be best to ask your dealer how the car can handle these conditions.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Can I have a test drive?</strong></h3>\\n<p>You would never purchase a house without having first visited an inspection. The same rule applies for any car purchases. It is highly recommended you ask to test drive any car before purchasing it to have first-hand experience of how it performs and to see whether it meets your expectation.</p>\\n<p>Test vehicles are not always immediately available, so your dealer may have to schedule you for a later date. Check with your dealer about the length of time and the route of your test, as if you are looking for an off-road SUV you won’t want to test it in city conditions.</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170222145042/iStock-514059716.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>Has the car been used as a demo model?</strong></h3>\\n<p>If you’re looking to save hundreds, sometimes thousands of dollars, it’s worth asking your dealer if they have any demo cars available.</p>\\n<p>According to <a href=\\\"http://www.carsguide.com.au/\\\">Cars Guide</a> there are several pros and cons to picking up a demo car:</p>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Cheaper (always compare the price to a new model just in case)</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Well-maintained with bugs ironed out</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Drive away now (no waiting time)</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Less time left on a new car warranty</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">No option to customise the car</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Not brand new</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"car loans\",\"new cars\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Buying a new car is one of the biggest financial decisions you will make.</p>\\n<p>You wouldn’t purchase a used car without asking the owner a few standard questions first &#8211; how long have they owned it, what is the reason for selling, what condition is it in? &#8211; and it’s no different when it comes to buying new.</p>\\n<p>Here are RateCity’s top questions to ask before you buy a new car:</p>\\n<h3><strong>What&#8217;s the fuel efficiency?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Financially savvy shoppers will need to ensure their new car has good fuel efficiency to avoid a costly weekly spend on fuel. According to <a href=\\\"http://www.carsguide.com.au/\\\">Cars Guide</a>, fuel efficiency refers to the distance you can travel on an amount of fuel. </p>\\n<p>“Anything that is listed as less than 6-litres/100km or more than 16.5km/1-litre is considered to be pretty good.”</p>\\n<h3><strong>What is the warranty coverage?</strong></h3>\\n<p>If you experience any faults with your new car, you’ll want to know you’re covered for the replacement of faulty parts and the labour to do so. Asking your dealer about the vehicle&#8217;s warranty coverage will allow you to know for how long your dealer is obligated to fix the issue at no extra cost to yourself.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>For new cars, often the manufacturer’s warranty will be two-year/40,000kms or three-year/60,000kms. The statutory warranty for new cars is also usually for 12 months/20,000kms. For additional coverage, you can also purchase extended warranties to suit your needs.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3><strong>Is it good for long drives/off-road conditions?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Are you the outdoorsy type? Do you use your car for work and know you often have to make long drives? Choosing the right car for you isn’t just about the price, but also about how you will use it. If you know the car will be taking you across dirt roads every weekend, it will be best to ask your dealer how the car can handle these conditions.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Can I have a test drive?</strong></h3>\\n<p>You would never purchase a house without having first visited an inspection. The same rule applies for any car purchases. It is highly recommended you ask to test drive any car before purchasing it to have first-hand experience of how it performs and to see whether it meets your expectation.</p>\\n<p>Test vehicles are not always immediately available, so your dealer may have to schedule you for a later date. Check with your dealer about the length of time and the route of your test, as if you are looking for an off-road SUV you won’t want to test it in city conditions.</p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170222145042/iStock-514059716.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<h3><strong>Has the car been used as a demo model?</strong></h3>\\n<p>If you’re looking to save hundreds, sometimes thousands of dollars, it’s worth asking your dealer if they have any demo cars available.</p>\\n<p>According to <a href=\\\"http://www.carsguide.com.au/\\\">Cars Guide</a> there are several pros and cons to picking up a demo car:</p>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Cheaper (always compare the price to a new model just in case)</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Well-maintained with bugs ironed out</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Drive away now (no waiting time)</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Less time left on a new car warranty</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">No option to customise the car</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Not brand new</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1487774934\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Buying a new car is one of the biggest financial decisions you will make.
