car\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62316\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170222130150/iStock-501619772-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62316,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/questions-ask-buy-new-car/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62316\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 22 Feb 2017 04:48:54 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"Here are RateCity’s top questions to ask before you buy a new car.\",\"slug\":\"questions-ask-buy-new-car\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170222130150/iStock-501619772-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"Questions to ask before you buy a new car\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1487775249\",\"url\":\"/car-loans/news/questions-ask-buy-new-car\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"_edit_lock\":\"1478821722:22\",\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"The Australian love affair with SUVs continues, with new car buying intention statistics showing medium sized SUVs are the car of choice around the nation according to Roy Morgan Research.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Demand for cars up, with medium SUVs leading the way\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"car-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/328eb658853e1e60ee4b7080fb10121a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"RateCity Staff\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>The Australian love affair with SUVs continues, with new car buying intention statistics showing medium sized SUVs are the car of choice around the nation according to Roy Morgan Research.</p>\\n<p>Upwards of 850,000 Australians intend to buy an SUV in the next four years, a figure that has risen 20 per cent in the last year alone. The most popular vehicles noted by intended buyers included the Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4 and the Hyundai Tucson.</p>\\n<p>But while medium sized SUVs are certainly having their moment, the car market as a whole is set to experience a lift with 2,331,000 Australians now intending to buy a new vehicle in the next four years. This includes 634,000 buyers who are looking to buy within the next 12 months.</p>\\n<p>Both these short- and medium-term intentions are on an upward trend, fully reversing a decline over the second half of 2015.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related stories</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers\\\">Five critical questions for car buyers</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/how-to-beat-depreciation-on-your-car\\\">How to beat depreciation on your car</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/biggest-car-buyer-regrets\\\">Biggest car buyer regrets</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>&ldquo;Car buying intentions have continued to improve with 11.8% per cent of the population (14+) intending to buy a new car in the next four years (equating to 2.33 million people),&rdquo; said Jordan Pakes, Industry Director &ndash; Automotive, Roy Morgan Research.</p>\\n<p>If you are among the many Australians who are looking to buy in the near future, you may be wondering how you can finance your purchase. If you have your heart set on the car of your dreams, finding a car loan that will make you just as happy could be a little harder.</p>\\n<p>Here are five tips to put you on the right track to finding a good deal on your car loan:</p>\\n<p><em>Check your credit history:&nbsp;</em>Arm yourself for your search by knowing how a possible lender views you. Use a free credit check service to see what your credit rating is and, if it&rsquo;s great, use this as a bargaining chip.</p>\\n<p><em>Compare interest rates: </em>Start to understand the market by comparing the interest rates available. This way you will be able to differentiate between a lender that is offering a loan at a reasonable rate and one that is unnecessarily high.</p>\\n<p><em>Compare fees:</em>&nbsp;Don&rsquo;t only look at interest rates, compare the fees that each loan charges as well. Is there a fee for making extra repayments? Or ending the loan early? Read the product disclosure statement so you have all the info before signing up.</p>\\n<p><em>Apply for your top pick: </em>Once you have narrowed down your search to a couple of good loans, apply for your top pick only. Applying for multiple loans, and possibly being knocked back from some, can negatively affect your credit rating. Apply for the best loan for your needs and wait to hear back before applying for more.</p>\\n<p><em>Secure your loan:</em>&nbsp;Car loans can be unsecured or secured against the value of your car. Secured loans are generally cheaper as the lender will be able to recoup your vehicle if you default on the loan. This may be a good way to reduce car loan costs if you are confident you will be making your repayments regularly.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans?nav=car-loans\\\">Compare car loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/calculator?nav=car-loans-calculator\\\">Car loans calculator</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/guide?nav=car-loans-guide\\\">Car loans guide</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/demand-for-cars-up-with-medium-suvs-leading-the-way/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>The Australian love affair with SUVs continues, with new car buying intention statistics showing medium sized SUVs are the car of choice around the nation according to Roy Morgan Research.</p>\\n<p>Upwards of 850,000 Australians intend to buy an SUV in the next four years, a figure that has risen 20 per cent in the last year alone. The most popular vehicles noted by intended buyers included the Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4 and the Hyundai Tucson.</p>\\n<p>But while medium sized SUVs are certainly having their moment, the car market as a whole is set to experience a lift with 2,331,000 Australians now intending to buy a new vehicle in the next four years. This includes 634,000 buyers who are looking to buy within the next 12 months.</p>\\n<p>Both these short- and medium-term intentions are on an upward trend, fully reversing a decline over the second half of 2015.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related stories</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers\\\">Five critical questions for car buyers</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/how-to-beat-depreciation-on-your-car\\\">How to beat depreciation on your car</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/biggest-car-buyer-regrets\\\">Biggest car buyer regrets</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>&ldquo;Car buying intentions have continued to improve with 11.8% per cent of the population (14+) intending to buy a new car in the next four years (equating to 2.33 million people),&rdquo; said Jordan Pakes, Industry Director &ndash; Automotive, Roy Morgan Research.</p>\\n<p>If you are among the many Australians who are looking to buy in the near future, you may be wondering how you can finance your purchase. If you have your heart set on the car of your dreams, finding a car loan that will make you just as happy could be a little harder.</p>\\n<p>Here are five tips to put you on the right track to finding a good deal on your car loan:</p>\\n<p><em>Check your credit history:&nbsp;</em>Arm yourself for your search by knowing how a possible lender views you. Use a free credit check service to see what your credit rating is and, if it&rsquo;s great, use this as a bargaining chip.</p>\\n<p><em>Compare interest rates: </em>Start to understand the market by comparing the interest rates available. This way you will be able to differentiate between a lender that is offering a loan at a reasonable rate and one that is unnecessarily high.</p>\\n<p><em>Compare fees:</em>&nbsp;Don&rsquo;t only look at interest rates, compare the fees that each loan charges as well. Is there a fee for making extra repayments? Or ending the loan early? Read the product disclosure statement so you have all the info before signing up.</p>\\n<p><em>Apply for your top pick: </em>Once you have narrowed down your search to a couple of good loans, apply for your top pick only. Applying for multiple loans, and possibly being knocked back from some, can negatively affect your credit rating. Apply for the best loan for your needs and wait to hear back before applying for more.</p>\\n<p><em>Secure your loan:</em>&nbsp;Car loans can be unsecured or secured against the value of your car. Secured loans are generally cheaper as the lender will be able to recoup your vehicle if you default on the loan. This may be a good way to reduce car loan costs if you are confident you will be making your repayments regularly.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a Staff\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>The decision to buy a new car may seem insignificant compared to purchasing a house, but the due diligence required is very similar.</p>\\n<p>A wrong move in the bargaining process could equal years of additional debt, while a hasty selection could diminish the resale value.</p>\\n<p>Essentially, it comes down to the questions you ask at the onset, which include the following.</p>\\n<h3>Does it meet my needs and expectations?</h3>\\n<p>Before you get started, it&rsquo;s wise to come up with a checklist of what exactly you&rsquo;re looking for in a car. New or second hand? Prestige or budget? Compact or family? What model?</p>\\n<p>Then, narrow down further and ask whether it has the right safety and reliability ratings, ticks the boxes on fuel efficiency and has a clean maintenance history if it is second hand.</p>\\n<h3>Do I know anyone with this car?</h3>\\n<p>An honest reviewer will tell you what the car dealer or private seller won&rsquo;t. Scan your network to see if anyone has the car you intend to buy and ask them for the pros and cons. You can also look on sites like reddit for reviews of makes and models.</p>\\n<h3>What are the running costs?</h3>\\n<p>Underestimating the cost of running your new car is a dangerous mistake from a budgeting perspective. Find out how much it costs to service (get quotes from several auto-mechanics), how much a tank of fuel is and how long it typically takes before parts start to deteriorate. Then find out how much part replacement costs are.</p>\\n<h3>Can I do better on price?</h3>\\n<p>Always be willing to negotiate on price because the sticker price is rarely what the vendor expects to sell it for. If you have doubts, walk away, even if that takes the offer off the table. Often, if you go back in 24 hours, the offer will still stand.</p>\\n<h3>How will I finance it?</h3>\\n<p>Car loans are becoming a more popular way of paying for a new vehicle for those who don&rsquo;t have ready finance, but before you take one, it&rsquo;s important to evaluate how much you can afford to borrow, what your repayments would be and how long the liability would hang around.</p>\\n<p>Unlike houses and units, cars inevitably depreciate in value, so only take a loan if you&rsquo;re comfortable you will be able to pay it off over a period of time, in a variety of circumstances, and know that you are unlikely to recoup the sale value.&nbsp;</p>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>The decision to buy a new car may seem insignificant compared to purchasing a house, but the due diligence required is very similar.</p>\\n<p>A wrong move in the bargaining process could equal years of additional debt, while a hasty selection could diminish the resale value.</p>\\n<p>Essentially, it comes down to the questions you ask at the onset, which include the following.</p>\\n<h3>Does it meet my needs and expectations?</h3>\\n<p>Before you get started, it&rsquo;s wise to come up with a checklist of what exactly you&rsquo;re looking for in a car. New or second hand? Prestige or budget? Compact or family? What model?</p>\\n<p>Then, narrow down further and ask whether it has the right safety and reliability ratings, ticks the boxes on fuel efficiency and has a clean maintenance history if it is second hand.</p>\\n<h3>Do I know anyone with this car?</h3>\\n<p>An honest reviewer will tell you what the car dealer or private seller won&rsquo;t. Scan your network to see if anyone has the car you intend to buy and ask them for the pros and cons. You can also look on sites like reddit for reviews of makes and models.</p>\\n<h3>What are the running costs?</h3>\\n<p>Underestimating the cost of running your new car is a dangerous mistake from a budgeting perspective. Find out how much it costs to service (get quotes from several auto-mechanics), how much a tank of fuel is and how long it typically takes before parts start to deteriorate. Then find out how much part replacement costs are.</p>\\n<h3>Can I do better on price?</h3>\\n<p>Always be willing to negotiate on price because the sticker price is rarely what the vendor expects to sell it for. If you have doubts, walk away, even if that takes the offer off the table. Often, if you go back in 24 hours, the offer will still stand.</p>\\n<h3>How will I finance it?</h3>\\n<p>Car loans are becoming a more popular way of paying for a new vehicle for those who don&rsquo;t have ready finance, but before you take one, it&rsquo;s important to evaluate how much you can afford to borrow, what your repayments would be and how long the liability would hang around.</p>\\n<p>Unlike houses and units, cars inevitably depreciate in value, so only take a loan if you&rsquo;re comfortable you will be able to pay it off over a period of time, in a variety of circumstances, and know that you are unlikely to recoup the sale value.&nbsp;</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1468905996\",\"dc:creator\":\"RateCity Staff\",\"description\":\"The decision to buy a new car may seem insignificant compared to purchasing a house, but the due diligence required is very similar.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3717/iStock_86063089_SMALL.jpg\",\"id\":56102,\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers/\",\"meta_description\":\"The decision to buy a new car may seem insignificant compared to purchasing a house, but the due diligence required is very similar.\",\"meta_title\":\"Five critical questions for car buyers\",\"overallRating\":null,\"post_id\":\"56102\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon, 18 Jul 2016 19:26:36 +0000\",\"readingTime\":3,\"short_description\":\"The decision to buy a new car may seem insignificant compared to purchasing a house, but the due diligence required is very similar.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3717/iStock_86063089_SMALL.jpg\",\"title\":\"Five critical questions for car buyers\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1468905996\",\"url\":\"/car-loans/news/five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/five-critical-questions-for-car-buyers/feed/\"},{\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"Finding the perfect new car can be hard. It has to be the right brand, have the right features and of course the right look.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Top three questions you should ask when getting a car loan\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"car-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/328eb658853e1e60ee4b7080fb10121a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"RateCity Staff\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Finding the perfect new car can be hard. It has to be the right brand, have the right features and of course the right look.</p>\\n<p>While it pays to be picky when choosing your car, the same is true when it comes to car loans. Getting stuck in a car loan with high interest rates or fees can continue to have bad financial repercussions long after the excitement of owning a new car has worn off.</p>\\n<p>The best way to avoid an impulse car loan decision, that will leave you paying through the nose, is to do some research on the right loan for you. RateCity spoke to Michael Cullinan, Director of <a href=\\\"https://gorapid.com.au/\\\">Rapid Finance</a>, about the best questions to ask about a car loan before signing on the dotted line.</p>\\n<p><strong>Is this a good interest rate?</strong></p>\\n<p>Knowing what is considered a good interest rate in the market is essential to being able to compare the loans on offer against a bench mark. Currently the lowest loans are under five per cent but are only available to customers who are securing their loan against an asset. This asset is usually the car that is being purchased.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Securing your loan is the best way to get access to the lowest interest rates,&rdquo; says Cullinan, &ldquo;and for added security you can fix your interest rate so that you can plan your repayments going forward.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>Deciding on a fixed or variable interest rate is also an important consideration. A fixed interest rate will remain the same over the loan term but a variable interest rate will fluctuate at the lenders discretion.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Fixing can seem like a risk, as you might miss out on lower interest rates down the track, but if you prefer peace of mind in knowing your repayment amount over the term of the loan fixing is the best option.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Although, if you don&rsquo;t mind the potential risk of higher interest rates for a period of your loan, there is the possibility of saving money on interest over time with a variable loan,&rdquo; says Cullinan.&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/biggest-car-buyer-regrets\\\">Biggest car buyer regrets</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly\\\">Going guarantor: the good, the bad and the ugly</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/how-to-beat-depreciation-on-your-car\\\">How to beat depreciation on your car</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p><strong>What fees are involved? &nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>\\n<p>Once you have found a loan with a competitive interest rate it is important to look at the fees that will be charged on a once off and ongoing basis. From establishment fees to account keeping fees and early termination fees, you might find that what initially seemed like a great deal will end up costing a fair bit more over time.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Checking the comparison rate of a car loan is a great way to understand the overall costs associated with the loan,&rdquo; advises Cullinan.</p>\\n<p>The comparison rate includes the interest rate and fees associated with a loan to provide customers with a more accurate representation of what they will be paying to the lender in total.</p>\\n<p>An important fee, that is often over looked by those taking out car loans, is the residual fee or &lsquo;balloon payment&rsquo; charged at the end of the loan term. The residual fee is a lump sum payment, that you can opt to include as part of your loan, which keeps <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">monthly repayments</a> down but has to be paid at the end of the loan before the car is completely owned by the customer. Before signing up for a loan with a residual payment consider how you will pay the amount when the time comes and budget it into your savings plans.</p>\\n<p><strong>Can I make the repayments?</strong></p>\\n<p>The single most important question that customers should ask before taking out a car loan is whether or not they will be able to afford the repayments over the life of the loan.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Calculating your monthly repayments and factoring them into your budget before you take out a loan is the key making sure you will have no issues down the track,&rdquo; says Cullinan. You can use a <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/calculator\\\">car loans calculator</a>&nbsp;to estimate your monthly repayments.</p>\\n<p>Keeping in mind that circumstances can change, and preparing a buffer, is just as important.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;If you find that you can comfortably make your expected car loan repayments now, consider what would happen if you were to have an unexpected expense one month,&rdquo; says Cullinan, &ldquo;If you don&rsquo;t think you could afford the repayment in this situation you may have to save up a buffer before committing to a loan.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>In some cases, missing a repayment on your car loan can mean that interest rates are jacked up for the remaining term of the loan, costing you more in the long run. Doing some budget planning beforehand, with the help of a car loans calculator, will help prepare you for all the possibilities and prevent you from defaulting on the loan.</p>\\n<p><em>This article is sponsored by Rapid Finance. For more information on Rapid&#39;s extensive range of car loans, including secured and bad credit car loans, visit:&nbsp;<a href=\\\"https://gorapid.com.au/car-loans/\\\">https://gorapid.com.au/car-loans/</a></em><br />\\n&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans?nav=car-loans\\\">Compare car loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/calculator?nav=car-loans-calculator\\\">Car loans calculator</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/new-cars\\\">Compare new car loans</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/top-three-questions-you-should-ask-when-getting-a-car-loan/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Finding the perfect new car can be hard. It has to be the right brand, have the right features and of course the right look.</p>\\n<p>While it pays to be picky when choosing your car, the same is true when it comes to car loans. Getting stuck in a car loan with high interest rates or fees can continue to have bad financial repercussions long after the excitement of owning a new car has worn off.</p>\\n<p>The best way to avoid an impulse car loan decision, that will leave you paying through the nose, is to do some research on the right loan for you. RateCity spoke to Michael Cullinan, Director of <a href=\\\"https://gorapid.com.au/\\\">Rapid Finance</a>, about the best questions to ask about a car loan before signing on the dotted line.</p>\\n<p><strong>Is this a good interest rate?</strong></p>\\n<p>Knowing what is considered a good interest rate in the market is essential to being able to compare the loans on offer against a bench mark. Currently the lowest loans are under five per cent but are only available to customers who are securing their loan against an asset. This asset is usually the car that is being purchased.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Securing your loan is the best way to get access to the lowest interest rates,&rdquo; says Cullinan, &ldquo;and for added security you can fix your interest rate so that you can plan your repayments going forward.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>Deciding on a fixed or variable interest rate is also an important consideration. A fixed interest rate will remain the same over the loan term but a variable interest rate will fluctuate at the lenders discretion.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Fixing can seem like a risk, as you might miss out on lower interest rates down the track, but if you prefer peace of mind in knowing your repayment amount over the term of the loan fixing is the best option.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Although, if you don&rsquo;t mind the potential risk of higher interest rates for a period of your loan, there is the possibility of saving money on interest over time with a variable loan,&rdquo; says Cullinan.&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/biggest-car-buyer-regrets\\\">Biggest car buyer regrets</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/going-guarantor-the-good-the-bad-and-the-ugly\\\">Going guarantor: the good, the bad and the ugly</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/how-to-beat-depreciation-on-your-car\\\">How to beat depreciation on your car</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p><strong>What fees are involved? &nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>\\n<p>Once you have found a loan with a competitive interest rate it is important to look at the fees that will be charged on a once off and ongoing basis. From establishment fees to account keeping fees and early termination fees, you might find that what initially seemed like a great deal will end up costing a fair bit more over time.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Checking the comparison rate of a car loan is a great way to understand the overall costs associated with the loan,&rdquo; advises Cullinan.</p>\\n<p>The comparison rate includes the interest rate and fees associated with a loan to provide customers with a more accurate representation of what they will be paying to the lender in total.</p>\\n<p>An important fee, that is often over looked by those taking out car loans, is the residual fee or &lsquo;balloon payment&rsquo; charged at the end of the loan term. The residual fee is a lump sum payment, that you can opt to include as part of your loan, which keeps <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">monthly repayments</a> down but has to be paid at the end of the loan before the car is completely owned by the customer. Before signing up for a loan with a residual payment consider how you will pay the amount when the time comes and budget it into your savings plans.</p>\\n<p><strong>Can I make the repayments?</strong></p>\\n<p>The single most important question that customers should ask before taking out a car loan is whether or not they will be able to afford the repayments over the life of the loan.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Calculating your monthly repayments and factoring them into your budget before you take out a loan is the key making sure you will have no issues down the track,&rdquo; says Cullinan. You can use a <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/calculator\\\">car loans calculator</a>&nbsp;to estimate your monthly repayments.</p>\\n<p>Keeping in mind that circumstances can change, and preparing a buffer, is just as important.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;If you find that you can comfortably make your expected car loan repayments now, consider what would happen if you were to have an unexpected expense one month,&rdquo; says Cullinan, &ldquo;If you don&rsquo;t think you could afford the repayment in this situation you may have to save up a buffer before committing to a loan.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>In some cases, missing a repayment on your car loan can mean that interest rates are jacked up for the remaining term of the loan, costing you more in the long run. Doing some budget planning beforehand, with the help of a car loans calculator, will help prepare you for all the possibilities and prevent you from defaulting on the loan.</p>\\n<p><em>This article is sponsored by Rapid Finance. For more information on Rapid&#39;s extensive range of car loans, including secured and bad credit car loans, visit:&nbsp;<a href=\\\"https://gorapid.com.au/car-loans/\\\">https://gorapid.com.au/car-loans/</a></em><br />\\n&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans?nav=car-loans\\\">Compare car loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/calculator?nav=car-loans-calculator\\\">Car loans calculator</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/new-cars\\\">Compare new car loans</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\",\"created_at\":\"1464142185\",\"dc:creator\":\"RateCity Staff\",\"description\":\"Finding the perfect new car can be hard. It has to be the right brand, have the right features and of course the right look.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/top-three-questions-you-should-ask-when-getting-a-car-loan/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3703/iStock_000082822507_Small.jpg\",\"id\":56101,\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/top-three-questions-you-should-ask-when-getting-a-car-loan/\",\"meta_description\":\"Finding the perfect new car can be hard. It has to be the right brand, have the right features and of course the right look.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"top-three-questions-you-should-ask-when-getting-a-car-loan\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3703/iStock_000082822507_Small.jpg\",\"title\":\"Top three questions you should ask when getting a car loan\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1464142185\",\"url\":\"/car-loans/news/top-three-questions-you-should-ask-when-getting-a-car-loan\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/top-three-questions-you-should-ask-when-getting-a-car-loan/feed/\"},{\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"A RateCity.com.au analysis of ABS data has revealed that Aussie appetite for new car loans jumped in the 12 months to January 2016, compared to the same time the previous year. Used car loans on the other hand were down 0.50 per cent in the same period, suggesting a decline in the popularity of second hand rides. Evidently, VFACTS February sales figures showed 96,443 brand new vehicles were sold. Intention to buy a new car in the next four years is also up, with 2.21 million Aussies planning on making a purchase before 2020, according to Roy Morgan statistics.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Out with the old, in with the new: new cars make a comeback\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"car-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/655d7e0698b4208ced875c98ddae1987?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>It&rsquo;s official; 2016 is the year of the new car with the latest car finance figures showing a 7.35 per cent spike in value in total loans taken out for a new set of wheels in the past year.</p>\\n<p>A RateCity.com.au analysis of ABS data has revealed that <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/aussie\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Aussie</a> appetite for new car loans jumped in the 12 months to January 2016, compared to the same time the previous year. Used car loans on the other hand were down 0.50 per cent in the same period, suggesting a decline in the popularity of second hand rides.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\\n<p>Evidently, VFACTS February sales figures showed 96,443 brand new vehicles were sold.</p>\\n<p>Intention to buy a new car in the next four years is also up, with 2.21 million Aussies planning on making a purchase before 2020, according to Roy Morgan statistics.</p>\\n<p>So why the surge in new car purchases?</p>\\n<p>Sally Tindall, money editor at RateCity.com.au, says the higher costs of keeping a car on the road in recent years have reshaped Australians&rsquo; preferences.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;High fuel prices have driven customers to purchase smaller, more fuel efficient cars and the newer models on the market are some of the cheapest to run in this regard,&rdquo; she says.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;With the cost of these cars below $12,000 in some instances more Australian&rsquo;s can now easily afford to make a new car purchase with the help of the right car loan.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>Toyota and Mazda took out the largest percentage of sales last month to remain the most popular car brands in Australia. It is no coincidence that models such as the Mazda 2, Toyota Camry and Toyota Prado frequently feature on lists of the cheapest cars to run.</p>\\n<p>Bill Tsouvalas, founder & CEO at <a href=\\\"http://www.savvy.com.au/\\\">Savvy</a> agrees, &ldquo;Australian&rsquo;s don&rsquo;t mind spending the money on a new car if they know that it won&rsquo;t cost them a fortune in the long run.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Fuel efficiency and reliability are big deciding factors in where Aussies take their business and newer cars seem to deliver these guarantees more effectively,&rdquo; he says.</p>\\n<p>If you are one of the 585,000 people predicted to buy are new car by the end of the year then getting your finances in order early will improve your odds of getting the car you want when the time comes.</p>\\n<p>Chances are you don&rsquo;t have the full amount saved up for your purchase so it might be wise to start looking at car finance options. When you purchase a new car through a dealership they will have a car loan option available but, while convenient, this might not always be the best deal.</p>\\n<p>Tsouvalas says you should compare car loans available on the market in advance to avoid committing to a loan in a spur of the moment decision.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Taking out a car loan on impulse could result in you getting stuck with a high interest rate or a loan that doesn&rsquo;t allow you to make extra repayments and pay off the loan early,&rdquo; he says.</p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p class=\\\"caption\\\"><em><span class=\\\"highlight\\\">This article is sponsored by Savvy Finance. For more information on Savvy&#39;s extensive range of car loans visit: <a href=\\\"http://www.savvy.com.au/car-loans\\\">www.savvy.com.au/car-loans</a>.</span></em></p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related stories:</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/the-new-law-that-could-put-a-porsche-within-your-reach\\\">The new law that could put that Porsche within your&nbsp;reach</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/chattel-mortgages-explained\\\">Chattel mortgages explained</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/the-world-s-biggest-car-collectors-and-their-fleets\\\">The world&#39;s biggest car collectors and their fleets</a></li>\\n</ul>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>It&rsquo;s official; 2016 is the year of the new car with the latest car finance figures showing a 7.35 per cent spike in value in total loans taken out for a new set of wheels in the past year.</p>\\n<p>A RateCity.com.au analysis of ABS data has revealed that <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/aussie\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Aussie</a> appetite for new car loans jumped in the 12 months to January 2016, compared to the same time the previous year. Used car loans on the other hand were down 0.50 per cent in the same period, suggesting a decline in the popularity of second hand rides.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\\n<p>Evidently, VFACTS February sales figures showed 96,443 brand new vehicles were sold.</p>\\n<p>Intention to buy a new car in the next four years is also up, with 2.21 million Aussies planning on making a purchase before 2020, according to Roy Morgan statistics.</p>\\n<p>So why the surge in new car purchases?</p>\\n<p>Sally Tindall, money editor at RateCity.com.au, says the higher costs of keeping a car on the road in recent years have reshaped Australians&rsquo; preferences.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;High fuel prices have driven customers to purchase smaller, more fuel efficient cars and the newer models on the market are some of the cheapest to run in this regard,&rdquo; she says.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;With the cost of these cars below $12,000 in some instances more Australian&rsquo;s can now easily afford to make a new car purchase with the help of the right car loan.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>Toyota and Mazda took out the largest percentage of sales last month to remain the most popular car brands in Australia. It is no coincidence that models such as the Mazda 2, Toyota Camry and Toyota Prado frequently feature on lists of the cheapest cars to run.</p>\\n<p>Bill Tsouvalas, founder & CEO at <a href=\\\"http://www.savvy.com.au/\\\">Savvy</a> agrees, &ldquo;Australian&rsquo;s don&rsquo;t mind spending the money on a new car if they know that it won&rsquo;t cost them a fortune in the long run.&rdquo;</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Fuel efficiency and reliability are big deciding factors in where Aussies take their business and newer cars seem to deliver these guarantees more effectively,&rdquo; he says.</p>\\n<p>If you are one of the 585,000 people predicted to buy are new car by the end of the year then getting your finances in order early will improve your odds of getting the car you want when the time comes.</p>\\n<p>Chances are you don&rsquo;t have the full amount saved up for your purchase so it might be wise to start looking at car finance options. When you purchase a new car through a dealership they will have a car loan option available but, while convenient, this might not always be the best deal.</p>\\n<p>Tsouvalas says you should compare car loans available on the market in advance to avoid committing to a loan in a spur of the moment decision.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Taking out a car loan on impulse could result in you getting stuck with a high interest rate or a loan that doesn&rsquo;t allow you to make extra repayments and pay off the loan early,&rdquo; he says.</p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p class=\\\"caption\\\"><em><span class=\\\"highlight\\\">This article is sponsored by Savvy Finance. For more information on Savvy&#39;s extensive range of car loans visit: <a href=\\\"http://www.savvy.com.au/car-loans\\\">www.savvy.com.au/car-loans</a>.</span></em></p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related stories:</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/the-new-law-that-could-put-a-porsche-within-your-reach\\\">The new law that could put that Porsche within your&nbsp;reach</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/chattel-mortgages-explained\\\">Chattel mortgages explained</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/the-world-s-biggest-car-collectors-and-their-fleets\\\">The world&#39;s biggest car collectors and their fleets</a></li>\\n</ul>\",\"created_at\":\"1459393383\",\"dc:creator\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"description\":\"A RateCity.com.au analysis of ABS data has revealed that Aussie appetite for new car loans jumped in the 12 months to January 2016, compared to the same time the previous year. Used car loans on the other hand were down 0.50 per cent in the same period, suggesting a decline in the popularity of second hand rides.
