Intention to buy a new car in the next four years is also up, with 2.21 million Aussies planning on making a purchase before 2020, according to Roy Morgan statistics.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3679/New_cars.jpg\",\"id\":56100,\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback/\",\"meta_description\":\"A RateCity.com.au analysis of ABS data has revealed that Aussie appetite for new car loans jumped in the 12 months to January 2016, compared to the same time the previous year. Used car loans on the other hand were down 0.50 per cent in the same period, suggesting a decline in the popularity of second hand rides. Evidently, VFACTS February sales figures showed 96,443 brand new vehicles were sold. Intention to buy a new car in the next four years is also up, with 2.21 million Aussies planning on making a purchase before 2020, according to Roy Morgan statistics.\",\"meta_title\":\"Out with the old, in with the new: new cars make a comeback\",\"overallRating\":null,\"post_id\":\"56100\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 30 Mar 2016 17:03:03 +0000\",\"readingTime\":3,\"short_description\":\"A RateCity.com.au analysis of ABS data has revealed that Aussie appetite for new car loans jumped in the 12 months to January 2016, compared to the same time the previous year. Used car loans on the other hand were down 0.50 per cent in the same period, suggesting a decline in the popularity of second hand rides. Evidently, VFACTS February sales figures showed 96,443 brand new vehicles were sold. Intention to buy a new car in the next four years is also up, with 2.21 million Aussies planning on making a purchase before 2020, according to Roy Morgan statistics.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3679/New_cars.jpg\",\"title\":\"Out with the old, in with the new: new cars make a comeback\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1459393383\",\"url\":\"/car-loans/news/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-new-cars-make-a-comeback/feed/\"}],\"creditCards\":[{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"39\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1491192240:39\",\"_wp_old_slug\":\"credit-card-changes-winners-losers\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"credit-cards\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p><span>From 1 July 2017, new credit card regulations <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/media-releases/2016/mr-16-15.html\\\">recommended by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA)</a> will come into effect, including a cap on interchange fees – the fees that <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit card</a> providers charge banks to cover the cost of processing credit card transactions.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The credit card market is already being shaken up in anticipation of these changes, with banks preparing for the new regulations to take effect. But who exactly will end up better or worse off as a result?</span><span> </span></p>\\n<h3><span>What are interchange fees, and how are they changing?</span></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"cropped image of hands with credit card\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, lenders use interchange fees to help cover the costs of providing credit cards to consumers, including the costs of transferring money from one bank to another. Up until now, interchange fees have been a lucrative business for some lenders, who have been charging interchange fees of up to 3% of the transaction value for some premium credit cards. It has been estimated that banks currently earn approximately $2 billion annually in credit card interchange fees.</span></p>\\n<p><span>When you buy something with a credit card, the merchant’s bank pays the interchange fee to the bank providing your credit card. However, some banks pass the cost of interchange fees on to merchants in the form of Merchant Service Fees, which can cut into the bottom lines of some sellers. As a result, some merchants pass these costs on to customers in turn, whether by raising prices, putting surcharges on credit card transactions, or requiring a minimum spend for credit card payments (often $10 or more).</span></p>\\n<p><span>From 1 July, the RBA is mandating <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/q-and-a/card-payments-regulation-qa-conclusions-paper.html#interchange-fees\\\">a cap on interchange fees of 0.8%</a>. This means that for a $100 credit card purchase, a credit card’s issuer can only charge up to 80c from a merchant’s bank, rather than up to $3 as was previously the case for some premium credit cards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>This change to interchange fees is likely to have a significant impact on how banks and merchants generate revenue from credit card transactions, and on how everyday consumers use their credit cards.</span></p>\\n<h3><span>Who wins and who loses?</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Winning?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Credit cardholders</strong> &#8211; fewer extra charges</li>\\n<li><strong>Merchants</strong> &#8211; reduced merchant service fees</li>\\n<li><strong>People seeking CCs</strong> &#8211; lots of competition</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Losing?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Reward cardholders</strong> &#8211; harder to earn points</li>\\n<li><strong>Banks</strong> &#8211; losing interchange fee revenue</li>\\n<li><strong>Everyday cardholders</strong> &#8211; fees may increase</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Smiling young woman holding a credit card and typing on a laptop.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The question of whether credit card users will ultimately be better or </span><span>worse off from these new interchange fee regulations may ultimately depend on whether they’re using their credit cards as a simple and affordable way to buy now and pay later, or as a means to earn premium rewards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Consumers with rewards credit cards could be in for a tough time, as from mid-2017, it may be much more difficult and/or expensive to earn a free flight to the Gold Coast simply by regularly spending on your credit card. The forecast reduction in revenue from interchange fees means that banks may need to limit, reduce, or remove some of the extra benefits and services they offer, including credit card rewards. For example, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> recently got rid of high-reward <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> Reward Cards:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Changes to interchange fees are expected to hit credit cards with rewards programs the hardest, and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> credit cards are renowned for their competitive rewards.</p>\\n<p>Some banks issue <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards with their credit cards, where an Amex is linked to the same account as your Visa or MasterCard, so you can access its reward program. The new caps on interchange fees could lead to many of these Amex companion cards being withdrawn from the market.</p>\\n<p>However, credit cards issued by <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> itself deal directly with the merchant’s bank rather than going through a separate issuing bank, so interchange fees aren&#8217;t involved. You&#8217;ll still need to pay above-average interest rates and fees in some cases, but you&#8217;ll continue to enjoy access to the competitive Amex rewards program.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>For consumers with simpler low-rate credit cards without a rewards program, t</span><span>he new RBA regulations could make flashing the plastic at the checkout a much more viable option, no matter the transaction. </span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\"><img class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Bartender receiving credit card of customer for payment in cafe\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The new caps on interchange fees should help to keep the corresponding merchant service fees relatively low, thus providing merchants the flexibility to offer more competitive pricing and eliminate minimum spend amounts for credit card payments. Credit card surcharges may remain, but a separate set of regulations (<a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/conclusions-paper-may2016/excessive-surcharging.html\\\">effective September 2016 for large businesses, and September 2017 for small businesses</a>) should limit these to just cover the cost of the merchant service fee.</span></p>\\n<p><span>Another potential outcome of these regulations could end up affecting many credit cardholders. If banks start looking for other ways to raise the revenue they once got from interchange fees, it’s possible that they may start increasing the annual fees, late payment fees, and other charges on credit cards.    </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//TypXILYH3E0\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><span>Because it’s likely that many banks and lenders will make changes to their credit card offers as a result of these regulations, it’s also likely that many consumers may start considering alternative credit card options – the perfect time for smart lenders to unveil competitive new credit card deals. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, there are 180 different <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit cards</a> to choose from on the Australian market, including 83 <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/reward-programs\\\">credit cards with rewards programs</a>. If you find yourself in the market for a new or replacement credit card, remember to <a href=\\\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/compare\\\">compare credit cards</a> to find the options that will prove the most suitable for your unique financial situation. </span></p>\",\"category\":[\"credit cards\",\"interchange fees\",\"RateCity\",\"rba\",\"regulations\",\"reserve bank of australia\",\"rewards\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p><span>From 1 July 2017, new credit card regulations <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/media-releases/2016/mr-16-15.html\\\">recommended by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA)</a> will come into effect, including a cap on interchange fees – the fees that <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit card</a> providers charge banks to cover the cost of processing credit card transactions.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The credit card market is already being shaken up in anticipation of these changes, with banks preparing for the new regulations to take effect. But who exactly will end up better or worse off as a result?</span><span> </span></p>\\n<h3><span>What are interchange fees, and how are they changing?</span></h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"cropped image of hands with credit card\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328140240/credit-card-lender.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, lenders use interchange fees to help cover the costs of providing credit cards to consumers, including the costs of transferring money from one bank to another. Up until now, interchange fees have been a lucrative business for some lenders, who have been charging interchange fees of up to 3% of the transaction value for some premium credit cards. It has been estimated that banks currently earn approximately $2 billion annually in credit card interchange fees.</span></p>\\n<p><span>When you buy something with a credit card, the merchant’s bank pays the interchange fee to the bank providing your credit card. However, some banks pass the cost of interchange fees on to merchants in the form of Merchant Service Fees, which can cut into the bottom lines of some sellers. As a result, some merchants pass these costs on to customers in turn, whether by raising prices, putting surcharges on credit card transactions, or requiring a minimum spend for credit card payments (often $10 or more).</span></p>\\n<p><span>From 1 July, the RBA is mandating <a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/q-and-a/card-payments-regulation-qa-conclusions-paper.html#interchange-fees\\\">a cap on interchange fees of 0.8%</a>. This means that for a $100 credit card purchase, a credit card’s issuer can only charge up to 80c from a merchant’s bank, rather than up to $3 as was previously the case for some premium credit cards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>This change to interchange fees is likely to have a significant impact on how banks and merchants generate revenue from credit card transactions, and on how everyday consumers use their credit cards.</span></p>\\n<h3><span>Who wins and who loses?</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Winning?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Credit cardholders</strong> &#8211; fewer extra charges</li>\\n<li><strong>Merchants</strong> &#8211; reduced merchant service fees</li>\\n<li><strong>People seeking CCs</strong> &#8211; lots of competition</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Losing?</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li><strong>Reward cardholders</strong> &#8211; harder to earn points</li>\\n<li><strong>Banks</strong> &#8211; losing interchange fee revenue</li>\\n<li><strong>Everyday cardholders</strong> &#8211; fees may increase</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Smiling young woman holding a credit card and typing on a laptop.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143322/credit-card-consumer.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The question of whether credit card users will ultimately be better or </span><span>worse off from these new interchange fee regulations may ultimately depend on whether they’re using their credit cards as a simple and affordable way to buy now and pay later, or as a means to earn premium rewards. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Consumers with rewards credit cards could be in for a tough time, as from mid-2017, it may be much more difficult and/or expensive to earn a free flight to the Gold Coast simply by regularly spending on your credit card. The forecast reduction in revenue from interchange fees means that banks may need to limit, reduce, or remove some of the extra benefits and services they offer, including credit card rewards. For example, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> recently got rid of high-reward <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> Reward Cards:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Changes to interchange fees are expected to hit credit cards with rewards programs the hardest, and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> credit cards are renowned for their competitive rewards.</p>\\n<p>Some banks issue <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> companion cards with their credit cards, where an Amex is linked to the same account as your Visa or MasterCard, so you can access its reward program. The new caps on interchange fees could lead to many of these Amex companion cards being withdrawn from the market.</p>\\n<p>However, credit cards issued by <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\\\">American Express</a> itself deal directly with the merchant’s bank rather than going through a separate issuing bank, so interchange fees aren&#8217;t involved. You&#8217;ll still need to pay above-average interest rates and fees in some cases, but you&#8217;ll continue to enjoy access to the competitive Amex rewards program.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>For consumers with simpler low-rate credit cards without a rewards program, t</span><span>he new RBA regulations could make flashing the plastic at the checkout a much more viable option, no matter the transaction. </span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\"><img class=\\\"aligncenter size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Bartender receiving credit card of customer for payment in cafe\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328143002/credit-card-merchant.jpeg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p><span>The new caps on interchange fees should help to keep the corresponding merchant service fees relatively low, thus providing merchants the flexibility to offer more competitive pricing and eliminate minimum spend amounts for credit card payments. Credit card surcharges may remain, but a separate set of regulations (<a href=\\\"http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-and-infrastructure/review-of-card-payments-regulation/conclusions-paper-may2016/excessive-surcharging.html\\\">effective September 2016 for large businesses, and September 2017 for small businesses</a>) should limit these to just cover the cost of the merchant service fee.</span></p>\\n<p><span>Another potential outcome of these regulations could end up affecting many credit cardholders. If banks start looking for other ways to raise the revenue they once got from interchange fees, it’s possible that they may start increasing the annual fees, late payment fees, and other charges on credit cards.    </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//TypXILYH3E0\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><span>Because it’s likely that many banks and lenders will make changes to their credit card offers as a result of these regulations, it’s also likely that many consumers may start considering alternative credit card options – the perfect time for smart lenders to unveil competitive new credit card deals. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Currently, there are 180 different <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">credit cards</a> to choose from on the Australian market, including 83 <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/reward-programs\\\">credit cards with rewards programs</a>. If you find yourself in the market for a new or replacement credit card, remember to <a href=\\\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/compare\\\">compare credit cards</a> to find the options that will prove the most suitable for your unique financial situation. </span></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1491228039\",\"dc:creator\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"description\":\"From 1 July 2017, new credit card regulations recommended by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will come into effect, including a cap on interchange fees – the fees that credit card providers charge banks to cover the cost of processing credit card transactions. The credit card market is already being shaken up in anticipation &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Credit card interchange fee changes – winners and losers\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62902\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"true\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328135518/interchange-fee-733x420.jpeg\",\"id\":62902,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62902\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon, 03 Apr 2017 04:00:39 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":5,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"From 1 July 2017, new credit card regulations recommended by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will come into effect, including a cap on interchange fees – the fees that credit card providers charge banks to cover the cost of processing credit card transactions.\",\"slug\":\"credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328135518/interchange-fee-350x476.jpeg\",\"title\":\"Credit card interchange fee changes – winners and losers\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1491228328\",\"url\":\"/credit-cards/news/credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1489019115:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"credit-cards\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>We’ve all felt that rush and sense of achievement when we snag a fantastic retail bargain, but according to experts, around six per cent of the population have a compulsive shopping disorder, or oniomania, and it can have detrimental effects.</p>\\n<p>Financial problems may occur if you start to borrow more than you can afford to pay back. This can lead to growing financial anxiety and stress that impacts all aspects of your life, including your credit history.</p>\\n<p>According to <a href=\\\"https://www.australiacounselling.com.au/addictions/addiction-to-shopping/\\\">Australia Counselling</a>, one of the most detrimental consequences of compulsive shopping is financial strain.</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“People can be carrying huge credit card debt and be struggling to cover the minimum payments… When people are regularly and compulsively shopping to meet psychological and social needs, comparable behavioural patterns and consequences to substance addictions can arise. The person will continue to shop and spend despite negative consequences such as financial strain, interpersonal stress and a sense of spiritual emptiness.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>If the debt collectors are at your door, it’s time to take control of your finances.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Repair your credit score</strong><strong> </strong></h3>\\n<p>One of the main concerns for overspending is how this can impact your credit score.</p>\\n<p>Your credit report can be obtained online at <a href=\\\"http://www.mycreditfile.com.au/\\\">Veda Advantage’s website</a>. A low score will limit your ability to obtain a home loan, credit card, personal loan and many other aspects of your financial life. Lenders review your credit report when deciding whether to approve you for a loan or credit, and approval or rejection will come down to whether you appear to be at risk of not paying back the money you’re borrowing.</p>\\n<p>If your overspending has grown into substantial unpaid debt, and you’re concerned about the damage you’ve done to your credit score, follow RateCity’s <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news/repair-credit-score\\\">guide to repairing your credit score</a>.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Multiple credit cards = multiple debts</strong></h3>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170308124059/iStock-522644470-e1488940869526.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>If you are currently paying off credit card debt, don’t fret, as you are not alone. The Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC)’s <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/credit-cards/credit-card-debt-clock\\\">credit card debt clock</a> monitors and reports how much Australians owe on credit cards based on Reserve Bank of Australia statistics. The number owing (which is in the billions) can fluctuate depending on monthly trends.</p>\\n<p>When you start to use multiple credit cards to fund your shopping addiction, you will begin to grow multiple debts. It can be overwhelming to decide which debt to pay back first, so follow this guide:</p>\\n<p><strong>1. </strong>Contact your credit provider</p>\\n<p>If you are having issues paying back debt, you should contact your credit provider immediately. Your credit provider is required under consumer credit law to consider hardship variations, such as flexible payment arrangements, to assist you in paying back your credit card debt.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Chased by debt collectors?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>This requirement also applies to debt collectors, who will be able to assist you in creating a payment plan.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><strong>2.</strong> Choose the debt to pay first</p>\\n<p>If you’re able to budget an amount to pay your debt, <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/credit-cards/how-to-pay-off-multiple-credit-cards\\\">ASIC recommends</a> the following for choosing which debt to pay first:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>Pay off the credit card with the highest interest rate first &#8211; In addition to making minimum payments on all cards, pay more on the card with the highest interest rate, so you pay off the total amount on that card first. Then work your way through your other cards.</p>\\n<p>Pay off the card with the smallest debt first<strong> &#8211; </strong>Keep making minimum payments on all cards, and pay more on the card with the smallest debt, so you pay off the total amount on that card first. Then work on paying off the next smallest debt, and so on.</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p><strong>3.</strong> Balance Transfer</p>\\n<p>Another option for helping to pay off multiple credit cards is to move your debts to a balance transfer credit card with a lower interest rate. This should alleviate some of the stress of paying back your debt, as they usually offer an interest free period that could range from 5 to 24 months. You’ll want to pay the balance before this period ends to ensure you don’t incur any additional fees or charges.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much could you be saving?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Balance Transfer Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/balance-transfer-calculator?nav=balance-transfer-calculator\\\">Discover Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><strong>4. </strong>Seek financial help</p>\\n<p>If you are still struggling, it is recommended that you seek help from a <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/managing-your-money/managing-debts/financial-counselling\\\">financial counsellor</a>. This is a free service offered to help people struggling to pay back debt by community organisations, community legal centres and government agencies.</p>\\n<p><em>If you believe you or a loved one may be experiencing oniomania (compulsive shopping disorder), or are experiencing any interpersonal stress, depression, anger or anxiety please contact a medical and/or mental health professional immediately</em></p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\",\"category\":[\"bad credit\",\"credit cards\",\"credit score\",\"debt\",\"debt consolidation\",\"debt problem\",\"managing debt\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>We’ve all felt that rush and sense of achievement when we snag a fantastic retail bargain, but according to experts, around six per cent of the population have a compulsive shopping disorder, or oniomania, and it can have detrimental effects.</p>\\n<p>Financial problems may occur if you start to borrow more than you can afford to pay back. This can lead to growing financial anxiety and stress that impacts all aspects of your life, including your credit history.</p>\\n<p>According to <a href=\\\"https://www.australiacounselling.com.au/addictions/addiction-to-shopping/\\\">Australia Counselling</a>, one of the most detrimental consequences of compulsive shopping is financial strain.</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“People can be carrying huge credit card debt and be struggling to cover the minimum payments… When people are regularly and compulsively shopping to meet psychological and social needs, comparable behavioural patterns and consequences to substance addictions can arise. The person will continue to shop and spend despite negative consequences such as financial strain, interpersonal stress and a sense of spiritual emptiness.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>If the debt collectors are at your door, it’s time to take control of your finances.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Repair your credit score</strong><strong> </strong></h3>\\n<p>One of the main concerns for overspending is how this can impact your credit score.</p>\\n<p>Your credit report can be obtained online at <a href=\\\"http://www.mycreditfile.com.au/\\\">Veda Advantage’s website</a>. A low score will limit your ability to obtain a home loan, credit card, personal loan and many other aspects of your financial life. Lenders review your credit report when deciding whether to approve you for a loan or credit, and approval or rejection will come down to whether you appear to be at risk of not paying back the money you’re borrowing.</p>\\n<p>If your overspending has grown into substantial unpaid debt, and you’re concerned about the damage you’ve done to your credit score, follow RateCity’s <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news/repair-credit-score\\\">guide to repairing your credit score</a>.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Multiple credit cards = multiple debts</strong></h3>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170308124059/iStock-522644470-e1488940869526.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>If you are currently paying off credit card debt, don’t fret, as you are not alone. The Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC)’s <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/credit-cards/credit-card-debt-clock\\\">credit card debt clock</a> monitors and reports how much Australians owe on credit cards based on Reserve Bank of Australia statistics. The number owing (which is in the billions) can fluctuate depending on monthly trends.</p>\\n<p>When you start to use multiple credit cards to fund your shopping addiction, you will begin to grow multiple debts. It can be overwhelming to decide which debt to pay back first, so follow this guide:</p>\\n<p><strong>1. </strong>Contact your credit provider</p>\\n<p>If you are having issues paying back debt, you should contact your credit provider immediately. Your credit provider is required under consumer credit law to consider hardship variations, such as flexible payment arrangements, to assist you in paying back your credit card debt.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Chased by debt collectors?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>This requirement also applies to debt collectors, who will be able to assist you in creating a payment plan.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><strong>2.</strong> Choose the debt to pay first</p>\\n<p>If you’re able to budget an amount to pay your debt, <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/credit-cards/how-to-pay-off-multiple-credit-cards\\\">ASIC recommends</a> the following for choosing which debt to pay first:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>Pay off the credit card with the highest interest rate first &#8211; In addition to making minimum payments on all cards, pay more on the card with the highest interest rate, so you pay off the total amount on that card first. Then work your way through your other cards.</p>\\n<p>Pay off the card with the smallest debt first<strong> &#8211; </strong>Keep making minimum payments on all cards, and pay more on the card with the smallest debt, so you pay off the total amount on that card first. Then work on paying off the next smallest debt, and so on.</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p><strong>3.</strong> Balance Transfer</p>\\n<p>Another option for helping to pay off multiple credit cards is to move your debts to a balance transfer credit card with a lower interest rate. This should alleviate some of the stress of paying back your debt, as they usually offer an interest free period that could range from 5 to 24 months. You’ll want to pay the balance before this period ends to ensure you don’t incur any additional fees or charges.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much could you be saving?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Balance Transfer Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/balance-transfer-calculator?nav=balance-transfer-calculator\\\">Discover Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><strong>4. </strong>Seek financial help</p>\\n<p>If you are still struggling, it is recommended that you seek help from a <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/managing-your-money/managing-debts/financial-counselling\\\">financial counsellor</a>. This is a free service offered to help people struggling to pay back debt by community organisations, community legal centres and government agencies.</p>\\n<p><em>If you believe you or a loved one may be experiencing oniomania (compulsive shopping disorder), or are experiencing any interpersonal stress, depression, anger or anxiety please contact a medical and/or mental health professional immediately</em></p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1488976511\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"We’ve all felt that rush and sense of achievement when we snag a fantastic retail bargain, but according to experts, around six per cent of the population have a compulsive shopping disorder, or oniomania, and it can have detrimental effects. Financial problems may occur if you start to borrow more than you can afford to &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/shopping-addiction-wallet/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"What your shopping addiction is doing to your wallet\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62644\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170308123330/iStock-588610878-750x420.jpg\",\"id\":62644,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/shopping-addiction-wallet/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62644\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 08 Mar 2017 02:35:11 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":4,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"shopping-addiction-wallet\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170308123330/iStock-588610878-350x459.jpg\",\"title\":\"What your shopping addiction is doing to your wallet\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1489054576\",\"url\":\"/credit-cards/news/shopping-addiction-wallet\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1488769278:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"credit-cards\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Swiping your credit card to buy that new laptop may have felt great in the moment but your lender doesn’t care that your purchase improved your happiness; they care that you pay your monthly invoices – with interest.</p>\\n<p>Having a bad credit score can sometimes feel like a life sentence. However, there are ways to get your credit score back on track:</p>\\n<h2><strong>Get the most up-to-date version of your score.</strong></h2>\\n<p>Your credit report can be obtained online at <a href=\\\"http://www.mycreditfile.com.au/\\\">Veda Advantage’s website</a>. According to their website, applying for this report is simple and you should not have to pay a third party for a copy;</p>\\n<p>“A credit report and rating can be obtained online at Veda by providing your full name, date of birth, driver’s license number, current and previous address and forms of identification to help them collect your credit history. In most cases, you will be entitled to this report for free.”</p>\\n<p>If you’ve obtained your report and you’re still unsure as to how you could have developed bad credit, read <a href=\\\"https://www.veda.com.au/personal/aricles/what-looks-bad-my-credit-report\\\">Veda’s FAQs</a> about the different things that can look bad on your credit report.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Check for mistakes</strong></h2>\\n<p>It’s not uncommon for credit reports to contain mistakes. One of the most common errors can involve your name being credited with the debt of a family member or stranger with a very similar name to yours.</p>\\n<p>The Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) provides a <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/borrowing-basics/credit-reports#Correct\\\">detailed explanation on how to fix incorrect information</a> on your credit report, and how to contact an Ombudsman if you need help.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Pay off your existing debts</strong></h2>\\n<p>This may seem like an obvious step but it’s very important for getting your credit score in order.</p>\\n<p>If you have multiple sources of debt (personal loan, credit card etc.) you should focus on one debt at a time and budget to pay it off. Once you know how much you owe, you should set money aside to pay one debt off at a time, starting with the debt with the highest interest rate first. If you have any additional cash left over at the end of your pay cycle, put it towards the debt as well.</p>\\n<p>If you have troubles paying your bills on time. you can set up a direct debit with your bank so your credit card and other bills are paid before the due date. Putting your payments on autopilot removes the stress of having to remember multiple debit dates for various bills.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Mobile Banking Apps</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span>Mobile banking apps such as </span><a href=\\\"https://itunes.apple.com/au/app/pocketbook-personal-finance-expense-tracker/id653330894?mt=8\\\">Pocketbook</a><span> also help users to pay off existing debt by detecting regular bill payments, notifying you of upcoming bills and auto-categorising your transactions. Their ‘Safely Spend’ feature helps you limit your weekly or monthly spend, so you can budget without stress.</span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h2><strong>Completely cancel your credit card</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170306124735/iStock-585795908.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>Paid off your outstanding credit card debt but don’t trust yourself to keep using the card? It’s time to give it the chop.</p>\\n<p>While physically cutting your credit card up may be a therapeutic and symbolic way of removing it from your life, you’ll need to close off your account completely to ensure you don’t further damage your credit rating.</p>\\n<p>If you have a rewards card, once you’ve paid the outstanding balance you’ll want to transfer any existing points to your frequent flyer account and/or redeem the reward points. Then you should contact your lender to advise you want to cancel. Your lender may approve your cancellation over the phone by confirming your identity, although some may request a written cancellation request. If they do not take phone cancellations, simply write to your lender advising you want to cancel and close the account, including your credit card number and account details in the letter. You should receive a cancellation confirmation via mail.</p>\\n<p>It is also crucial you cancel all direct debits linked to your credit card as this can reactivate your cancelled card. Once the account is well and truly closed you can destroy your credit card.</p>\\n<p>Would a card with a lower interest rate or higher amount of interest free days would suit you better? <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">Compare different credit card options now</a>.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Add positive information to your credit report</strong></h2>\\n<p>If you’ve read Veda’s FAQ’s regarding <a href=\\\"https://www.veda.com.au/personal/aricles/what-looks-bad-my-credit-report\\\">why you may have a bad credit history</a>, you will know there are various ways you can show creditors you are aren’t a reliable borrower. But did you know there are also ways you can show lenders you are reliable, without paying off debt?</p>\\n<p>Lenders look for stability in your personal and financial life. If you:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>are married;</li>\\n<li>are a homeowner;</li>\\n<li>have lived at the same address for several years, or;</li>\\n<li>have been with the same employer for several years;</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>…these factors all reflect positively on your credit record. If you believe that this information has not been included in your report, you can notify credit reporting agencies to include it.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Interested in lower interest rates?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare Low Rate Credit Cards</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/low-rates?nav=low-rate-credit-cards\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h2><strong>Stay on course!</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170306125720/iStock-481194832-e1488769069484.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>You’ve paid off your debt and you’ve cancelled those tempting credit card accounts – congratulations! Moving forward, make sure you maintain the good habits you’ve developed while repairing your credit history. Keep track of your transactions, budget and save effectively, auto-pay your bills and try to show lenders you have a stable financial and personal life.</p>\",\"category\":[\"bad credit\",\"credit cards\",\"credit score\",\"loan\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Swiping your credit card to buy that new laptop may have felt great in the moment but your lender doesn’t care that your purchase improved your happiness; they care that you pay your monthly invoices – with interest.</p>\\n<p>Having a bad credit score can sometimes feel like a life sentence. However, there are ways to get your credit score back on track:</p>\\n<h2><strong>Get the most up-to-date version of your score.</strong></h2>\\n<p>Your credit report can be obtained online at <a href=\\\"http://www.mycreditfile.com.au/\\\">Veda Advantage’s website</a>. According to their website, applying for this report is simple and you should not have to pay a third party for a copy;</p>\\n<p>“A credit report and rating can be obtained online at Veda by providing your full name, date of birth, driver’s license number, current and previous address and forms of identification to help them collect your credit history. In most cases, you will be entitled to this report for free.”</p>\\n<p>If you’ve obtained your report and you’re still unsure as to how you could have developed bad credit, read <a href=\\\"https://www.veda.com.au/personal/aricles/what-looks-bad-my-credit-report\\\">Veda’s FAQs</a> about the different things that can look bad on your credit report.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Check for mistakes</strong></h2>\\n<p>It’s not uncommon for credit reports to contain mistakes. One of the most common errors can involve your name being credited with the debt of a family member or stranger with a very similar name to yours.</p>\\n<p>The Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) provides a <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/borrowing-basics/credit-reports#Correct\\\">detailed explanation on how to fix incorrect information</a> on your credit report, and how to contact an Ombudsman if you need help.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Pay off your existing debts</strong></h2>\\n<p>This may seem like an obvious step but it’s very important for getting your credit score in order.</p>\\n<p>If you have multiple sources of debt (personal loan, credit card etc.) you should focus on one debt at a time and budget to pay it off. Once you know how much you owe, you should set money aside to pay one debt off at a time, starting with the debt with the highest interest rate first. If you have any additional cash left over at the end of your pay cycle, put it towards the debt as well.</p>\\n<p>If you have troubles paying your bills on time. you can set up a direct debit with your bank so your credit card and other bills are paid before the due date. Putting your payments on autopilot removes the stress of having to remember multiple debit dates for various bills.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Mobile Banking Apps</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span>Mobile banking apps such as </span><a href=\\\"https://itunes.apple.com/au/app/pocketbook-personal-finance-expense-tracker/id653330894?mt=8\\\">Pocketbook</a><span> also help users to pay off existing debt by detecting regular bill payments, notifying you of upcoming bills and auto-categorising your transactions. Their ‘Safely Spend’ feature helps you limit your weekly or monthly spend, so you can budget without stress.</span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h2><strong>Completely cancel your credit card</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170306124735/iStock-585795908.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>Paid off your outstanding credit card debt but don’t trust yourself to keep using the card? It’s time to give it the chop.</p>\\n<p>While physically cutting your credit card up may be a therapeutic and symbolic way of removing it from your life, you’ll need to close off your account completely to ensure you don’t further damage your credit rating.</p>\\n<p>If you have a rewards card, once you’ve paid the outstanding balance you’ll want to transfer any existing points to your frequent flyer account and/or redeem the reward points. Then you should contact your lender to advise you want to cancel. Your lender may approve your cancellation over the phone by confirming your identity, although some may request a written cancellation request. If they do not take phone cancellations, simply write to your lender advising you want to cancel and close the account, including your credit card number and account details in the letter. You should receive a cancellation confirmation via mail.</p>\\n<p>It is also crucial you cancel all direct debits linked to your credit card as this can reactivate your cancelled card. Once the account is well and truly closed you can destroy your credit card.</p>\\n<p>Would a card with a lower interest rate or higher amount of interest free days would suit you better? <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards\\\">Compare different credit card options now</a>.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Add positive information to your credit report</strong></h2>\\n<p>If you’ve read Veda’s FAQ’s regarding <a href=\\\"https://www.veda.com.au/personal/aricles/what-looks-bad-my-credit-report\\\">why you may have a bad credit history</a>, you will know there are various ways you can show creditors you are aren’t a reliable borrower. But did you know there are also ways you can show lenders you are reliable, without paying off debt?</p>\\n<p>Lenders look for stability in your personal and financial life. If you:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>are married;</li>\\n<li>are a homeowner;</li>\\n<li>have lived at the same address for several years, or;</li>\\n<li>have been with the same employer for several years;</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>…these factors all reflect positively on your credit record. Keep track of your transactions, budget and save effectively, auto-pay your bills and try to show lenders you have a stable financial and personal life.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1488804817\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Swiping your credit card to buy that new laptop may have felt great in the moment but your lender doesn’t care that your purchase improved your happiness; they care that you pay your monthly invoices – with interest. The truth is that most of us don’t have the time or the patience, but this laziness means you could be losing money in unnecessary debits.</p>\\n<p>Some of the biggest culprits are fees. No, not just those pesky ATM fees we know are sometimes an unavoidable evil, but all the different fees that can add up across your loans and bank accounts.</p>\\n<p>RateCity has compiled a list of the most common types of fees and the average amount you could be being charged without realising it.</p>\\n<h2><strong>Home Loan Fees</strong></h2>\\n<p>Most people will be aware of the different types of fees you can be charged with a home loan. However, a lot of these can be avoided as there are products available that do not charge a variety of fees.</p>\\n<p>RateCity has found the following information about the different types of fees for currently available home loans:</p>\\n<p>Discharge Fees:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li style=\\\"text-align: left;\\\">4518 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li style=\\\"text-align: left;\\\">Average fee cost is $289.36</li>\\n<li style=\\\"text-align: left;\\\">69 per cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Valuation Fees:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>940 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li>Average fee cost is $230.39</li>\\n<li>90 per cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Annual Fees:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>2885 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li>Average fee cost is $258.60</li>\\n<li>26 per cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Total Upfront Fees:</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>3131 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li>Average fee cost is $509.76</li>\\n<li>74 per cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>While avoiding every single fee may not be possible, if you take the time to research different home loans you can avoid costly payments. For example, choosing a home loan that offers no annual fee can save on average $7,758 over thirty years.<br /> <em></em></p>\\n<p>Check out RateCity’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/compare\\\">home loan comparison</a> table which helps you to compare products via fees. For example:</p>\\n<h4>Top home loans with zero estimated up front fees</h4>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_upfront_fee=0&h_sort_field=upfront_fee\\\"></div>\\n<h2>Car Loan Fees</h2>\\n<p><strong> </strong>Another way you could be losing money through laziness is by not examining the fees charged in a car loan. RateCity has found the following information about the different types of fees for currently available car loans:</p>\\n<p>Application fee</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>216 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li>Average fee cost is $200.46</li>\\n<li>47 per cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Missed penalty fee</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>164 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li>Average fee cost is $20.15</li>\\n<li>51 per cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Ongoing annual fee</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>79 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li>Average fee cost is $97.06</li>\\n<li>53 per cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Car loans that don&#8217;t charge you loan fees?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span>One example of a car loan that doesn’t charge you loan fees is the </span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/cua/discount-personal-loan-fixed\\\">CUA Discount Personal Loan Fixed</a><span>. As this type of fee is a lot less common, it would be reasonable to look elsewhere if your savings account charges you monthly.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to See how your savings account compares?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Top Savings Accounts</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/compare?nav=compare-savings-accounts\\\">Look Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"car loan\",\"car loans\",\"car loans australia\",\"Fees\",\"home loan\",\"personal loan\",\"saving\",\"savings accounts\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>When was the last time you went through all your transactions with a fine-tooth comb? cent of products available have ZERO fees</li>\\n</ul>\\n<p>Missed penalty fee</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li>228 loans available with this fee</li>\\n<li>Average fee cost is $20.57</li>\\n<li>13 per cent of fees. For example:</p>\\n<h4>Top personal loans with zero ongoing fees</h4>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/personal-loans/rate-table?pl_per_page=4&pl_showAll=true&ab_test_id=0.12&ongoingFeesFrequency=Monthly\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<h2><strong>Savings Account Fees</strong></h2>\\n<p>Another place you may be losing money without realising it is through monthly account keeping fees for your savings accounts.</p>\\n<p>The percentage of products with zero fees is around 99.9%, however there are some savings accounts available that do charge you monthly fees at an average of $4.85. As this type of fee is a lot less common, it would be reasonable to look elsewhere if your savings account charges you monthly.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to See how your savings account compares?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Top Savings Accounts</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/compare?nav=compare-savings-accounts\\\">Look Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1488458664\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"When was the last time you went through all your transactions with a fine-tooth comb? The truth is that most of us don’t have the time or the patience, but this laziness means you could be losing money in unnecessary debits. Some of the biggest culprits are fees. As you get older, it’s wise to consider all your options before deciding which one is right for you.</p>\\n<p>If you already have a debit card, picking a credit card should be simple, right? You do not necessarily need to use one that your main lender provides. In fact, it’s a good idea to shop around for a more competitive option.</p>\\n<p>It’s important to consider what exactly you need your first credit card for. If you can identify some key criteria your card must have, it’ll be a lot easier to choose between the many different types available.</p>\\n<h2><strong>I want a new wardrobe/phone/laptop etc.</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170228142621/iStock-535448086-e1488256047764.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>Is there something you’ve been dreaming of and can’t wait any longer to have? Credit cards provide users with the ability to borrow and spend up to their maximum credit limit, which varies from card to card.</p>\\n<p>If you sometimes have trouble paying invoices on time, particularly for your first credit card, you’ll want to look for a credit card with a lower than average purchase interest rate (less than 18 per cent). The last thing you want to do is start to adversely impact your credit history.</p>\\n<p>You’ll also want to ensure you have the highest possible amount of interest free days (with the maximum being up to 55). It will also be beneficial to find a card with a high number of interest free days so you have time to pay your monthly invoices without incurring interest or late payment fees.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to compare Rates?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Low Rate Credit Cards</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/low-rates?nav=low-rate-credit-cards\\\">Compare Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h2><strong> </strong><strong>I want perks and rewards</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170228142618/iStock-505526508-e1488256034104.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>Are you a big spender? Are you in a couple or large family and will have multiple card users? There are credit cards which will reward you for making transactions instead of using cash or your debit card through rewards programs. Depending on the rewards program, you could earn up to three points per dollar spent.</p>\\n<p>You could also earn bonus points for shopping at certain stores. The more you spend, the more you will earn. However, reward credit cards tend to have higher interest rates than standard cards, so these will benefit users who pay off their debt each month.</p>\\n<h2><strong>I want to travel</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170228142619/iStock-583724424-e1488256006381.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>If you’re planning an overseas trip, choosing the right credit card can make a world of difference for avoiding overseas fees and charges. There are a multitude of different cards available and each will have different pros and cons depending on your criteria.</p>\\n<p>If you’re looking for complimentary perks, many credit cards offer travel insurance and a 24/7 concierge service as a part of their perks and reward programs. Your chosen lender will usually have a partnership with an insurance provider, and this can come in handy in case of any emergencies.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Frequent Flyer Perks?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span style=\\\"background-color: #ffffff;\\\"><span>You can also choose credit cards which let you earn frequent flyer points for every dollar you spend. For example, the </span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/american-express/explorer-credit-card\\\">American Express explorer credit card</a><span> offers users 1.5 frequent flyer points per dollar spent, and it partners with Virgin Australia, Air New Zealand and Emirates.</span></span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>For a list of RateCity’s top travel cards for 2017, please <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news/top-travel-cards-2017\\\">read more here</a>.</p>\",\"category\":[\"credit cards\",\"frequent flyer rewards\",\"overseas spending\",\"rewards\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>When you’re younger, financial decisions like credit cards are a far away concern. Credit cards provide users with the ability to borrow and spend up to their maximum credit limit, which varies from card to card.</p>\\n<p>If you sometimes have trouble paying invoices on time, particularly for your first credit card, you’ll want to look for a credit card with a lower than average purchase interest rate (less than 18 per cent).
