There are credit cards which will reward you for making transactions instead of using cash or your debit card through rewards programs. Depending on the rewards program, you could earn up to three points per dollar spent.</p>\\n<p>You could also earn bonus points for shopping at certain stores. The more you spend, the more you will earn. However, reward credit cards tend to have higher interest rates than standard cards, so these will benefit users who pay off their debt each month.</p>\\n<h2><strong>I want to travel</strong></h2>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170228142619/iStock-583724424-e1488256006381.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>If you’re planning an overseas trip, choosing the right credit card can make a world of difference for avoiding overseas fees and charges. There are a multitude of different cards available and each will have different pros and cons depending on your criteria.</p>\\n<p>If you’re looking for complimentary perks, many credit cards offer travel insurance and a 24/7 concierge service as a part of their perks and reward programs. Your chosen lender will usually have a partnership with an insurance provider, and this can come in handy in case of any emergencies.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Frequent Flyer Perks?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span style=\\\"background-color: #ffffff;\\\"><span>You can also choose credit cards which let you earn frequent flyer points for every dollar you spend. For example, the </span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/american-express/explorer-credit-card\\\">American Express explorer credit card</a><span> offers users 1.5 frequent flyer points per dollar spent, and it partners with Virgin Australia, Air New Zealand and Emirates.</span></span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>For a list of RateCity’s top travel cards for 2017, please <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news/top-travel-cards-2017\\\">read more here</a>.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1488292673\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"When you’re younger, financial decisions like credit cards are a far away concern. As you get older, it’s wise to consider all your options before deciding which one is right for you. If you already have a debit card, picking a credit card should be simple, right? You do not necessarily need to use one &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/pick-first-credit-card/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"How to pick your first credit card\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62482\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170228142620/iStock-497840054-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62482,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/pick-first-credit-card/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62482\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, 28 Feb 2017 04:37:53 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"pick-first-credit-card\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170228142620/iStock-497840054-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"How to pick your first credit card\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1488292791\",\"url\":\"/credit-cards/news/pick-first-credit-card\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"39\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1486420220:39\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"credit-cards\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p><span>Three of the most popular methods for borrowing a bit of extra cash are credit cards, personal loans and payday loans. Each of these loan types have their share of benefits and drawbacks, making them better suited to different financial circumstances. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Before you sign on any dotted lines, it’s worth getting an idea of what benefits each type of loan can offer, and finding out if there are any pitfalls worth keeping an eye out for:</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><span>Credit Cards</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li>Useful for small or large borrowing</li>\\n<li>Flexible repayments</li>\\n<li>Option to earn benefits and rewards</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li>Interest and fees can build up</li>\\n<li>Less ideal for very large expenses</li>\\n<li>Temptation to borrow more</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter wp-image-61663 size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Young woman on the beach phoning the bank for credit card support\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What makes credit cards useful?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>A credit card effectively functions as a flexible loan, allowing you to borrow money from a lender up to a predetermined limit. If you keep up to date with your repayments, you’ll always have the option to flash your fantastic piece of plastic to make payments in shops, over the phone, or online, even for international purchases and services. </span></p>\\n<p><span>It&#8217;s also possible to use a credit card to get cash advances from the bank, a bit like withdrawing money from your bank account via an ATM, though there are often extra costs involved.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//pLnseKtcNvg\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p>Depending on your credit card provider, you may also be eligible to earn additional rewards and benefits by using your credit card, such as free travel insurance, or bonus points that can be redeemed at selected retailers.</p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>How can you apply for a credit card?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Many lenders offer credit cards, ranging from major banks to independent credit providers. To apply, you’ll need some identification and evidence of income, to prove that you’ll be able to pay back any money you borrow from the lender. Your lender will also check our credit history, to determine the level of risk involved in lending to you.</span></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the costs of a credit card?</span></h4>\\n<p><span><span>Many lenders charge annual fees on their credit cards, as well as interest. </span></span><span>Interest rates for credit cards tend to be on the high side, though depending on how you use your card, you may not always be charged for interest. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Many credit cards come with a monthly interest-free period on purchases. If you make a purchase on your credit card as long as you repay this amount before the month&#8217;s interest-free period ends, you won’t be charged interest on the purchase. But if an amount is left outstanding, interest will be charged on this remainder, and you&#8217;ll lose the interest-free benefit for the next month until the card is full paid off.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">EXAMPLE:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Vlad has a credit card with a 45 day interest free period and a monthly billing cycle. He uses it to buy a new smartphone on the 1st of January. He has until the 14th of February (45 days from 1 Jan) to pay back the lender for his phone, or he&#8217;ll be charged interest on what he owes for January and lose the interest-free period for February.</p>\\n<p>Towards the end of January, Vlad want to replace his washing machine. He could use his credit card to buy a new one on the 31st of January, the last day of his billing cycle. However, because the interest-free period is calculated from the START of the billing cycle (e.g. 45 days from 1 Jan), he&#8217;ll need to pay back the value of his new washer to his lender by 14 Feb, just like his new smartphone, if he wants to avoid being charged interest on both his January and February purchases.</p>\\n<p>Vlad delays his washing machine purchase until 1 Feb, giving him until 17 March (45 days from the start of the new credit card billing cycle) to make his repayments and avoid interest charges.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">The latest credit cards news and tips</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Credit Card News</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the risks of a credit card?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Unlike many other types of loan, where you borrow a set amount of money then make steady progress towards getting this amount paid back plus interest by a certain date, credit cards tend to be a lot more flexible, which can be a problem as well as a benefit. </span></p>\\n<p><span>While you&#8217;re encouraged to fully repay your credit card each month, many lenders typically only require that you make a minimum repayment for a small percentage (often just 2%) of the outstanding balance you owe, plus interest charges. If you only make these minimum repayments, you’ll VERY slowly make progress towards clearing your debt, but you’ll likely end up paying a LOT of extra interest charges to your lender. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Also, because a credit card effectively functions as an open-ended loan, even if you’re already struggling to manage your repayments, you may still be tempted to borrow even more money. This could lead to you losing  and previous progress made towards repaying your loan, and getting you closer to being trapped in a cycle of inescapable debt. </span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><span>Personal Loans</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li>Good for making large purchases</li>\\n<li>Can consolidate other debt</li>\\n<li>Fixed borrowing keeps repayments manageable</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li>Less flexible, fewer options</li>\\n<li>Risk of losing security</li>\\n<li>Extra fees could apply</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-61742\\\" alt=\\\"personal-car-loan-application-compressor\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor.jpeg\\\" srcset=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor.jpeg 620w, http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor-300x155.jpeg 300w\\\" sizes=\\\"(max-width: 709px) 85vw, (max-width: 909px) 67vw, (max-width: 984px) 61vw, (max-width: 1362px) 45vw, 600px\\\" /></a></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What makes personal loans useful?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Personal loans are structured differently to credit cards or lines of credit. Rather than offering the flexibility to borrow any amount of money up to a fixed limit, and to then repay what you borrow as you go, personal loans involve borrowing a fixed sum of money that you receive from the lender up front, then making regular repayments over a set term to make sure that this amount ens up fully paid back to your lender, plus interest, on time. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>This makes personal loans more useful for making large single purchases, such as buying a car, starting up a business, or paying for a dream wedding. They can also be used to consolidate multiple smaller debts (e.g. credit cards, payday loans) into a single, easy to manage loan, so you’ll only need to make the one repayment per month, and only be charged interest the once per month. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Because you can’t typically borrow more money and increase your level of debt with a personal loan, you should be able to make steady progress towards paying back what you owe, with less risk of ending up trapped in a bad financial position. </span></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>How to apply for a personal loan</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Personal loans are available from a selection of banks and non-bank lenders, including some lenders that specialise in providing personal loans for borrowers with special needs, such as nonconforming personal loans for borrowers with bad credit. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Much like applying for a credit card, when you apply for a personal loan you’ll need to provide your personal details, plus evidence that you’ll be able to manage your loan repayments. Your lender will also check your credit history to determine the risk of lending to you.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Depending on the type of personal loan you apply for, you may also need to provide security to guarantee the sum you’re borrowing. For example, many car loans are guaranteed by the value of the car you’re buying, so if you don’t make your repayments, your vehicle will be repossessed and sold by the lender to cover its losses.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/personal-loans/rate-table?pl_per_page=4&ab_test_id=0.72\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the costs of a personal loan?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Personal loans typically involve paying interest on the money you borrow, either at a fixed or variable rate. Fixed rates guarantee consistent repayments for the full term of the loan, for simpler budgeting, while variable rate loans usually offer greater flexibility, and may let you enjoy reduced repayments if your lender cuts its rates.  You may also need to pay establishment and/or ongoing fees on your personal loan. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The length of your personal loan term will make an impact on how much it will ultimately cost you in terms of interest and possibly fees. The shorter your loan term, the more expensive your <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> will be, though you’ll pay less in interest and ultimately pay off your loan sooner. A longer loan term can make your <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">monthly repayments</a> more affordable, though the total interest and fees you’ll have paid by the end of your loan may be significantly higher. Some personal loans (often those with variable interest rates) include flexible features such as offset accounts and redraw facilities that provide extra options for managing your loan repayments, which may help you to reduce some of your interest costs in the right circumstances.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Calculate your personal loan and repayments</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Personal Loan Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/calculator\\\">Try It</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the risks of a personal loan?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Because personal loans need to be organised in advance, it’s usually straightforward for borrowers to work out whether they can afford the repayments before they sign on the dotted line. </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//MJQe4TfnddM\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><span></span><span>If your personal loan has a variable interest rate, there is a risk that the rate could rise, making your loan repayments more expensive. In such a case, you may need to consider the options for refinancing your personal loan, whether with your current lender or a different one. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The greatest risk to keep in mind when you take out a personal loan is being stung with surprise fees, which (depending on your lender) may be charged if you choose to exercise some of your loan’s optional features. You may also be charged penalty fees if you make extra repayments or complete your loan early, to make up for the interest charges the lender will miss out on. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Also, if you opt for a secured personal loan and don’t keep up with your repayments, you may risk losing your security asset, whether that’s your car, your property, or even just a bank deposit. </span></p>\\n<h3><span>Payday Loans</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li>Fast cash in a pinch</li>\\n<li>Handy for small purchases</li>\\n<li>Simple to apply for</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li>Interest + fees add up quickly</li>\\n<li>Temptation to borrow more</li>\\n<li>Tough penalties for defaults</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-61743\\\" alt=\\\"payday-loans-compressor\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor.jpeg\\\" srcset=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor.jpeg 620w, http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor-300x155.jpeg 300w\\\" sizes=\\\"(max-width: 709px) 85vw, (max-width: 909px) 67vw, (max-width: 984px) 61vw, (max-width: 1362px) 45vw, 600px\\\" /></a></p>\\n<h4>Why are payday loans useful?</h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>The typical example scenario for a payday loan goes something like this:</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">EXAMPLE:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Janice&#8217;s family fridge has broken down, right in the middle of a summer heatwave. She needs a new replacement right now, but all the money from her last payday has already been accounted for, covering bills and life&#8217;s other expenses. She’d easily be able to afford a replacement in a month’s time, but that’s not going to save the rapidly-defrosting food she needs to feed her family right now!</p>\\n<p>By approaching a payday lender, Janice can get a small loan approved in a matter of minutes, allowing her to pick up a new fridge that very day and rescue her melting ice cream. When Janice&#8217;s next payday arrives, she can pay back the loan, plus any fees and charges, and get on with her life.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>How to apply for a payday loan:</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Most payday lenders can be quickly contacted by phone or online to make an application. This application is usually faster and less involved than the process of applying for a credit card or a personal loan, though you’ll still need to provide your personal details and some evidence of income to show that you’ll be able to afford to pay the lender back. </span></p>\\n<p>Your payday lender will then confirm your details and perform a credit check. Payday lenders tend to be more flexible around bad credit than many larger lending organisations, but if your credit history clearly shows major financial problems, your application may be declined. </p>\\n<p><span></span>Once<span> your payday loan application has been approved, you’ll often be able to receive your funds very quickly, sometimes literally within a matter of minutes. </span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Are there alternatives to payday loans?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Can I get a personal loan if I receive Centrelink payments?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/can-i-get-a-personal-loan-if-i-receive-centrelink-payments\\\">Find Out</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the costs of payday loans?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Unlike credit cards and personal loans, payday loans don&#8217;t charge interest on the amount you borrow &#8211; only fees. However, these fees are usually listed in percentages, based on the amount you owe, similar to interest rates. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span></span><span>Current Australian government legislation requires that establishment fees charged at the start of a payday loan can only total up to 20% of the loan principal (e.g. for a $600 loan, there can be a maximum establishment fee of $120). On top of this, the monthly ongoing fees can only total a maximum of 4% (e.g. for a $600 loan, the ongoing fee can be a maximum of $24 per month). Payday loans tend to have fairly short terms, often ranging from as little as 2 weeks to as much as 12 months.</span></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the risks of payday loans?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Payday loans provide fast and simple access to money, which can prove very tempting to people who are already experiencing financial stress, and are thus the most vulnerable to extra costs, fees and charges. </span><span>Even if you only borrow a small amount of money from a payday lender, if your finances are already tight, there’s a big risk of ending up in more debt that you can realistically handle if you’re not careful, or if you experience some bad luck (e.g. having to pay for car repairs after you&#8217;ve already taken out a loan for your new fridge). It just takes one missed repayment to find yourself slapped with steep penalty fees, which can quickly add up, leaving you in real financial trouble.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Get some help</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">MoneySmart Payday loan calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/tools-and-resources/calculators-and-apps/payday-loan-calculator\\\">Try It</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span></span><span></span><span>The best precaution when thinking about payday loans is to take some extra time to look carefully at all the terms and conditions involved, work out a budget to see if you’ll be able to realistically afford the extra fees and charges, and decide whether you think these extra costs will be worth it. Taking this extra time to consider your options may mean you won&#8217;t get your hands on that money quite as fast as simply applying for a payday loan, but avoiding the extra risk of ending up with problem debt is often worth it. </span></p>\\n<p>Also, try to avoid using payday loans as a &#8220;stopgap&#8221; solution for managing repayments on larger debts, such as overdue credit cards or personal loans. Borrowing more money could allow you to avoid a late repayment now, but won&#8217;t fix the root problem, and could leave you in even more debt trouble further down the line.</p>\\n<p>If you ever find yourself struggling with any loan repayments, contact your lender to find out your available options. Alternatively, <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/managing-your-money/managing-debts/financial-counselling\\\">contact MoneySmart</a> for free financial counselling, or call Australia&#8217;s <strong>National Debt Helpline on 1800 007 007</strong>.</p>\",\"category\":[\"comparison\",\"credit cards\",\"debt\",\"debt problem\",\"interest\",\"payday loans\",\"personal finance\",\"personal-loans\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p><span>Three of the most popular methods for borrowing a bit of extra cash are credit cards, personal loans and payday loans. Each of these loan types have their share of benefits and drawbacks, making them better suited to different financial circumstances. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Before you sign on any dotted lines, it’s worth getting an idea of what benefits each type of loan can offer, and finding out if there are any pitfalls worth keeping an eye out for:</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><span>Credit Cards</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li>Useful for small or large borrowing</li>\\n<li>Flexible repayments</li>\\n<li>Option to earn benefits and rewards</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li>Interest and fees can build up</li>\\n<li>Less ideal for very large expenses</li>\\n<li>Temptation to borrow more</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter wp-image-61663 size-full\\\" alt=\\\"Young woman on the beach phoning the bank for credit card support\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What makes credit cards useful?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>A credit card effectively functions as a flexible loan, allowing you to borrow money from a lender up to a predetermined limit. If you keep up to date with your repayments, you’ll always have the option to flash your fantastic piece of plastic to make payments in shops, over the phone, or online, even for international purchases and services. </span></p>\\n<p><span>It&#8217;s also possible to use a credit card to get cash advances from the bank, a bit like withdrawing money from your bank account via an ATM, though there are often extra costs involved.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//pLnseKtcNvg\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p>Depending on your credit card provider, you may also be eligible to earn additional rewards and benefits by using your credit card, such as free travel insurance, or bonus points that can be redeemed at selected retailers.</p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>How can you apply for a credit card?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Many lenders offer credit cards, ranging from major banks to independent credit providers. To apply, you’ll need some identification and evidence of income, to prove that you’ll be able to pay back any money you borrow from the lender. Your lender will also check our credit history, to determine the level of risk involved in lending to you.</span></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the costs of a credit card?</span></h4>\\n<p><span><span>Many lenders charge annual fees on their credit cards, as well as interest. </span></span><span>Interest rates for credit cards tend to be on the high side, though depending on how you use your card, you may not always be charged for interest. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Many credit cards come with a monthly interest-free period on purchases. If you make a purchase on your credit card as long as you repay this amount before the month&#8217;s interest-free period ends, you won’t be charged interest on the purchase. But if an amount is left outstanding, interest will be charged on this remainder, and you&#8217;ll lose the interest-free benefit for the next month until the card is full paid off.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">EXAMPLE:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Vlad has a credit card with a 45 day interest free period and a monthly billing cycle. He uses it to buy a new smartphone on the 1st of January. He has until the 14th of February (45 days from 1 Jan) to pay back the lender for his phone, or he&#8217;ll be charged interest on what he owes for January and lose the interest-free period for February.</p>\\n<p>Towards the end of January, Vlad want to replace his washing machine. He could use his credit card to buy a new one on the 31st of January, the last day of his billing cycle. However, because the interest-free period is calculated from the START of the billing cycle (e.g. 45 days from 1 Jan), he&#8217;ll need to pay back the value of his new washer to his lender by 14 Feb, just like his new smartphone, if he wants to avoid being charged interest on both his January and February purchases.</p>\\n<p>Vlad delays his washing machine purchase until 1 Feb, giving him until 17 March (45 days from the start of the new credit card billing cycle) to make his repayments and avoid interest charges.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">The latest credit cards news and tips</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Credit Card News</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the risks of a credit card?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Unlike many other types of loan, where you borrow a set amount of money then make steady progress towards getting this amount paid back plus interest by a certain date, credit cards tend to be a lot more flexible, which can be a problem as well as a benefit. </span></p>\\n<p><span>While you&#8217;re encouraged to fully repay your credit card each month, many lenders typically only require that you make a minimum repayment for a small percentage (often just 2%) of the outstanding balance you owe, plus interest charges. If you only make these minimum repayments, you’ll VERY slowly make progress towards clearing your debt, but you’ll likely end up paying a LOT of extra interest charges to your lender. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Also, because a credit card effectively functions as an open-ended loan, even if you’re already struggling to manage your repayments, you may still be tempted to borrow even more money. This could lead to you losing  and previous progress made towards repaying your loan, and getting you closer to being trapped in a cycle of inescapable debt. </span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><span>Personal Loans</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li>Good for making large purchases</li>\\n<li>Can consolidate other debt</li>\\n<li>Fixed borrowing keeps repayments manageable</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li>Less flexible, fewer options</li>\\n<li>Risk of losing security</li>\\n<li>Extra fees could apply</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-61742\\\" alt=\\\"personal-car-loan-application-compressor\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor.jpeg\\\" srcset=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor.jpeg 620w, http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123124626/personal-car-loan-application-compressor-300x155.jpeg 300w\\\" sizes=\\\"(max-width: 709px) 85vw, (max-width: 909px) 67vw, (max-width: 984px) 61vw, (max-width: 1362px) 45vw, 600px\\\" /></a></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What makes personal loans useful?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Personal loans are structured differently to credit cards or lines of credit. Rather than offering the flexibility to borrow any amount of money up to a fixed limit, and to then repay what you borrow as you go, personal loans involve borrowing a fixed sum of money that you receive from the lender up front, then making regular repayments over a set term to make sure that this amount ens up fully paid back to your lender, plus interest, on time. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>This makes personal loans more useful for making large single purchases, such as buying a car, starting up a business, or paying for a dream wedding. They can also be used to consolidate multiple smaller debts (e.g. credit cards, payday loans) into a single, easy to manage loan, so you’ll only need to make the one repayment per month, and only be charged interest the once per month. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Because you can’t typically borrow more money and increase your level of debt with a personal loan, you should be able to make steady progress towards paying back what you owe, with less risk of ending up trapped in a bad financial position. </span></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>How to apply for a personal loan</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Personal loans are available from a selection of banks and non-bank lenders, including some lenders that specialise in providing personal loans for borrowers with special needs, such as nonconforming personal loans for borrowers with bad credit. </span></p>\\n<p><span>Much like applying for a credit card, when you apply for a personal loan you’ll need to provide your personal details, plus evidence that you’ll be able to manage your loan repayments. Your lender will also check your credit history to determine the risk of lending to you.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Depending on the type of personal loan you apply for, you may also need to provide security to guarantee the sum you’re borrowing. For example, many car loans are guaranteed by the value of the car you’re buying, so if you don’t make your repayments, your vehicle will be repossessed and sold by the lender to cover its losses.</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/personal-loans/rate-table?pl_per_page=4&ab_test_id=0.72\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the costs of a personal loan?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Personal loans typically involve paying interest on the money you borrow, either at a fixed or variable rate. Fixed rates guarantee consistent repayments for the full term of the loan, for simpler budgeting, while variable rate loans usually offer greater flexibility, and may let you enjoy reduced repayments if your lender cuts its rates.  You may also need to pay establishment and/or ongoing fees on your personal loan. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The length of your personal loan term will make an impact on how much it will ultimately cost you in terms of interest and possibly fees. The shorter your loan term, the more expensive your <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> will be, though you’ll pay less in interest and ultimately pay off your loan sooner. A longer loan term can make your <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">monthly repayments</a> more affordable, though the total interest and fees you’ll have paid by the end of your loan may be significantly higher. Some personal loans (often those with variable interest rates) include flexible features such as offset accounts and redraw facilities that provide extra options for managing your loan repayments, which may help you to reduce some of your interest costs in the right circumstances.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Calculate your personal loan and repayments</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Personal Loan Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/calculator\\\">Try It</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the risks of a personal loan?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Because personal loans need to be organised in advance, it’s usually straightforward for borrowers to work out whether they can afford the repayments before they sign on the dotted line. </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//MJQe4TfnddM\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><span></span><span>If your personal loan has a variable interest rate, there is a risk that the rate could rise, making your loan repayments more expensive. In such a case, you may need to consider the options for refinancing your personal loan, whether with your current lender or a different one. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>The greatest risk to keep in mind when you take out a personal loan is being stung with surprise fees, which (depending on your lender) may be charged if you choose to exercise some of your loan’s optional features. You may also be charged penalty fees if you make extra repayments or complete your loan early, to make up for the interest charges the lender will miss out on. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Also, if you opt for a secured personal loan and don’t keep up with your repayments, you may risk losing your security asset, whether that’s your car, your property, or even just a bank deposit. </span></p>\\n<h3><span>Payday Loans</span></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li>Fast cash in a pinch</li>\\n<li>Handy for small purchases</li>\\n<li>Simple to apply for</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li>Interest + fees add up quickly</li>\\n<li>Temptation to borrow more</li>\\n<li>Tough penalties for defaults</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor.jpeg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-61743\\\" alt=\\\"payday-loans-compressor\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor.jpeg\\\" srcset=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor.jpeg 620w, http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123125217/payday-loans-compressor-300x155.jpeg 300w\\\" sizes=\\\"(max-width: 709px) 85vw, (max-width: 909px) 67vw, (max-width: 984px) 61vw, (max-width: 1362px) 45vw, 600px\\\" /></a></p>\\n<h4>Why are payday loans useful?</h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>The typical example scenario for a payday loan goes something like this:</span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">EXAMPLE:</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Janice&#8217;s family fridge has broken down, right in the middle of a summer heatwave. She needs a new replacement right now, but all the money from her last payday has already been accounted for, covering bills and life&#8217;s other expenses. She’d easily be able to afford a replacement in a month’s time, but that’s not going to save the rapidly-defrosting food she needs to feed her family right now!</p>\\n<p>By approaching a payday lender, Janice can get a small loan approved in a matter of minutes, allowing her to pick up a new fridge that very day and rescue her melting ice cream. When Janice&#8217;s next payday arrives, she can pay back the loan, plus any fees and charges, and get on with her life.</p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>How to apply for a payday loan:</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Most payday lenders can be quickly contacted by phone or online to make an application. This application is usually faster and less involved than the process of applying for a credit card or a personal loan, though you’ll still need to provide your personal details and some evidence of income to show that you’ll be able to afford to pay the lender back. </span></p>\\n<p>Your payday lender will then confirm your details and perform a credit check. Payday lenders tend to be more flexible around bad credit than many larger lending organisations, but if your credit history clearly shows major financial problems, your application may be declined. </p>\\n<p><span></span>Once<span> your payday loan application has been approved, you’ll often be able to receive your funds very quickly, sometimes literally within a matter of minutes. </span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Are there alternatives to payday loans?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Can I get a personal loan if I receive Centrelink payments?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/can-i-get-a-personal-loan-if-i-receive-centrelink-payments\\\">Find Out</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the costs of payday loans?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Unlike credit cards and personal loans, payday loans don&#8217;t charge interest on the amount you borrow &#8211; only fees. However, these fees are usually listed in percentages, based on the amount you owe, similar to interest rates. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span></span><span>Current Australian government legislation requires that establishment fees charged at the start of a payday loan can only total up to 20% of the loan principal (e.g. for a $600 loan, there can be a maximum establishment fee of $120). On top of this, the monthly ongoing fees can only total a maximum of 4% (e.g. for a $600 loan, the ongoing fee can be a maximum of $24 per month). Payday loans tend to have fairly short terms, often ranging from as little as 2 weeks to as much as 12 months.</span></p>\\n<h4><span></span><span>What are the risks of payday loans?</span></h4>\\n<p><span></span><span>Payday loans provide fast and simple access to money, which can prove very tempting to people who are already experiencing financial stress, and are thus the most vulnerable to extra costs, fees and charges. </span><span>Even if you only borrow a small amount of money from a payday lender, if your finances are already tight, there’s a big risk of ending up in more debt that you can realistically handle if you’re not careful, or if you experience some bad luck (e.g. having to pay for car repairs after you&#8217;ve already taken out a loan for your new fridge). It just takes one missed repayment to find yourself slapped with steep penalty fees, which can quickly add up, leaving you in real financial trouble.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Get some help</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">MoneySmart Payday loan calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/tools-and-resources/calculators-and-apps/payday-loan-calculator\\\">Try It</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span></span><span></span><span>The best precaution when thinking about payday loans is to take some extra time to look carefully at all the terms and conditions involved, work out a budget to see if you’ll be able to realistically afford the extra fees and charges, and decide whether you think these extra costs will be worth it. Taking this extra time to consider your options may mean you won&#8217;t get your hands on that money quite as fast as simply applying for a payday loan, but avoiding the extra risk of ending up with problem debt is often worth it. </span></p>\\n<p>Also, try to avoid using payday loans as a &#8220;stopgap&#8221; solution for managing repayments on larger debts, such as overdue credit cards or personal loans. Borrowing more money could allow you to avoid a late repayment now, but won&#8217;t fix the root problem, and could leave you in even more debt trouble further down the line.</p>\\n<p>If you ever find yourself struggling with any loan repayments, contact your lender to find out your available options. Alternatively, <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/managing-your-money/managing-debts/financial-counselling\\\">contact MoneySmart</a> for free financial counselling, or call Australia&#8217;s <strong>National Debt Helpline on 1800 007 007</strong>.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1485259644\",\"dc:creator\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"description\":\"Three of the most popular methods for borrowing a bit of extra cash are credit cards, personal loans and payday loans. Each of these loan types have their share of benefits and drawbacks, making them better suited to different financial circumstances. Before you sign on any dotted lines, it’s worth getting an idea of what benefits each type &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/credit-cards-vs-personal-loans-vs-payday-loans/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Credit Cards vs Personal Loans vs Payday Loans\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=61739\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"true\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123131621/credit-card-compare-compressor-724x420.jpeg\",\"id\":61739,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/credit-cards-vs-personal-loans-vs-payday-loans/\",\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"61739\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, 24 Jan 2017 02:07:24 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":13,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"Three of the most popular methods for borrowing a bit of extra cash are credit cards, personal loans and payday loans. Each of these loan types have their share of benefits and drawbacks, making them better suited to different financial circumstances.\",\"slug\":\"credit-cards-vs-personal-loans-vs-payday-loans\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170123131621/credit-card-compare-compressor-350x483.jpeg\",\"title\":\"Credit Cards vs Personal Loans vs Payday Loans\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1485259759\",\"url\":\"/credit-cards/news/credit-cards-vs-personal-loans-vs-payday-loans\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"16\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1484780715:16\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"credit-cards\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/655d7e0698b4208ced875c98ddae1987?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>For the lucky holiday makers who are heading overseas, taking the right credit card can make all the difference when it comes to spending fees and charges.</p>\\n<p>While not all destinations will be credit friendly, there are many that will happily accept your plastic. If you are unsure about the destination you&#8217;re heading to, a quick internet search will help you uncover the advice of past travellers.</p>\\n<p>It is advisable to have several different ways of accessing money with you on your travels so you can never be completely caught out. This could be a mixture of cash, a debit card, travel cards and a credit card. </p>\\n<p>It is worth noting that credit cards may not be the best option for withdrawing cash overseas as you will be charged a cash advance interest rate. They are, however, great to have as a back up plan and can come with handy perks like travel insurance, concierge services and can earn you points while you travel. </p>\\n<p>Picking the right credit card for overseas spending can be tricky as there are many different criteria you could look at. If you aren’t sure how your current card stacks up in the travel market it may be worth contacting your lender and asking for a rundown of overseas ATM charges, currency conversion fees and any perks your card may offer.</p>\\n<p>If you need a new card for your travels, and are at a loss as to where to start, here are some card suggestions. These are merely the tip of the iceberg so if you want to dive further into your credit card search follow the link below. </p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Travel cards</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare credit cards for travel</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/overseas-spending?nav=overseas-spending-credit-cards\\\">Compare now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good for a Frequent Traveller: ANZ Rewards Travel Adventures Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085217/iStock-511194852-e1484779997733.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61661\\\" alt=\\\"Young man travelling in Venice, Italy\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085217/iStock-511194852-e1484779997733.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>This card has the lowest overseas spending fees and foreign exchange fees currently on the market which makes it the perfect travel companion. There are, however, some catches such as the high annual fee and high cash advance rate. If you are doing a lot of travelling, the annual fee might not be a big burden as you will also get travel benefits thrown in such as a return Virgin domestic flight, travel insurance and rental vehicle excess insurance. The cash advance rate is quite high so this card is best used to make credit purchases rather than withdrawing at an ATM.  </p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">ANZ Rewards Travel Adventures Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/anz/rewards-travel-adventures-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good for a Backup Plan: Horizon Credit Union Visa Credit Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61663\\\" alt=\\\"Young woman on the beach phoning the bank for credit card support\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>This card has no overseas ATM fees but charges a currency conversion fee of 1.95 per cent. There is, however, no annual fee which means that you can take the card to have with you as a travel backup for no extra cost. If you do get stuck and need to withdraw cash, the cash advance rate is a relatively reasonable 12.95 per cent. This card doesn’t offer any travel perks such as travel insurance so you will have to pay for any extras separately.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Horizon Credit Union Visa Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/horizon-credit-union/visa-credit-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good Cash Advance Rate: BankVic Visa Silver Credit Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085218/iStock-518506642-e1484780035513.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61662\\\" alt=\\\"young shopper woman taking out money from wallet on street\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085218/iStock-518506642-e1484780035513.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>This card has one of the lowest cash advance rates on the market so if you think you may have to withdraw cash through your credit card overseas this card should be a contender. The card has a credit limit of $10,000 so depending on how long your trip is you might like to have an alternate form of credit available just in case. There is no annual fee on the card but there is a nominal overseas ATM fee and a 2 per cent currency conversion fee that cardholders should be aware of.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3>BankVic Visa Silver Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/bankvic/visa-silver-credit-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good for a Luxury Traveller: Victoria Teachers Mutual Bank Visa Classic Credit Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085215/iStock-503390872-e1484780065806.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61660\\\" alt=\\\"Happy young couple in village Oia on Santorini island, Greece. Click for more similar images from this session.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085215/iStock-503390872-e1484780065806.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Ready to go on the trip of a lifetime? And blow all your cash while you’re there?</p>\\n<p>This card not only has a small overseas ATM fee and 2 per cent foreign currency conversion fee it has a very high credit limit. If you have the credit rating to be approved for a large limit, then you could be living it up on your overseas trip with this card. Of course, reality will always hit and the money will need to be paid back but the card’s interest rate is below average and there is no annual fee.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Victoria Teachers Mutual Bank Visa Classic Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/victoria-teachers-mutual-bank/visa-classic-credit-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>For the lucky holiday makers who are heading overseas, taking the right credit card can make all the difference when it comes to spending fees and charges.</p>\\n<p>While not all destinations will be credit friendly, there are many that will happily accept your plastic. If you are unsure about the destination you&#8217;re heading to, a quick internet search will help you uncover the advice of past travellers.</p>\\n<p>It is advisable to have several different ways of accessing money with you on your travels so you can never be completely caught out. This could be a mixture of cash, a debit card, travel cards and a credit card. </p>\\n<p>It is worth noting that credit cards may not be the best option for withdrawing cash overseas as you will be charged a cash advance interest rate. They are, however, great to have as a back up plan and can come with handy perks like travel insurance, concierge services and can earn you points while you travel. </p>\\n<p>Picking the right credit card for overseas spending can be tricky as there are many different criteria you could look at. If you aren’t sure how your current card stacks up in the travel market it may be worth contacting your lender and asking for a rundown of overseas ATM charges, currency conversion fees and any perks your card may offer.</p>\\n<p>If you need a new card for your travels, and are at a loss as to where to start, here are some card suggestions. These are merely the tip of the iceberg so if you want to dive further into your credit card search follow the link below. </p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Travel cards</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare credit cards for travel</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/overseas-spending?nav=overseas-spending-credit-cards\\\">Compare now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good for a Frequent Traveller: ANZ Rewards Travel Adventures Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085217/iStock-511194852-e1484779997733.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61661\\\" alt=\\\"Young man travelling in Venice, Italy\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085217/iStock-511194852-e1484779997733.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>This card has the lowest overseas spending fees and foreign exchange fees currently on the market which makes it the perfect travel companion. There are, however, some catches such as the high annual fee and high cash advance rate. If you are doing a lot of travelling, the annual fee might not be a big burden as you will also get travel benefits thrown in such as a return Virgin domestic flight, travel insurance and rental vehicle excess insurance. The cash advance rate is quite high so this card is best used to make credit purchases rather than withdrawing at an ATM.  </p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">ANZ Rewards Travel Adventures Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/anz/rewards-travel-adventures-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good for a Backup Plan: Horizon Credit Union Visa Credit Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61663\\\" alt=\\\"Young woman on the beach phoning the bank for credit card support\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085219/iStock-578292378-e1484780015535.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>This card has no overseas ATM fees but charges a currency conversion fee of 1.95 per cent. There is, however, no annual fee which means that you can take the card to have with you as a travel backup for no extra cost. If you do get stuck and need to withdraw cash, the cash advance rate is a relatively reasonable 12.95 per cent. This card doesn’t offer any travel perks such as travel insurance so you will have to pay for any extras separately.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Horizon Credit Union Visa Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/horizon-credit-union/visa-credit-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good Cash Advance Rate: BankVic Visa Silver Credit Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085218/iStock-518506642-e1484780035513.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61662\\\" alt=\\\"young shopper woman taking out money from wallet on street\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085218/iStock-518506642-e1484780035513.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>This card has one of the lowest cash advance rates on the market so if you think you may have to withdraw cash through your credit card overseas this card should be a contender. The card has a credit limit of $10,000 so depending on how long your trip is you might like to have an alternate form of credit available just in case. There is no annual fee on the card but there is a nominal overseas ATM fee and a 2 per cent currency conversion fee that cardholders should be aware of.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3>BankVic Visa Silver Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/bankvic/visa-silver-credit-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<h3>Good for a Luxury Traveller: Victoria Teachers Mutual Bank Visa Classic Credit Card</h3>\\n<p><a href=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085215/iStock-503390872-e1484780065806.jpg\\\"><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"size-full wp-image-61660\\\" alt=\\\"Happy young couple in village Oia on Santorini island, Greece. Click for more similar images from this session.\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085215/iStock-503390872-e1484780065806.jpg\\\" /></a></p>\\n<p>Ready to go on the trip of a lifetime? And blow all your cash while you’re there?</p>\\n<p>This card not only has a small overseas ATM fee and 2 per cent foreign currency conversion fee it has a very high credit limit. If you have the credit rating to be approved for a large limit, then you could be living it up on your overseas trip with this card. Of course, reality will always hit and the money will need to be paid back but the card’s interest rate is below average and there is no annual fee.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Find out more</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Victoria Teachers Mutual Bank Visa Classic Credit Card</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/victoria-teachers-mutual-bank/visa-classic-credit-card\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1484816407\",\"dc:creator\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"description\":\"For the lucky holiday makers who are heading overseas, taking the right credit card can make all the difference when it comes to spending fees and charges. While not all destinations will be credit friendly, there are many that will happily accept your plastic. If you are unsure about the destination you&#8217;re heading to, a &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/top-travel-cards-2017/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Top travel cards for 2017\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=61655\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085939/iStock-494166320-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":61655,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/top-travel-cards-2017/\",\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"61655\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed,
