can make all the difference when it comes to spending fees and charges.\",\"slug\":\"top-travel-cards-2017\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170119085939/iStock-494166320-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"Top travel cards for 2017\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1484816461\",\"url\":\"/credit-cards/news/top-travel-cards-2017\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"}],\"homeLoans\":[{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[\\\"on\\\",null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1492057933:39\",\"_yoast_wpseo_focuskw\":\"home loan calculator, mortgage repayment calculator, interest rates, home loan repayment calculator, home loans, home loan comparison\",\"_yoast_wpseo_focuskw_text_input\":\"home loan calculator, mortgage repayment calculator, interest rates, home loan repayment calculator, home loans, home loan comparison\",\"_yoast_wpseo_linkdex\":\"53\",\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"The fixed versus variable home loan debate\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/cb42476b4c10c5427d762d5dabd94582?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":null,\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\\\">home loans</a> can feel like playing a game of rock, paper, scissors – all about predicting what’s likely to happen next. </span></p>\\n<p><span>With interest rates continuing to rise for owner-occupier and investor home loans, borrowers may be feeling uncertain as to which type of loan they should commit to. Choosing between variable and fixed interest rates can be difficult, but there are ways to get ahead.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a fixed home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><span>A fixed home loan allows you to lock in an interest rate on your mortgage for a length of time to enjoy greater stability and simpler budgeting in your personal finances. Most lenders will offer fixed periods between 1-5 years, however some do offer fixed home loans of up to 10 years. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">Fixed interest rates</a><span> </span>give you certainty; if you can afford the repayments today, you can afford them next year (assuming your circumstances remain the same). It’s this peace of mind that appeals to many<span> </span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">fixed rate</a><span> </span>borrowers because their repayments stay the same whether rates fall, rise or stay the same.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a variable home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span>Fixed home loans can be frustrating if you lock in a rate before variable rates drop, because exiting a fixed-rate mortgage can be costly.  Most borrowers stick with the<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/variable-rate\\\">variable rate</a><span> </span>rollercoaster, which keeps things flexible – allowing for extra repayments, for instance.</span></p>\\n<p>A variable home loan usually starts with a lower home loan rate offered by the bank, which fluctuates depending on the cash rate determined by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA).</p>\\n<h3><strong>Is it worth the risk?</strong></h3>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411093003/iStock-538027758-e1491867015381.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p><span>In recent weeks, dozens of lenders have increased interest rates for owner-occupied and investor home loans, <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">including the big-four banks</a>. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>This has followed changes to regulations made by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders. The RBA has responded to changes in regulations and rising interest rates by holding the cash rate at an historically low 1.5%. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>A recent RateCity survey has shown that 1 in 10 people who have refinanced their home loan in the past two years switched from a variable to a fixed home loan with the same bank.</span></p>\\n<h3><strong>Borrowers’ best options</strong></h3>\\n<p>While interest rates can make a substantial difference to your repayments and the total interest you pay on your home loan, the past has proven it&#8217;s very hard to predict which option will perform better.</p>\\n<p>Fixing in October 2005 would have saved borrowers 15%, or around $12,200 compared to variable over the following three years. Fixing a home loan rate in September 1991 would have cost a borrower an extra 30%, or $29,800, over the next three years.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><span style=\\\"background-color: #ffffff;\\\">Typically, when the gap between fixed and variable rates widens due to either an increase in variable rates or a decrease in fixed or both, it could be the right time to fix.</span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>Another good time would be if fixed rates were not much higher than the average basic variable rate. For example, if the average basic variable rate was 4.97%, and some lenders were offering three-year fixed loans at 5.1%, with a difference between the two of only 13 basis points, it could be worth fixing.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><span>However, most Aussies tend to ‘panic fix’ when rates are at the highest. For example, more than 25% of new loans were fixed in March 2008 when the RBA cash rate was at a peak at 7.25%. When rates fell to 3% a year later, only 4% of new loans were fixed.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Ultimately, choosing between a fixed or variable rate is still a personal choice. It is important that you factor in whether you can afford at least a 2% rate increase no matter what type of loan you decide.</span> </p>\\n<p><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/YfcmYsE1LPc\\\" width=\\\"560\\\" height=\\\"315\\\"></iframe></p>\\n<h3><strong>Tips to consider before fixing</p>\\n<p></strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><strong><span>What are the break costs?</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>Lenders can charge borrowers fees when you make extra repayments on a fixed home loan. Most will allow you to pay a small extra amount off your mortgage without being charged. but if you go over this amount, or fully pay off your loan ahead of schedule, you may be charged break costs. As of July 2011, variable mortgages have no early repayment penalties or exit fees, however fixed rate break costs and discharge fees still apply. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Track your bank’s interest rates</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If your loan’s fixed term is coming to completion, it is wise to monitor it well ahead of time and discuss your best options with your bank before it finishes. You may want to fix again or revert to a variable rate, depending on whether you believe rates will continue to rise or fall.</span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Consider taking out a split loan  </span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If you still can’t decide, perhaps a split loan is for you. Having half your loan in a variable account could allow for flexibility, while the other half of your loan remains secured at the fixed rate. </span></p>\\n<h3><span> </span><strong><span>Pros / Cons of fixed rate</span></strong><strong><span> </span></strong></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Protected against raising interest rates</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">P<span>rotected against cash rate fluctuations</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Set an accurate budget</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>If lenders drop rates you’re stuck paying more</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">L<span>ess flexibility to make extra payments</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Typically have expensive break fees</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Loan may take longer to pay off, so you’ll pay more interest</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"fixed rate\",\"home loan\",\"mortgage\",\"variable rate\"],\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\\\">home loans</a> can feel like playing a game of rock, paper, scissors – all about predicting what’s likely to happen next. </span></p>\\n<p><span>With interest rates continuing to rise for owner-occupier and investor home loans, borrowers may be feeling uncertain as to which type of loan they should commit to. Choosing between variable and fixed interest rates can be difficult, but there are ways to get ahead.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a fixed home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><span>A fixed home loan allows you to lock in an interest rate on your mortgage for a length of time to enjoy greater stability and simpler budgeting in your personal finances. Most lenders will offer fixed periods between 1-5 years, however some do offer fixed home loans of up to 10 years. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">Fixed interest rates</a><span> </span>give you certainty; if you can afford the repayments today, you can afford them next year (assuming your circumstances remain the same). It’s this peace of mind that appeals to many<span> </span><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">fixed rate</a><span> </span>borrowers because their repayments stay the same whether rates fall, rise or stay the same.</span></p>\\n<h3><span></span><strong>What is a variable home loan?</strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span>Fixed home loans can be frustrating if you lock in a rate before variable rates drop, because exiting a fixed-rate mortgage can be costly.  Most borrowers stick with the<span> </span><span><a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/variable-rate\\\">variable rate</a><span> </span>rollercoaster, which keeps things flexible – allowing for extra repayments, for instance.</span></p>\\n<p>A variable home loan usually starts with a lower home loan rate offered by the bank, which fluctuates depending on the cash rate determined by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA).</p>\\n<h3><strong>Is it worth the risk?</strong></h3>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\" http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411093003/iStock-538027758-e1491867015381.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p><span>In recent weeks, dozens of lenders have increased interest rates for owner-occupied and investor home loans, <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">including the big-four banks</a>. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>This has followed changes to regulations made by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders. The RBA has responded to changes in regulations and rising interest rates by holding the cash rate at an historically low 1.5%. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>A recent RateCity survey has shown that 1 in 10 people who have refinanced their home loan in the past two years switched from a variable to a fixed home loan with the same bank.</span></p>\\n<h3><strong>Borrowers’ best options</strong></h3>\\n<p>While interest rates can make a substantial difference to your repayments and the total interest you pay on your home loan, the past has proven it&#8217;s very hard to predict which option will perform better.</p>\\n<p>Fixing in October 2005 would have saved borrowers 15%, or around $12,200 compared to variable over the following three years. Fixing a home loan rate in September 1991 would have cost a borrower an extra 30%, or $29,800, over the next three years.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\"><span style=\\\"background-color: #ffffff;\\\">Typically, when the gap between fixed and variable rates widens due to either an increase in variable rates or a decrease in fixed or both, it could be the right time to fix.</span></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>Another good time would be if fixed rates were not much higher than the average basic variable rate. For example, if the average basic variable rate was 4.97%, and some lenders were offering three-year fixed loans at 5.1%, with a difference between the two of only 13 basis points, it could be worth fixing.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><span>However, most Aussies tend to ‘panic fix’ when rates are at the highest. For example, more than 25% of new loans were fixed in March 2008 when the RBA cash rate was at a peak at 7.25%. When rates fell to 3% a year later, only 4% of new loans were fixed.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Ultimately, choosing between a fixed or variable rate is still a personal choice. It is important that you factor in whether you can afford at least a 2% rate increase no matter what type of loan you decide.</span> </p>\\n<p><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/YfcmYsE1LPc\\\" width=\\\"560\\\" height=\\\"315\\\"></iframe></p>\\n<h3><strong>Tips to consider before fixing</p>\\n<p></strong></h3>\\n<p><span></span><strong><span>What are the break costs?</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>Lenders can charge borrowers fees when you make extra repayments on a fixed home loan. Most will allow you to pay a small extra amount off your mortgage without being charged. but if you go over this amount, or fully pay off your loan ahead of schedule, you may be charged break costs. As of July 2011, variable mortgages have no early repayment penalties or exit fees, however fixed rate break costs and discharge fees still apply. </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Track your bank’s interest rates</span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If your loan’s fixed term is coming to completion, it is wise to monitor it well ahead of time and discuss your best options with your bank before it finishes. You may want to fix again or revert to a variable rate, depending on whether you believe rates will continue to rise or fall.</span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><strong><span>Consider taking out a split loan  </span></strong></p>\\n<p><span>If you still can’t decide, perhaps a split loan is for you. Having half your loan in a variable account could allow for flexibility, while the other half of your loan remains secured at the fixed rate. </span></p>\\n<h3><span> </span><strong><span>Pros / Cons of fixed rate</span></strong><strong><span> </span></strong></h3>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Protected against raising interest rates</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">P<span>rotected against cash rate fluctuations</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\"><span>Set an accurate budget</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>If lenders drop rates you’re stuck paying more</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">L<span>ess flexibility to make extra payments</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Typically have expensive break fees</span></li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\"><span>Loan may take longer to pay off, so you’ll pay more interest</span></li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1491903053\",\"dc:creator\":\"administrator\",\"description\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411092811/iStock-507546185-725x420.jpg\",\"id\":48297,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/\",\"media_release\":null,\"meta_description\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"meta_keywords\":\"home loan calculator, mortgage repayment calculator, interest rates, home loan repayment calculator, home loans, home loan comparison\",\"meta_title\":\"The fixed versus variable home loan debate\",\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"48297\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon, 10 Apr 2017 23:30:53 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":5,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"Choosing between variable, fixed and split rate home loans can be like engaging in the chance game of paper, rocks, scissors. Choosing your opponents next move can be just as hard as trying to predict the property market and interest rate changes.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"the_article_type\":\"articles\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170411092811/iStock-507546185-350x482.jpg\",\"title\":\"The fixed versus variable home loan debate\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1491903442\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/the-fixed-versus-variable-home-loan-debate/feed/\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"39\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1491780472:39\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Philip Lowe, has shown support for new housing affordability regulations from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders.</p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://www.rba.gov.au/speeches/2017/sp-gov-2017-04-04.html\\\">Speaking at the RBA Board dinner</a> following the central bank’s April meeting, which kept Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at record-low 1.5% for the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\\\">eighth straight month</a>, governor Lowe commented that Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest-only home loans</a> are “unusual” compared to the rest of the world:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Over the past year, close to 40% of the housing loans made in Australia have not required the scheduled repayment of even one dollar of principal at least in the first years of the life of the loan; only interest payments are required. This is unusual by international standards. In some countries, repayment of at least some principal is required on all housing loans for the entire life of the loan. In other countries, interest-only loans are available only if the borrower has already contributed a fair degree of equity. So this is one area where Australia stands out. We are not unique in this area, but we are unusual.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>What is an interest only home loan?</h3>\\n<p>An <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest only home loan</a> does <a href=\\\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Does_exactly_what_it_says_on_the_tin\\\">exactly what it says on the tin</a> – it’s a home loan where instead of making repayments that include both the loan’s principal and interest, you only pay interest to your lender instead.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//Oo5T6277z98\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">Interest-only home loans</a> are typically only available for a limited period of time. Many lenders limit interest-only repayments to 1 to 5 year stretches, though some lenders are willing to accept interest-only repayments for longer periods. Once an interest-only period is up, you’ll need to either apply to the lender to start a new interest-only period, or switch to paying principal and interest</p>\\n<h3>Advantages of interest-only loans </h3>\\n<p>One of the most obvious advantages of an interest only loan is that you only need to pay the interest and not the principal, which makes the loan cheaper on a month to month basis. This can make interest-only loans attractive to some owner-occupiers looking to keep their costs down, whether they’re first homebuyers trying to firmly establish their finances, or borrowers seeking to free up more of their income to pay for a renovation or some other personal project.</p>\\n<p>According to governor Lowe, the flexible nature of Australia’s mortgages plays a significant role in the popularity of interest-only loans:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Many people with interest-only loans make significant payments into offset accounts rather than explicitly paying down principal. This flexibility, which is of value to many people, isn&#8217;t available in most countries.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>By paying money into an offset account on an interest only loan, borrowers can reduce their interest repayments, and still access these funds if required much more easily than making a redraw or taking out a line of credit from a principal and interest home loan.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//LUmh9AOzmug\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p>But it’s property investors that can really benefit from interest only loans. By using an interest-only loan to buy a property, an investor can enjoy low <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> (potentially lowered further by an offset account), as well as tax benefits from negative gearing if the interest they pay is higher than the rental income they earn.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Are tax benefits worth investment losses?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">The pros and cons of negative gearing</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/the-pros-and-cons-of-negative-gearing\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>And even though an interest only loan doesn’t reduce the principal, the property’s value can still increase over time, so by the end of the interest-only period, the investor can sell and come out ahead, or reinvest using the resulting equity.     </p>\\n<h3>Disadvantages of interest only loans </h3>\\n<p>While interest only loans may seem relatively affordable because you only need to pay your loan’s interest, if lenders repeatedly raise their interest rates, borrowers could find their <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> quickly growing unaffordable. Similarly, if a lender declines to renew or extend an ending interest only period, borrowers could find themselves unable to afford their higher principal and interest repayments.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Can you afford P&I repayments?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Home Loan Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">Find Out</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>For owner occupiers, interest only loans may be more affordable in the short term, but because the principal isn’t being reduced during the interest-only period, this can mean the loan ultimately takes longer to pay off, and the borrower will pay more in total interest over the lifetime of the loan.</p>\\n<p>For investors, if their property&#8217;s capital growth is sluggish, or even drops in value (not impossible in specific areas) they could reach the end of their interest-only period without enough usable equity available to cover their costs.</p>\\n<h3>How will the new regulations affect interest only loans? </h3>\\n<p>Among <a href=\\\"http://www.apra.gov.au/adi/Publications/Documents/Further%20measures%20to%20reinforce%20sound%20residential%20mortgage%20lending%20practices.pdf\\\">APRA’s new guidelines</a> for banks, lenders and home loan providers are regulations to “limit the flow of new interest-only lending to 30% of new residential mortgage lending”, and to “manage lending to investors in such a manner so as to comfortably remain below the previously advised benchmark of 10% growth.”</p>\\n<p>Limiting the number of new interest-only loans (among other APRA regulations) should help to limit the number of Australians borrowing beyond their means and putting themselves into potentially risky financial positions if interest rates were to rise or house prices to fall.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">What options are available?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How can we fix the housing affordability crisis?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/can-fix-housing-affordability-crisis\\\">Learn More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>These regulations should also contribute to reducing the overall level of risk in the Australian housing market, and help to stabilise the broader Australian economy in case of future economic downturns.  </p>\\n<p>Curbing interest-only loans is also expected to limit the impact of investors on Australia’s housing affordability, which according to governor Lowe, was already under pressure from high demand and limited supply in popular areas:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Not surprisingly, the rising prices have encouraged people to buy residential property as an investment in the hope of ongoing capital gains. With global interest rates so low, many investors have found it attractive to borrow money to invest in appreciating residential property. This has reinforced the upward pressure on prices.”</p>\\n<p>“Like the earlier ‘speed limits’ on investor lending, these new requirements should help the whole system pull back to a more sustainable position. A reduced reliance on interest-only loans in Australia would be a positive development and would help improve our resilience.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>Compare interest-only home loans:</h3>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_comparisonRate=3.8&ab_test_id=0.72&interestOnly=true&sort_field=advertisedRate\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"category\":[\"home-loans\",\"interest\",\"interest only\",\"interest only loans\",\"investment lending\",\"mortgages\",\"negative gearing\",\"rba\",\"reserve bank of australia\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Philip Lowe, has shown support for new housing affordability regulations from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders.</p>\\n<p><a href=\\\"https://www.rba.gov.au/speeches/2017/sp-gov-2017-04-04.html\\\">Speaking at the RBA Board dinner</a> following the central bank’s April meeting, which kept Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at record-low 1.5% for the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\\\">eighth straight month</a>, governor Lowe commented that Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest-only home loans</a> are “unusual” compared to the rest of the world:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Over the past year, close to 40% of the housing loans made in Australia have not required the scheduled repayment of even one dollar of principal at least in the first years of the life of the loan; only interest payments are required. This is unusual by international standards. In some countries, repayment of at least some principal is required on all housing loans for the entire life of the loan. In other countries, interest-only loans are available only if the borrower has already contributed a fair degree of equity. So this is one area where Australia stands out. We are not unique in this area, but we are unusual.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>What is an interest only home loan?</h3>\\n<p>An <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">interest only home loan</a> does <a href=\\\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Does_exactly_what_it_says_on_the_tin\\\">exactly what it says on the tin</a> – it’s a home loan where instead of making repayments that include both the loan’s principal and interest, you only pay interest to your lender instead.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//Oo5T6277z98\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/interest-only-home-loans\\\">Interest-only home loans</a> are typically only available for a limited period of time. Many lenders limit interest-only repayments to 1 to 5 year stretches, though some lenders are willing to accept interest-only repayments for longer periods. Once an interest-only period is up, you’ll need to either apply to the lender to start a new interest-only period, or switch to paying principal and interest</p>\\n<h3>Advantages of interest-only loans </h3>\\n<p>One of the most obvious advantages of an interest only loan is that you only need to pay the interest and not the principal, which makes the loan cheaper on a month to month basis. This can make interest-only loans attractive to some owner-occupiers looking to keep their costs down, whether they’re first homebuyers trying to firmly establish their finances, or borrowers seeking to free up more of their income to pay for a renovation or some other personal project.</p>\\n<p>According to governor Lowe, the flexible nature of Australia’s mortgages plays a significant role in the popularity of interest-only loans:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Many people with interest-only loans make significant payments into offset accounts rather than explicitly paying down principal. This flexibility, which is of value to many people, isn&#8217;t available in most countries.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>By paying money into an offset account on an interest only loan, borrowers can reduce their interest repayments, and still access these funds if required much more easily than making a redraw or taking out a line of credit from a principal and interest home loan.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"embed-container\\\"><iframe src=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/embed//LUmh9AOzmug\\\" width=\\\"300\\\" height=\\\"150\\\"></iframe></div>\\n<p>But it’s property investors that can really benefit from interest only loans. By using an interest-only loan to buy a property, an investor can enjoy low <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> (potentially lowered further by an offset account), as well as tax benefits from negative gearing if the interest they pay is higher than the rental income they earn.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Are tax benefits worth investment losses?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">The pros and cons of negative gearing</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/the-pros-and-cons-of-negative-gearing\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>And even though an interest only loan doesn’t reduce the principal, the property’s value can still increase over time, so by the end of the interest-only period, the investor can sell and come out ahead, or reinvest using the resulting equity.     </p>\\n<h3>Disadvantages of interest only loans </h3>\\n<p>While interest only loans may seem relatively affordable because you only need to pay your loan’s interest, if lenders repeatedly raise their interest rates, borrowers could find their <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">monthly repayments</a> quickly growing unaffordable. Similarly, if a lender declines to renew or extend an ending interest only period, borrowers could find themselves unable to afford their higher principal and interest repayments.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Can you afford P&I repayments?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Home Loan Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/calculator\\\">Find Out</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>For owner occupiers, interest only loans may be more affordable in the short term, but because the principal isn’t being reduced during the interest-only period, this can mean the loan ultimately takes longer to pay off, and the borrower will pay more in total interest over the lifetime of the loan.</p>\\n<p>For investors, if their property&#8217;s capital growth is sluggish, or even drops in value (not impossible in specific areas) they could reach the end of their interest-only period without enough usable equity available to cover their costs.</p>\\n<h3>How will the new regulations affect interest only loans? </h3>\\n<p>Among <a href=\\\"http://www.apra.gov.au/adi/Publications/Documents/Further%20measures%20to%20reinforce%20sound%20residential%20mortgage%20lending%20practices.pdf\\\">APRA’s new guidelines</a> for banks, lenders and home loan providers are regulations to “limit the flow of new interest-only lending to 30% of new residential mortgage lending”, and to “manage lending to investors in such a manner so as to comfortably remain below the previously advised benchmark of 10% growth.”</p>\\n<p>Limiting the number of new interest-only loans (among other APRA regulations) should help to limit the number of Australians borrowing beyond their means and putting themselves into potentially risky financial positions if interest rates were to rise or house prices to fall.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">What options are available?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How can we fix the housing affordability crisis?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/can-fix-housing-affordability-crisis\\\">Learn More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>These regulations should also contribute to reducing the overall level of risk in the Australian housing market, and help to stabilise the broader Australian economy in case of future economic downturns.  </p>\\n<p>Curbing interest-only loans is also expected to limit the impact of investors on Australia’s housing affordability, which according to governor Lowe, was already under pressure from high demand and limited supply in popular areas:</p>\\n<blockquote><p>“Not surprisingly, the rising prices have encouraged people to buy residential property as an investment in the hope of ongoing capital gains. With global interest rates so low, many investors have found it attractive to borrow money to invest in appreciating residential property. This has reinforced the upward pressure on prices.”</p>\\n<p>“Like the earlier ‘speed limits’ on investor lending, these new requirements should help the whole system pull back to a more sustainable position. A reduced reliance on interest-only loans in Australia would be a positive development and would help improve our resilience.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>Compare interest-only home loans:</h3>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_comparisonRate=3.8&ab_test_id=0.72&interestOnly=true&sort_field=advertisedRate\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1491562047\",\"dc:creator\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"description\":\"The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Philip Lowe, has shown support for new housing affordability regulations from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders. Speaking at the RBA Board dinner following the central bank’s April meeting, which kept Australia’s &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/looking-interest-loans/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Looking at interest only loans\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=63549\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"true\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170407104427/interest-only-loans-compressor-748x420.jpeg\",\"id\":63549,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/looking-interest-loans/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"63549\",\"pubDate\":\"Fri, 07 Apr 2017 00:47:27 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":6,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Philip Lowe, has shown support for new housing affordability regulations from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, including limiting interest-only loans to 30% of all new loans supplied by banks and lenders.\",\"slug\":\"looking-interest-loans\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170407104427/interest-only-loans-compressor-350x467.jpeg\",\"title\":\"Looking at interest only loans\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1491816563\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/looking-interest-loans\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1491285525:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Continuing an eight-month trend, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has held the <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at 1.5 per cent at its April board meeting.</p>\\n<p>In a statement made today, governor Philip Lowe has referenced increases in <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">mortgage rates</a> and growth in household borrowing outpacing growth in household income as influencing the decision.</p>\\n<p>The decision to hold the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> is understandable when you consider how many leading banks, including the big four, have been steadily increasing principal and interest and interest only rates for owner-occupier and investor home loans.</p>\\n<p>On Friday, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) advised banks that it expects them to tighten lending practices on interest-only loans. Following this announcement, three of the four major banks raised interest rates in interest-only and investor loans. </p>\\n<p>“By reinforcing strong lending standards, the recently announced supervisory measures should help address the risks associated with high and rising levels of indebtedness,” Lowe said.</p>\\n<p>“Lenders need to ensure that the serviceability metrics that they use are appropriate for current conditions.”</p>\\n<p>“A reduced reliance on interest-only housing loans in the Australian market would also be a positive development.”</p>\\n<p>New rules implemented by APRA limit interest-only loans with banks to no more than 30 per cent of their total new home lending. APRA chairman, Wayne Byres, advised that this was to ensure banks recognise the “heightened risk in the lending environment, and that their lending standards and practices appropriately respond to these conditions.”</p>\\n<p>Housing prices in Sydney are also at a seven-year high, increasing another 1.4 per cent across Australia in March. Data from property group, CoreLogic, has shown that annual property price growth has grown 19 per cent in Sydney and 16 per cent in Melbourne.</p>\\n<p>It is evident that the RBA will want to see how the growth in household borrowing and increasing mortgage interest rates may affect the Australian economy before making any changes to the cash rate.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Has your bank raised interest rates?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How the big four&#8217;s increases affect you</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">Learn how now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"home loan\",\"RBA and interest rate\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Continuing an eight-month trend, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has held the <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> at 1.5 per cent at its April board meeting.</p>\\n<p>In a statement made today, governor Philip Lowe has referenced increases in <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">mortgage rates</a> and growth in household borrowing outpacing growth in household income as influencing the decision.</p>\\n<p>The decision to hold the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> is understandable when you consider how many leading banks, including the big four, have been steadily increasing principal and interest and interest only rates for owner-occupier and investor home loans.</p>\\n<p>On Friday, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) advised banks that it expects them to tighten lending practices on interest-only loans. Following this announcement, three of the four major banks raised interest rates in interest-only and investor loans. </p>\\n<p>“By reinforcing strong lending standards, the recently announced supervisory measures should help address the risks associated with high and rising levels of indebtedness,” Lowe said.</p>\\n<p>“Lenders need to ensure that the serviceability metrics that they use are appropriate for current conditions.”</p>\\n<p>“A reduced reliance on interest-only housing loans in the Australian market would also be a positive development.”</p>\\n<p>New rules implemented by APRA limit interest-only loans with banks to no more than 30 per cent of their total new home lending. APRA chairman, Wayne Byres, advised that this was to ensure banks recognise the “heightened risk in the lending environment, and that their lending standards and practices appropriately respond to these conditions.”</p>\\n<p>Housing prices in Sydney are also at a seven-year high, increasing another 1.4 per cent across Australia in March. Data from property group, CoreLogic, has shown that annual property price growth has grown 19 per cent in Sydney and 16 per cent in Melbourne.</p>\\n<p>It is evident that the RBA will want to see how the growth in household borrowing and increasing mortgage interest rates may affect the Australian economy before making any changes to the cash rate.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Has your bank raised interest rates?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">How the big four&#8217;s increases affect you</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\\\">Learn how now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1491318370\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Continuing an eight-month trend, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has held the cash rate at 1.5 per cent at its April board meeting. In a statement made today, governor Philip Lowe has referenced increases in mortgage rates and growth in household borrowing outpacing growth in household income as influencing the decision. The decision to &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"RBA cash rate holds yet again at 1.5 per cent\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=63517\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170404150341/iStock-540127528-725x420.jpg\",\"id\":63517,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"63517\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":2,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170404150341/iStock-540127528-350x482.jpg\",\"title\":\"RBA cent\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1491321664\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-cash-rate-holds-yet-1-5-per-cent\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1491264028:39\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Yet another of the big four banks has increased <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a>, with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\\\">Commonwealth Bank</a> of Australia (CBA) raising borrowing costs for owner-occupiers and property investors.</p>\\n<p>These increases will see CBA raise principal and interest loan interest rates to 5.25 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.80 per cent for investors. Interest only loan rates will also be increasing to 5.47 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.94 per cent for investors.</p>\\n<p>CBA’s rate increases come hot on the heels of <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a>, and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> announcing similar increases to their owner-occupied and investment home loans only hours earlier.</p>\\n<h4><strong>Big Four Bank Rate Increases:</strong></h4>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170329091412/Screen-Shot-2017-03-29-at-10.13.46-AM.png\\\" /></p>\\n<p><em> * Based on $500,000 principal and 30 year loan term.</em></p>\\n<p><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\\\">NAB</a> and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a> customers may be feeling the pinch, as rate increases to owner-occupied and investment loans have already come into effect.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-tip\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">What will this cost everyday Australians?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p>Examples:</p>\\n<p>Customers with owner-occupier, interest only loans with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\">Westpac</a> can expect to pay an extra $400 per year.*</p>\\n<p>Investors with interest only loans with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\\\">NAB</a> will also find themselves out of pocket an extra $1,250 per year.*</p>\\n<p>*<em>Based </em><em>on $500,000 principal and 30 year loan term.</em></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>However, CBA and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\\\">ANZ</a> customers still have time to assess their existing loans and whether they’ll be better off switching.</p>\\n<p>In a statement made on Friday, Matt Comyn, CBA’s Group Executive for Retail Banking Services, announced the May 8 deadline has been put in place to minimise the impact for the majority of home loan customers.</p>\\n<p>“Rising costs and regulatory responsibilities mean we are increasing home loan interest rates” he said, regarding the cause of these rate increases.</p>\\n<p>These ‘regulatory responsibilities’ relate to increasing concerns about a property bubble in Australia. Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) chairman, Greg Medcraft, issued the warning at their recent annual forum in Sydney. ASIC are working with Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) to help mitigate these risks, such as encouraging responsible lending by curbing loans to investors. </p>\\n<p>Only last month CBA announced they were blocking the refinancing of some investor loans as a response to these regulations. CBA subsidiary, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">BankWest</a>, also halted all investment lending to new borrowers.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to learn more?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Banks Blocking Investor Loans</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/61989\\\">Read More</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"home loan\",\"interest rates\",\"investor\",\"mortgage\",\"owner-occupier\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Yet another of the big four banks has increased <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a>, with <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\\\">Commonwealth Bank</a> of Australia (CBA) raising borrowing costs for owner-occupiers and property investors.</p>\\n<p>These increases will see CBA raise principal and interest loan interest rates to 5.25 per cent for owner-occupiers and 5.80 per cent for investors. Services, announced the May 8 deadline has been put in place to minimise the impact for the majority of home loan customers.</p>\\n<p>“Rising costs and regulatory responsibilities mean we are increasing home loan interest rates” he said, regarding the cause of these rate increases.</p>\\n<p>These ‘regulatory responsibilities’ relate to increasing concerns about a property bubble in Australia. ASIC are working with Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) to help mitigate these risks, such as encouraging responsible lending by curbing loans to investors. </p>\\n<p>Only last month CBA announced they were blocking the refinancing of some investor loans as a response to these regulations. class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"How will the big four’s interest rate increases affect you?\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62907\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328130803/iStock-577640492-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62907,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62907\",\"pubDate\":\"Tue, 28 Mar 2017 03:06:11 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":2,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170328130803/iStock-577640492-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"How will the big four’s interest rate increases affect you?\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1490778966\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-big-fours-interest-rate-increases-affect\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1490157881:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Did you know some banks compete to give certain borrowers a home loan? They offer inducements such as interest rate discounts and waived fees all because these people are ‘ideal borrowers’.</p>\\n<p>RateCity data indicates that these ideal borrowers receive, on average, 0.55 per cent lower interest rates from lenders than other borrowers. So, what are their secrets?</p>\\n<h3><strong>What is an ideal borrower?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Ideal borrowers are those who present the least amount of risk to lenders in terms of defaulting on their loan.  They will have a good credit rating, including a proven track record of paying their bills and credit cards on time. They will also have a deposit of at least 20 per cent and be intending to live in the home they buy.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Becoming an ideal borrower</strong><strong> </strong></h3>\\n<p>The trick to getting these discounted <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a> is to become an ideal borrower.</p>\\n<p>One of the best ways to position yourself as an ideal borrower is to save as large a deposit as possible. This shows lenders that you are less of a risk as they will have less to recoup if you default on the loan. It also proves that you are the type of borrower who can save a large nest egg.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much can you borrow?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Borrow Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow?nav=borrow-calculator\\\">Learn Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>That said, saving up a 20 per cent deposit is no easy feat, especially if you live in Sydney or Melbourne where this would equate to saving $150,000 to $200,000. Luckily, there are other ways you become an ‘ideal borrower’ and take advantage of lower interest rates.</p>\\n<ol>\\n<li><strong>Get a guarantor</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>One way to become a more attractive borrower is to get a guarantor.</p>\\n<p>If you have the support of someone with equity in their home they can be linked to your home loan and their property will be used as additional security. Lenders tend to only allow immediate family members as guarantors, but this can differ depending on the lender.</p>\\n<p>The main concern with this type of loan is that if you default on your loan the lender can take action against the borrower and guarantor, and your guarantor will be liable for your home loan.  </p>\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\">\\n<li><strong>Take extra precautions if you’re self-employed</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Applying for a home loan can be a daunting process if you’re self-employed. However, if you organise all your financial records before you apply you will be in a much stronger position, particularly when lenders are looking to identify consistency of income. Lenders look for transparency when assessing risk, so make sure you can identify all your business expenses, such as car allowance, deprecation, non-recurring expenses etc.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Are you really self-employed?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span>It’s also important to clarify whether you are actually self-employed in the bank’s eyes because some lenders consider contractors or sub-contractors as employees.</span><strong> </strong></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\">\\n<li><strong>Correct your credit history</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Your credit score is one of the major deciding factors for lenders when assessing whether you are eligible for a loan, let alone a loan with a discounted interest rate. They will go through your history with a fine-tooth comb looking for any missed or defaulted payments.</p>\\n<p>The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) recently reported that 30 per cent of Australians have errors on their credit report. It is worth getting a copy of your credit report from <a href=\\\"http://www.equifax.com.au/getcreditscore/\\\">Veda</a> and going through it very carefully just in case of mistakes, such as strangers or family members with similar names having their debt incorrectly labelled as yours. </p>\",\"category\":[\"home loan\",\"interest rates\",\"mortgage\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Did you know some banks compete to give certain borrowers a home loan? They offer inducements such as interest rate discounts and waived fees all because these people are ‘ideal borrowers’.</p>\\n<p>RateCity data indicates that these ideal borrowers receive, on average, 0.55 per cent lower interest rates from lenders than other borrowers. So, what are their secrets?</p>\\n<h3><strong>What is an ideal borrower?</strong></h3>\\n<p>Ideal borrowers are those who present the least amount of risk to lenders in terms of defaulting on their loan.  They will have a good credit rating, including a proven track record of paying their bills and credit cards on time. They will also have a deposit of at least 20 per cent and be intending to live in the home they buy.</p>\\n<h3><strong>Becoming an ideal borrower</strong><strong> </strong></h3>\\n<p>The trick to getting these discounted <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-rates\\\">home loan rates</a> is to become an ideal borrower.</p>\\n<p>One of the best ways to position yourself as an ideal borrower is to save as large a deposit as possible. This shows lenders that you are less of a risk as they will have less to recoup if you default on the loan. It also proves that you are the type of borrower who can save a large nest egg.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">How much can you borrow?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Borrow Calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow?nav=borrow-calculator\\\">Learn Now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p>That said, saving up a 20 per cent deposit is no easy feat, especially if you live in Sydney or Melbourne where this would equate to saving $150,000 to $200,000. Luckily, there are other ways you become an ‘ideal borrower’ and take advantage of lower interest rates.</p>\\n<ol>\\n<li><strong>Get a guarantor</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>One way to become a more attractive borrower is to get a guarantor.</p>\\n<p>If you have the support of someone with equity in their home they can be linked to your home loan and their property will be used as additional security. Lenders tend to only allow immediate family members as guarantors, but this can differ depending on the lender.</p>\\n<p>The main concern with this type of loan is that if you default on your loan the lender can take action against the borrower and guarantor, and your guarantor will be liable for your home loan.  </p>\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\">\\n<li><strong>Take extra precautions if you’re self-employed</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Applying for a home loan can be a daunting process if you’re self-employed. However, if you organise all your financial records before you apply you will be in a much stronger position, particularly when lenders are looking to identify consistency of income. Lenders look for transparency when assessing risk, so make sure you can identify all your business expenses, such as car allowance, deprecation, non-recurring expenses etc.</p>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout breakout-example\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-heading\\\">\\n<p class=\\\"breakout-title\\\">Are you really self-employed?</p>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"breakout-body\\\">\\n<p><span>It’s also important to clarify whether you are actually self-employed in the bank’s eyes because some lenders consider contractors or sub-contractors as employees.</span><strong> </strong></p>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\">\\n<li><strong>Correct your credit history</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Your credit score is one of the major deciding factors for lenders when assessing whether you are eligible for a loan, let alone a loan with a discounted interest rate. They will go through your history with a fine-tooth comb looking for any missed or defaulted payments.</p>\\n<p>The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) recently reported that 30 per cent of Australians have errors on their credit report. It is worth getting a copy of your credit report from <a href=\\\"http://www.equifax.com.au/getcreditscore/\\\">Veda</a> and going through it very carefully just in case of mistakes, such as strangers or family members with similar names having their debt incorrectly labelled as yours. </p>\",\"created_at\":\"1490188735\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"Did you know some banks compete to give certain borrowers a home loan? They offer inducements such as interest rate discounts and waived fees all because these people are ‘ideal borrowers’. RateCity data indicates that these ideal borrowers receive, on average, 0.55 per cent lower interest rates from lenders than other borrowers. So, what are &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"The secrets to getting the lowest home loan rate\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62826\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170322131648/iStock-505472872-1-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62826,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62826\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 22 Mar 2017 03:18:55 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":3,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":null,\"slug\":\"secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170322131648/iStock-505472872-1-350x483.jpg\",\"title\":\"The secrets to getting the lowest home loan rate\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1490188790\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/secrets-getting-lowest-home-loan-rate\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"},{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1489752214:51\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"home-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>When you examine the average Australian house prices in December 2016 (according to the <a href=\\\"http://www.domain.com.au/product/domain-house-price-report-december/\\\">Domain Rental & House Pricing Report</a>) the average price of a house in Sydney is $1,123,991. So it’s no surprise Sydney was ranked the second most expensive city in the world in a recent survey.</p>\\n<p>According to the <a href=\\\"http://www.demographia.com/dhi.pdf\\\">International Housing Affordability Survey</a>, this rating is determined by a ‘Median Multiple’ score, which is the median house price divided by median household income. According to these ratings, any city with a score of 5.1 and over is considered ‘Severely Unaffordable’ and Sydney scored a Median Multiple of 12.2. Melbourne also featured on the top 10 list, scoring a 9.5.</p>\\n<p>Instead of calculating how much we’d have to save to have 20 per cent deposit, we’ve decided to extend our gazes elsewhere and explore 10 cities that are cheaper to live in than Sydney:</p>\\n<ol>\\n<li><strong>London, U.K.</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The U.K.’s largest market, London, has a severely unaffordable Median Multiple of 8.5. If you’re willing to put up with the very un-Sydney-like weather, at least it’s more likely you’ll be more able to afford a house!</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\">\\n<li><strong>New York, U.S.A.</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Yes, even the city that never sleeps is more affordable than Sydney and Melbourne, with a Median Multiple of 5.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\">\\n<li><strong>Vancouver, Canada.</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The most expensive city in Canada is still more affordable than Sydney, with a Median Multiple of 11.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"4\\\">\\n<li><strong>Dublin, Ireland</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Ireland ranks as the most affordable geography in the survey, with the country’s capital of Dublin scoring a Median Multiple of 4.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"5\\\">\\n<li><strong>Tokyo-Yokohama, Japan</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The Greater Tokyo Area is the most populous metropolitan area in the world and still more affordable than Sydney, with a Median Multiple of 4.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"6\\\">\\n<li><strong>Honolulu, U.S.A</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The five housing markets with the poorest housing affordability are in California and Hawaii. Honolulu is the second least affordable American city, with a Median Multiple of 9.4.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"7\\\">\\n<li><strong>Los Angeles, U.S.A</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Speaking of California, the centre of America’s iconic film and television industry, Los Angeles, is also more affordable than Sydney. It has a Median Multiple of 9.3.<strong> </strong></p>\\n<ol start=\\\"8\\\">\\n<li><strong>San Francisco, U.S.A</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The commercial and financial centre of Northern California is currently facing the world’s seventh worst housing bubble risk, and has a Median Multiple of 9.2.</p>\\n<p>If you think this is just a Sydney and Melbourne issue, it’s worth noting that out of Australia’s 54 measurable housing markets, 14 are Seriously Unaffordable, 33 are Severely Unaffordable, 3 are Moderately Unaffordable and only 4 are considered Affordable.</p>\\n<p>While Adelaide may be cheaper to live in than Sydney and Melbourne, it has with a Median Multiple of 6.6 and is the 16<sup>th</sup> least affordable city globally. Brisbane also only has a population of 2 million and is ranked 18<sup>th</sup> least affordable city, with a Median Multiple of 6.2.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">It could be easier than you think</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Can you afford a mortgage?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/can-afford-mortgage\\\">Find out now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"category\":[\"adelaide\",\"Brisbane\",\"home loan\",\"Housing affordability\",\"Melbourne\",\"Sydney\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p>When you examine the average Australian house prices in December 2016 (according to the <a href=\\\"http://www.domain.com.au/product/domain-house-price-report-december/\\\">Domain Rental & House Pricing Report</a>) the average price of a house in Sydney is $1,123,991. So it’s no surprise Sydney was ranked the second most expensive city in the world in a recent survey.</p>\\n<p>According to the <a href=\\\"http://www.demographia.com/dhi.pdf\\\">International Housing Affordability Survey</a>, this rating is determined by a ‘Median Multiple’ score, which is the median house price divided by median household income. According to these ratings, any city with a score of 5.1 and over is considered ‘Severely Unaffordable’ and Sydney scored a Median Multiple of 12.2. Melbourne also featured on the top 10 list, scoring a 9.5.</p>\\n<p>Instead of calculating how much we’d have to save to have 20 per cent deposit, we’ve decided to extend our gazes elsewhere and explore 10 cities that are cheaper to live in than Sydney:</p>\\n<ol>\\n<li><strong>London, U.K.</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The U.K.’s largest market, London, has a severely unaffordable Median Multiple of 8.5. If you’re willing to put up with the very un-Sydney-like weather, at least it’s more likely you’ll be more able to afford a house!</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\">\\n<li><strong>New York, U.S.A.</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Yes, even the city that never sleeps is more affordable than Sydney and Melbourne, with a Median Multiple of 5.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\">\\n<li><strong>Vancouver, Canada.</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The most expensive city in Canada is still more affordable than Sydney, with a Median Multiple of 11.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"4\\\">\\n<li><strong>Dublin, Ireland</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Ireland ranks as the most affordable geography in the survey, with the country’s capital of Dublin scoring a Median Multiple of 4.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"5\\\">\\n<li><strong>Tokyo-Yokohama, Japan</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The Greater Tokyo Area is the most populous metropolitan area in the world and still more affordable than Sydney, with a Median Multiple of 4.7.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"6\\\">\\n<li><strong>Honolulu, U.S.A</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The five housing markets with the poorest housing affordability are in California and Hawaii. Honolulu is the second least affordable American city, with a Median Multiple of 9.4.</p>\\n<ol start=\\\"7\\\">\\n<li><strong>Los Angeles, U.S.A</strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>Speaking of California, the centre of America’s iconic film and television industry, Los Angeles, is also more affordable than Sydney. It has a Median Multiple of 9.3.<strong> </strong></p>\\n<ol start=\\\"8\\\">\\n<li><strong>San Francisco, U.S.A</strong><strong> </strong></li>\\n</ol>\\n<p>The commercial and financial centre of Northern California is currently facing the world’s seventh worst housing bubble risk, and has a Median Multiple of 9.2.</p>\\n<p>If you think this is just a Sydney and Melbourne issue, it’s worth noting that out of Australia’s 54 measurable housing markets, 14 are Seriously Unaffordable, 33 are Severely Unaffordable, 3 are Moderately Unaffordable and only 4 are considered Affordable.</p>\\n<p>While Adelaide may be cheaper to live in than Sydney and Melbourne, it has with a Median Multiple of 6.6 and is the 16<sup>th</sup> least affordable city globally. Brisbane also only has a population of 2 million and is ranked 18<sup>th</sup> least affordable city, with a Median Multiple of 6.2.</p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">It could be easier than you think</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Can you afford a mortgage?</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/can-afford-mortgage\\\">Find out now</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\",\"created_at\":\"1489762707\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"When you examine the average Australian house prices in December 2016 (according to the Domain Rental &#38; House Pricing Report) the average price of a house in Sydney is $1,123,991. So it’s no surprise Sydney was ranked the second most expensive city in the world in a recent survey. According to the International Housing Affordability &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/8-cities-cheaper-live-sydney/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"8 cities that are more affordable than Sydney\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62787\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170317145143/iStock-494607942-724x420.jpg\",\"id\":62787,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/8-cities-cheaper-live-sydney/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62787\",\"pubDate\":\"Fri,
