Bristow\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p><span>Last night’s meeting of the US Federal Reserve increased America’s benchmark interest rate from 0.75% to 1%. Leading up to this widely-forecast increase, finance industry experts predicted that rising US interest rates may influence Australia and other countries where lenders could struggle with increased overseas funding costs, and raise their own interest rates to compensate. </span></p>\\n<p><span>While the most recent meeting of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) left Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-rate-hold-1-5\\\">on hold at 1.5%</a> for the seventh month in a row, without a crystal ball it’s impossible to accurately forecast whether the RBA will increase the <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> in upcoming months or later in the year. However, it is possible that Australian banks and lenders may soon start raising their rates independently of the RBA – and some have already begun.</span></p>\\n<p><span>A recent update to brokers from <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">Bankwest</a> announced that the lender will be increasing fixed and variable interest rates on a variety of investment loans, as well as variable interest rates for some owner occupier home loans. </span></p>\\n<p><span><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">BankWest</a>’s parent, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\\\">Commonwealth Bank</a>, also recently announced that it will be reducing the maximum LVR on several investment loan products. This includes reducing the LVR on its investment home loans from 95% to 90%, effectively doubling the size of the deposit required from new borrowers.  </span></p>\\n<p><span>This follows <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/61989\\\">last month’s changes</a> to CBA and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">BankWest</a>’s investment lending policies, understood to be intended to limit the growth of investment lending to remain compliant with the Australia Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA). </span></p>\\n<p><span>If you’re in the market for a new home loan, or are considering refinancing your existing mortgage, and are concerned about the risk of rising interest rates, there are options available to consider. <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">Fixing the interest rate</a> on your home loan may be able to help insulate you from the worst effects of rising interest rates, and <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/split-loans\\\">split rate loans</a> combine stability with flexibility. You should always carefully consider which options will be the most appropriate for your unique financial situation – if you’re not sure, consult a financial adviser.</span></p>\\n<h3>Fixed rate home loans:</h3>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&h_rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&h_rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&h_rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&h_rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&h_rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&h_rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&h_rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&h_rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&h_rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&h_rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years&nav=fixed-rate-home-loans&group_by=companyName&rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"category\":[\"BankWest\",\"CommBank\",\"Commonwealth Bank\",\"Federal Reserve\",\"interest rates\",\"news\",\"RateCity\",\"rba\",\"reserve bank of australia\",\"US Fed\",\"USA\"],\"content:encoded\":\"<p><span>Last night’s meeting of the US Federal Reserve increased America’s benchmark interest rate from 0.75% to 1%. Leading up to this widely-forecast increase, finance industry experts predicted that rising US interest rates may influence Australia and other countries where lenders could struggle with increased overseas funding costs, and raise their own interest rates to compensate. </span></p>\\n<p><span>While the most recent meeting of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) left Australia’s <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-rate-hold-1-5\\\">on hold at 1.5%</a> for the seventh month in a row, without a crystal ball it’s impossible to accurately forecast whether the RBA will increase the <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\">cash rate</a> in upcoming months or later in the year. However, it is possible that Australian banks and lenders may soon start raising their rates independently of the RBA – and some have already begun.</span></p>\\n<p><span>A recent update to brokers from <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">Bankwest</a> announced that the lender will be increasing fixed and variable interest rates on a variety of investment loans, as well as variable interest rates for some owner occupier home loans. </span></p>\\n<p><span><a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">BankWest</a>’s parent, <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\\\">Commonwealth Bank</a>, also recently announced that it will be reducing the maximum LVR on several investment loan products. This includes reducing the LVR on its investment home loans from 95% to 90%, effectively doubling the size of the deposit required from new borrowers.  </span></p>\\n<p><span>This follows <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/61989\\\">last month’s changes</a> to CBA and <a class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\\\">BankWest</a>’s investment lending policies, understood to be intended to limit the growth of investment lending to remain compliant with the Australia Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA). </span></p>\\n<p><span>If you’re in the market for a new home loan, or are considering refinancing your existing mortgage, and are concerned about the risk of rising interest rates, there are options available to consider. <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/fixed-rate\\\">Fixing the interest rate</a> on your home loan may be able to help insulate you from the worst effects of rising interest rates, and <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/split-loans\\\">split rate loans</a> combine stability with flexibility. You should always carefully consider which options will be the most appropriate for your unique financial situation – if you’re not sure, consult a financial adviser.</span></p>\\n<h3>Fixed rate home loans:</h3>\\n<div class=\\\"rc-embed-widget\\\" data-rc-source=\\\"ratecity\\\" data-rc-url=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/widgets/home-loans/rate-table?h_per_page=4&h_rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&h_rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&h_rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&h_rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&h_rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&h_rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&h_rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&h_rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&h_rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&h_rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&h_rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years&nav=fixed-rate-home-loans&group_by=companyName&rate_type%5B0%5D=Fixed&rate_type%5B1%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20months&rate_type%5B2%5D=Fixed%20-%201%20year&rate_type%5B3%5D=Fixed%20-%202%20years&rate_type%5B4%5D=Fixed%20-%203%20years&rate_type%5B5%5D=Fixed%20-%204%20years&rate_type%5B6%5D=Fixed%20-%205%20years&rate_type%5B7%5D=Fixed%20-%206%20years&rate_type%5B8%5D=Fixed%20-%207%20years&rate_type%5B9%5D=Fixed%20-%209%20years&rate_type%5B10%5D=Fixed%20-%2010%20years\\\"></div>\\n<p><script src=\\\"//blaze.ratecity.com.au/blaze-assets/embedWidget.js\\\" type=\\\"text/javascript\\\"><\\/script></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1489657614\",\"dc:creator\":\"Mark Bristow\",\"description\":\"Last night’s meeting of the US Federal Reserve increased America’s benchmark interest rate from 0.75% to 1%. Leading up to this widely-forecast increase, finance industry experts predicted that rising US interest rates may influence Australia and other countries where lenders could struggle with increased overseas funding costs, and raise their own interest rates to compensate. While the &#8230; <a href=\\\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/will-us-rate-rises-affect-australia/\\\" class=\\\"more-link\\\">Continue reading<span class=\\\"screen-reader-text\\\"> \\\"Will US rate rises affect Australia?\\\"</span></a>\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"false\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=62714\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170316094443/US-Fed-compressor.jpeg\",\"id\":62714,\"inline_featured_image\":\"0\",\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/will-us-rate-rises-affect-australia/\",\"media_release\":null,\"overallRating\":null,\"page_header\":null,\"page_subheader\":null,\"partner_name\":null,\"post_id\":\"62714\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 15 Mar 2017 23:46:54 +0000\",\"publish_until\":null,\"readingTime\":2,\"result_name\":null,\"short_description\":\"Last night’s meeting of the US Federal Reserve increased America’s benchmark interest rate from 0.75% to 1%. Leading up to this widely-forecast increase, finance industry experts predicted that rising US interest rates may influence Australia and other countries where lenders could struggle with increased overseas funding costs, and raise their own interest rates to compensate.\",\"slug\":\"will-us-rate-rises-affect-australia\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"supplierReference\":null,\"supplier_reference\":null,\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170316094443/US-Fed-compressor-350x320.jpeg\",\"title\":\"Will US rate rises affect Australia?\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1489658500\",\"url\":\"/home-loans/mortgage-news/will-us-rate-rises-affect-australia\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\"}],\"personalLoans\":[{\"SEO_Smart_Links\":\"[null,null,\\\"\\\",\\\"\\\",null]\",\"_edit_last\":\"44\",\"_edit_lock\":\"1488162921:44\",\"article_template\":\"default\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"personal-loans\",\"attachments\":null,\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p><span>If you’re considering taking out a personal loan your first thought is usually ‘which of the big banks are the best fit for me?’ </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><span>However, the growing popularity of a new type of lender has been paving the road for alternative ways to take out a personal loan. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>An increasing number of borrowers are turning to P2P lenders for a personal loan. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170206105821/iStock-521087642-e1486342732601.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p><span>P2P lenders are bypassing traditional banks and facilitating a growing number of personal loans.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to look at personal loans now?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare personal loans</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans\\\">Compare</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>Figures released by Veda (Australia and New Zealand’s leading provider of consumer and commercial data and insights) in their <a href=\\\"http://www.veda.com.au/news-media/consumer-credit-demand-strengthens-personal-loan-applications-surge\\\">Quarterly Consumer Credit Demand Index</a> (December 2016 Quarter) have shown an increase of 12.4 percent in personal loan applications compared to their December 2015 Quarter. </span><span> </span></p>\\n<blockquote><p><span>&#8220;Growth in personal loan applications is predominantly coming from products offered by new entrants in the personal lending space, beyond traditional credit card and auto finance markets,&#8221; says Angus Luffman, Veda&#8217;s general manager of consumer risk.</span></p>\\n<p> “These divergent movements suggest that consumers are being circumspect about taking on additional credit. Instead, they are taking advantage of the increased product options on offer to meet their needs.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>What are peer-to-peer lenders?</h3>\\n<p><span>Peer-to-peer (P2P) lenders are online based platforms in which individuals or businesses can apply (and often bid) for a personal loan. They provide a direct link between applicants and investors, cutting out banks from the process.  </span></p>\\n<blockquote><p><span></span><span>&#8220;[But] there is no clear definition of what a peer-to-peer lender is, but what is common to all is that they are digital players,&#8221; Luffman says.</span> </p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3><span>How does it work?</span></h3>\\n<p><span>These P2P lenders work similarly to banks in that you can apply for a personal loan, however your rates are completely personalised based on your unique credit history. There is no fixed interest rate for all applicants.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Unlike traditional banks, investors also have the ability tell peer-to-peer lenders how much money the wish to invest, how long they want to lend the money, and the interest rate they would like. P2P lenders connect you to an investor and facilitate scheduled principal and interest repayments on your loan.</span> </p>\\n<blockquote><p><span>&#8220;They are also very focused on giving the customer the best experience. They tend to use &#8220;risk-based pricing&#8221;, where borrowers with better credit scores pay lower rates of interest than borrowers with lower credit scores. They tend to offer only personal loans.</span></p>\\n<p><span>&#8220;We are seeing a lot of the growth coming from these players,&#8221; Luffman advises.</span> </p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3><span>What are the risks involved?</span></h3>\\n<p><span>P2P lenders prioritise their borrowers and investors security, ensuring the processing of payments are secure and on time. To minimise the likelihood of late payments for their investors they vet all applicants and examine your credit history to determine if you are a reliable borrower</span><span>. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>P2P lenders also typically charge a higher interest rate than you may get from a typical personal loan. It is therefore critical before you apply, you calculate how much you will be expected to pay back.</span> </p>\\n<h3><span>So which type of personal loan should I choose?</span></h3>\\n<p><span>As with traditional banks, it is important to compare your options and examine what is the best rate for you.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Investors with peer-to-peer lenders are not covered by the government&#8217;s guarantee on the first $250,000 on deposit with a bank or credit union. This can mean a higher interest rates set by lenders to compensate. P2P lenders also offer lower loan amounts than banks, usually up to $35,000 for a personal loan, so if you’re looking for a larger sum you may be better off with a bank.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><span>However, traditional banks tend to give you one fixed rate. This means that if you have great credit history you will be charged the same interest rate as someone who does not, which in itself could be a positive or negative based on your personal credit history. This can be an affordable alternative compared to taking a personal loan from a bank.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Also, as it is an online marketplace platform the process of taking out a personal loan can be a lot faster and more convenient than the traditional method.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Personalised rate based on your credit history</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Affordable alternative &#8211; bypasses traditional bank fees and charges.</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Faster and more convenient. </li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Potential higher interest rates set by lenders.</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Loan amount of $35,000 or less.</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span> </span></p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170206111937/iStock-506994242-e1486343991202.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><span>RateCity provides a comprehensive personal loan calculator that we help will guide your decision. Whatever you choose it is clear that P2P lenders are an interesting and dynamic alternative to consider for your personal loan.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Calculate your personal loan and repayments</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Personal loan calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/calculator?nav=personal-loans-calculator\\\">Calculate</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span></span></p>\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p><span>If you’re considering taking out a personal loan your first thought is usually ‘which of the big banks are the best fit for me?’ </span></p>\\n<p><span> </span><span>However, the growing popularity of a new type of lender has been paving the road for alternative ways to take out a personal loan. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>An increasing number of borrowers are turning to P2P lenders for a personal loan. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170206105821/iStock-521087642-e1486342732601.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p><span>P2P lenders are bypassing traditional banks and facilitating a growing number of personal loans.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Want to look at personal loans now?</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Compare personal loans</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans\\\">Compare</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span>Figures released by Veda (Australia and New Zealand’s leading provider of consumer and commercial data and insights) in their <a href=\\\"http://www.veda.com.au/news-media/consumer-credit-demand-strengthens-personal-loan-applications-surge\\\">Quarterly Consumer Credit Demand Index</a> (December 2016 Quarter) have shown an increase of 12.4 percent in personal loan applications compared to their December 2015 Quarter. </span><span> </span></p>\\n<blockquote><p><span>&#8220;Growth in personal loan applications is predominantly coming from products offered by new entrants in the personal lending space, beyond traditional credit card and auto finance markets,&#8221; says Angus Luffman, Veda&#8217;s general manager of consumer risk.</span></p>\\n<p> “These divergent movements suggest that consumers are being circumspect about taking on additional credit. Instead, they are taking advantage of the increased product options on offer to meet their needs.”</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3>What are peer-to-peer lenders?</h3>\\n<p><span>Peer-to-peer (P2P) lenders are online based platforms in which individuals or businesses can apply (and often bid) for a personal loan. They provide a direct link between applicants and investors, cutting out banks from the process.  </span></p>\\n<blockquote><p><span></span><span>&#8220;[But] there is no clear definition of what a peer-to-peer lender is, but what is common to all is that they are digital players,&#8221; Luffman says.</span> </p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3><span>How does it work?</span></h3>\\n<p><span>These P2P lenders work similarly to banks in that you can apply for a personal loan, however your rates are completely personalised based on your unique credit history. There is no fixed interest rate for all applicants.</span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>Unlike traditional banks, investors also have the ability tell peer-to-peer lenders how much money the wish to invest, how long they want to lend the money, and the interest rate they would like. P2P lenders connect you to an investor and facilitate scheduled principal and interest repayments on your loan.</span> </p>\\n<blockquote><p><span>&#8220;They are also very focused on giving the customer the best experience. They tend to use &#8220;risk-based pricing&#8221;, where borrowers with better credit scores pay lower rates of interest than borrowers with lower credit scores. They tend to offer only personal loans.</span></p>\\n<p><span>&#8220;We are seeing a lot of the growth coming from these players,&#8221; Luffman advises.</span> </p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<h3><span>What are the risks involved?</span></h3>\\n<p><span>P2P lenders prioritise their borrowers and investors security, ensuring the processing of payments are secure and on time. To minimise the likelihood of late payments for their investors they vet all applicants and examine your credit history to determine if you are a reliable borrower</span><span>. </span></p>\\n<p><span></span><span>P2P lenders also typically charge a higher interest rate than you may get from a typical personal loan. It is therefore critical before you apply, you calculate how much you will be expected to pay back.</span> </p>\\n<h3><span>So which type of personal loan should I choose?</span></h3>\\n<p><span>As with traditional banks, it is important to compare your options and examine what is the best rate for you.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Investors with peer-to-peer lenders are not covered by the government&#8217;s guarantee on the first $250,000 on deposit with a bank or credit union. This can mean a higher interest rates set by lenders to compensate. P2P lenders also offer lower loan amounts than banks, usually up to $35,000 for a personal loan, so if you’re looking for a larger sum you may be better off with a bank.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<p><span>However, traditional banks tend to give you one fixed rate. This means that if you have great credit history you will be charged the same interest rate as someone who does not, which in itself could be a positive or negative based on your personal credit history. This can be an affordable alternative compared to taking a personal loan from a bank.</span> </p>\\n<p><span>Also, as it is an online marketplace platform the process of taking out a personal loan can be a lot faster and more convenient than the traditional method.</span><span> </span></p>\\n<div class=\\\"pros-cons\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pros col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-up\\\"></span>Pros</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"pros-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Personalised rate based on your credit history</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Affordable alternative &#8211; bypasses traditional bank fees and charges.</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-pro\\\">Faster and more convenient. </li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"cons col-sm-6\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"pro-con-header\\\">\\n<h5 class=\\\"floating-title\\\"><span class=\\\"fa fa-thumbs-o-down\\\"></span>Cons</h5>\\n</div>\\n<ul id=\\\"cons-section\\\">\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Potential higher interest rates set by lenders.</li>\\n<li class=\\\"example-con\\\">Loan amount of $35,000 or less.</li>\\n</ul>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span> </span></p>\\n<p><img style=\\\"width: 100%;\\\" class=\\\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\\\" alt=\\\"istock_79305201_small5\\\" src=\\\"http://production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170206111937/iStock-506994242-e1486343991202.jpg\\\" /></p>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><span>RateCity provides a comprehensive personal loan calculator that we help will guide your decision. Whatever you choose it is clear that P2P lenders are an interesting and dynamic alternative to consider for your personal loan.</span></p>\\n<div>\\n<div class=\\\"link-bar\\\">\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-7\\\">\\n<h6 id=\\\"btn-subtitle-test\\\">Calculate your personal loan and repayments</h6>\\n<h3 id=\\\"btn-title-test\\\">Personal loan calculator</h3>\\n</div>\\n<div class=\\\"col-sm-5 text-right\\\"><a class=\\\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\\\" id=\\\"btn-test\\\" href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/calculator?nav=personal-loans-calculator\\\">Calculate</a></div>\\n</div>\\n</div>\\n<p><span></span></p>\",\"created_at\":\"1486380855\",\"dc:creator\":\"Alex Ritchie\",\"description\":\"If you’re considering taking out a personal loan your first thought is usually ‘which of the big banks are the best fit for me?’  However, the growing popularity of a new type of lender has been paving the road for alternative ways to take out a personal loan. penalty infringements.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"ASIC orders Cash Converters to pay out $12 million\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"personal-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/655d7e0698b4208ced875c98ddae1987?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>An ASIC investigation into payday lender Cash Convertors has found that $10.8 million must be refunded to consumers who were wrongfully issued loans and a further $1.35 million will be paid to ASIC in penalty infringements.</p>\\n<p>The probe by ASIC found that Cash Convertors, through their website, had approved loans for consumers without verifying their expenses in accordance with responsible lending obligations.</p>\\n<p>It has been revealed that loan applications were being approved on an internally-generated assumed benchmark as opposed to any real information about the expenses of the consumer.</p>\\n<p>This is the latest in a string of infringements that payday lenders have been charged with including the $1.5 million lender Nimble was forced to pay back earlier this year.</p>\\n<p>The payday lending industry has effectively been on notice by ASIC since last year but it seems not much has changed. So if you do find yourself in desperate need of some cash, here are some safer alternatives you can turn to.</p>\\n<p><strong>Alternatives to a payday loan</strong></p>\\n<p>1. Speak to your utility provider or bank as soon as you think you will have an issue</p>\\n<p>If you need money fast to pay a looming bill that you don&rsquo;t have the cash for your first call should be to the bill provider. This includes if you are worried about making a mortgage repayment. Your bank or utility provider will be able to discuss a hardship payment plan with you that can help you avoid defaulting on a payment and protect your overall credit score.</p>\\n<p>2. Look into a no interest loan</p>\\n<p>If you are a low income earner who needs to borrow money to pay for essentials such as household goods or medical bills you could qualify for a no interest loan. As the name suggests, these loans will help you out when you&rsquo;re in a financial bind without leaving you with the extra interest charges that can make the debt so hard to repay. For more information, you can visit the <a href=\\\"http://goodshepherdmicrofinance.org.au/services/no-interest-loan-scheme-nils/\\\">Good Shepherd Microfinance website</a>.</p>\\n<p>3. Ask for an advance on your Centrelink payment</p>\\n<p>If you receive Centrelink payments, you may be eligible to apply for an advanced payment to cover emergency costs. To see if you are eligible, contact the Department of Human Services.</p>\\n<p><strong>What not to do</strong></p>\\n<p>If you do need money fast the most important thing to do is to avoid taking out a loan you know you can&rsquo;t afford. Even if the lender approves the loan, but you have your reservations about how you will repay the loan before the interest kicks in, you should walk away.</p>\\n<p>It is also important to avoid applying for multiple loans from different lenders if you know you have a poor credit rating. Attempting to get a personal loan from a standard lender when the chances of you being approved are slim will only further damage your credit score with each rejected application.</p>\\n<p>For more information on how payday loans operate, and what to look out for, take a look at the <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/payday-loans\\\">MoneySmart website</a>.</p>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/asic-orders-cash-converters-to-pay-out-12-million/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>An ASIC investigation into payday lender Cash Convertors has found that $10.8 million must be refunded to consumers who were wrongfully issued loans and a further $1.35 million will be paid to ASIC in penalty infringements.</p>\\n<p>The probe by ASIC found that Cash Convertors, through their website, had approved loans for consumers without verifying their expenses in accordance with responsible lending obligations.</p>\\n<p>It has been revealed that loan applications were being approved on an internally-generated assumed benchmark as opposed to any real information about the expenses of the consumer.</p>\\n<p>This is the latest in a string of infringements that payday lenders have been charged with including the $1.5 million lender Nimble was forced to pay back earlier this year.</p>\\n<p>The payday lending industry has effectively been on notice by ASIC since last year but it seems not much has changed. So if you do find yourself in desperate need of some cash, here are some safer alternatives you can turn to.</p>\\n<p><strong>Alternatives to a payday loan</strong></p>\\n<p>1. Speak to your utility provider or bank as soon as you think you will have an issue</p>\\n<p>If you need money fast to pay a looming bill that you don&rsquo;t have the cash for your first call should be to the bill provider. This includes if you are worried about making a mortgage repayment. Your bank or utility provider will be able to discuss a hardship payment plan with you that can help you avoid defaulting on a payment and protect your overall credit score.</p>\\n<p>2. Look into a no interest loan</p>\\n<p>If you are a low income earner who needs to borrow money to pay for essentials such as household goods or medical bills you could qualify for a no interest loan. As the name suggests, these loans will help you out when you&rsquo;re in a financial bind without leaving you with the extra interest charges that can make the debt so hard to repay. For more information, you can visit the <a href=\\\"http://goodshepherdmicrofinance.org.au/services/no-interest-loan-scheme-nils/\\\">Good Shepherd Microfinance website</a>.</p>\\n<p>3. Ask for an advance on your Centrelink payment</p>\\n<p>If you receive Centrelink payments, you may be eligible to apply for an advanced payment to cover emergency costs. To see if you are eligible, contact the Department of Human Services.</p>\\n<p><strong>What not to do</strong></p>\\n<p>If you do need money fast the most important thing to do is to avoid taking out a loan you know you can&rsquo;t afford. Even if the lender approves the loan, but you have your reservations about how you will repay the loan before the interest kicks in, you should walk away.</p>\\n<p>It is also important to avoid applying for multiple loans from different lenders if you know you have a poor credit rating. Attempting to get a personal loan from a standard lender when the chances of you being approved are slim will only further damage your credit score with each rejected application.</p>\\n<p>For more information on how payday loans operate, and what to look out for, take a look at the <a href=\\\"https://www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit/payday-loans\\\">MoneySmart website</a>.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1478726171\",\"dc:creator\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"description\":\"An ASIC investigation into payday lender Cash Convertors has found that $10.8 million must be penalty infringements.\",\"meta_title\":\"ASIC orders Cash Converters to pay out $12 million\",\"overallRating\":null,\"post_id\":\"59080\",\"pubDate\":\"Wed, 09 Nov 2016 11:16:11 +0000\",\"readingTime\":3,\"short_description\":\"An ASIC investigation into payday lender Cash Convertors has found that $10.8 million must be refunded to consumers who were wrongfully issued loans and a further $1.35 million will be paid to ASIC in penalty infringements.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"asic-orders-cash-converters-to-pay-out-12-million\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3762/iStock_91802599_SMALL.jpg\",\"title\":\"ASIC orders Cash Converters to pay out $12 million\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1478726171\",\"url\":\"/personal-loans/news/asic-orders-cash-converters-to-pay-out-12-million\",\"uses_markdown\":\"FALSE\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/asic-orders-cash-converters-to-pay-out-12-million/feed/\"},{\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"With interest rates so low and property price growth continuing at a steady pace now may be a great time to renovate your property findings from a Housing Industry Association survey show.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Is now the time to renovate your home?\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"personal-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/328eb658853e1e60ee4b7080fb10121a?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"RateCity Staff\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>With interest rates so low and property price growth continuing at a steady pace now may be a great time to renovate your property findings from a Housing Industry Association survey show.</p>\\n<p>Whether it is for your own enjoyment or to attract potential buyers, borrowing to complete a renovation has rarely been this cheap with the historic low <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> keeping borrowers happy around the country.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Our renovations market survey also indicates that the price of houses in Sydney and Melbourne is persuading homeowners previously considering moving house to instead embark on major renovation projects in their current homes,&rdquo; explained Shane Garrett, HIA Senior Economist.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Overall, we anticipate that renovations activity will continue to grow modestly over the next few years and take up some of the slack that will result from weaker levels of new home building.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related stories</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/should-i-borrow-money-to-tick-things-off-my-bucket-list\\\">Should I borrow money to tick off things on my bucket list?</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/bathroom-bliss-funding-the-renovation-of-your-dreams\\\">Bathroom bliss: Funding the renovation of your dreams</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/personal-loans-vs-credit-cards\\\">Personal loans vs credit cards</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>With annual home renovations expenditure topping $31 billion, the sector packs quite a punch across the Australian economy,&rdquo; concluded Garrett.</p>\\n<p>The latest HIA Renovations Roundup reports that the volume of renovation activity increased by 4.7 per cent in 2015, the strongest growth since 2010.</p>\\n<p>If you&rsquo;re considering doing a renovation on your own property, or buying a property that needs some fixing up, you may be wondering what the best way to finance the cost will be.</p>\\n<p>Here are some options to consider:</p>\\n<p><strong>Take out a personal loan</strong></p>\\n<p>A personal loan can help you finance your renovation by giving you access to the money you need at a reasonable interest rate. If you are planning to pay off the debt fairly quickly then this could be a good option for you. Shopping around for a competitive interest rate before settling on a loan will ensure you pay no more interest than necessary.</p>\\n<p><strong>Use your mortgage</strong></p>\\n<p>If you have equity built into your property, then redrawing on your mortgage could be a good way to finance a renovation. If your mortgage offers this redraw feature and you&rsquo;re on a good interest rate, then this could be a cheap way of accessing money for a renovation. &nbsp;The potential down side to this is that if you don&rsquo;t pay the balance back in a short time frame you will end up paying a lot more in interest stretched over the loan term.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links&nbsp;</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans?nav=personal-loans\\\">Compare personal loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans?nav=home-loans\\\">Compare home loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans?nav=car-loans\\\">Compare car loans</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/is-now-the-time-to-renovate-your-home/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>With interest rates so low and property price growth continuing at a steady pace now may be a great time to renovate your property findings from a Housing Industry Association survey show.</p>\\n<p>Whether it is for your own enjoyment or to attract potential buyers, borrowing to complete a renovation has rarely been this cheap with the historic low <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> keeping borrowers happy around the country.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Our renovations market survey also indicates that the price of houses in Sydney and Melbourne is persuading homeowners previously considering moving house to instead embark on major renovation projects in their current homes,&rdquo; explained Shane Garrett, HIA Senior Economist.</p>\\n<p>&ldquo;Overall, we anticipate that renovations activity will continue to grow modestly over the next few years and take up some of the slack that will result from weaker levels of new home building.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related stories</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/should-i-borrow-money-to-tick-things-off-my-bucket-list\\\">Should I borrow money to tick off things on my bucket list?</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/bathroom-bliss-funding-the-renovation-of-your-dreams\\\">Bathroom bliss: Funding the renovation of your dreams</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/personal-loans-vs-credit-cards\\\">Personal loans vs credit cards</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>With annual home renovations expenditure topping $31 billion, the sector packs quite a punch across the Australian economy,&rdquo; concluded Garrett.</p>\\n<p>The latest HIA Renovations Roundup reports that the volume of renovation activity increased by 4.7 per cent in 2015, the strongest growth since 2010.</p>\\n<p>If you&rsquo;re considering doing a renovation on your own property, or buying a property that needs some fixing up, you may be wondering what the best way to finance the cost will be.</p>\\n<p>Here are some options to consider:</p>\\n<p><strong>Take out a personal loan</strong></p>\\n<p>A personal loan can help you finance your renovation by giving you access to the money you need at a reasonable interest rate. If you are planning to pay off the debt fairly quickly then this could be a good option for you. Shopping around for a competitive interest rate before settling on a loan will ensure you pay no more interest than necessary.</p>\\n<p><strong>Use your mortgage</strong></p>\\n<p>If you have equity built into your property, then redrawing on your mortgage could be a good way to finance a renovation. If your mortgage offers this redraw feature and you&rsquo;re on a good interest rate, then this could be a cheap way of accessing money for a renovation. &nbsp;The potential down side to this is that if you don&rsquo;t pay the balance back in a short time frame you will end up paying a lot more in interest stretched over the loan term.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>This week will be a big one for the heads of Australia&rsquo;s Big Four banks who will be facing the Federal Parliament&rsquo;s House of Representatives Economic Committee for a review of the way in which they balance the needs of customers, shareholders and the broader community.</p>\\n<p>The banks have been embroiled in various scandals over the past year including those involving life insurance policies and their failure to pass <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> cuts on to home loan borrowers. There have been calls from the Labour party to conduct a Royal Commission into the banking sector and this review will give the banks a chance to try and prove that it would not be&nbsp;necessary.&nbsp;</p>\\n<p>The review will take place over the next three days with the head of each major bank having their chance to explain&nbsp;their position. It is hoped that this will give the public a chance to understand some of the banking industry&#39;s&nbsp;decisions that have recently been called into question.&nbsp;</p>\\n<p>The four main topics highlighted for discussion by the committee are the international and domestic market developments that relate to the Australian banking sector; developments in prudential regulation and how these will affect Australian banks; the cost of funds impacts on margins and the basis for bank pricing decisions; and how banks are currently responding to previously raised issues such as enhancing consumer protection, government reforms and actions by regulators.</p>\\n<p>There&rsquo;s a lot of material for the review to get through over three days and for customers it may be hard to follow exactly what implications these discussions will have on their bottom line until the reviews conclusion.</p>\\n<p>Borrowers and savers alike no doubt have their own grievances to air with the Big 4. Also, with Australia currently having the largest amount of household debt of any developed nation, and most of this debt being tied up with the Big 4 Banks, it&rsquo;s fair to say that making sure we have transparency and regulation across the sector is absolutely necessary.</p>\\n<p>For customers around the nation, answers to questions like what sort of commission are bank workers getting for selling us loans and why won&rsquo;t the bank pass us our full rate cut on our home loans but savers get their interest rates slashed repeatedly, will be eagerly awaited.</p>\\n<p>This graph from the ABC also shows a worrying trend in that our personal debt, far from being paid off, is being shifted into other banking products, most likely to be paid back over longer terms.</p>\\n<p><iframe allowfullscreen=\\\"\\\" allowtransparency=\\\"true\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" height=\\\"400\\\" mozallowfullscreen=\\\"\\\" msallowfullscreen=\\\"\\\" oallowfullscreen=\\\"\\\" src=\\\"//d3bo5ucoqkgs8h.cloudfront.net/cnXoq/2/\\\" webkitallowfullscreen=\\\"\\\" width=\\\"548\\\"></iframe></p>\\n<p>And while the amount of debt we take on may be considered our own &ldquo;fault&rdquo; what about the way in which new credit cards, credit increases and other such banking products a marketed to vulnerable customers?</p>\\n<p>The next three days will hopefully provide some insights into the way the banks view these issues and what customers can expect going forward.</p>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/big-4-banks-face-government-review/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>This week will be a big one for the heads of Australia&rsquo;s Big Four banks who will be facing the Federal Parliament&rsquo;s House of Representatives Economic Committee for a review of the way in which they balance the needs of customers, shareholders and the broader community.</p>\\n<p>The banks have been embroiled in various scandals over the past year including those involving life insurance policies and their failure to pass <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">cash rate</a> cuts on to home loan borrowers. There have been calls from the Labour party to conduct a Royal Commission into the banking sector and this review will give the banks a chance to try and prove that it would not be&nbsp;necessary.&nbsp;</p>\\n<p>The review will take place over the next three days with the head of each major bank having their chance to explain&nbsp;their position. It is hoped that this will give the public a chance to understand some of the banking industry&#39;s&nbsp;decisions that have recently been called into question.&nbsp;</p>\\n<p>The four main topics highlighted for discussion by the committee are the international and domestic market developments that relate to the Australian banking sector; developments in prudential regulation and how these will affect Australian banks; the cost of funds impacts on margins and the basis for bank pricing decisions; and how banks are currently responding to previously raised issues such as enhancing consumer protection, government reforms and actions by regulators.</p>\\n<p>There&rsquo;s a lot of material for the review to get through over three days and for customers it may be hard to follow exactly what implications these discussions will have on their bottom line until the reviews conclusion.</p>\\n<p>Borrowers and savers alike no doubt have their own grievances to air with the Big 4. Also, with Australia currently having the largest amount of household debt of any developed nation, and most of this debt being tied up with the Big 4 Banks, it&rsquo;s fair to say that making sure we have transparency and regulation across the sector is absolutely necessary.</p>\\n<p>For customers around the nation, answers to questions like what sort of commission are bank workers getting for selling us loans and why won&rsquo;t the bank pass us our full rate cut on our home loans but savers get their interest rates slashed repeatedly, will be eagerly awaited.</p>\\n<p>This graph from the ABC also shows a worrying trend in that our personal debt, far from being paid off, is being shifted into other banking products, most likely to be paid back over longer terms.</p>\\n<p><iframe provide some insights into the way the banks view these issues and what customers can expect going forward.</p>\",\"created_at\":\"1475553871\",\"dc:creator\":\"Patricia community.\",\"exclusive_to_partner\":\"true\",\"guid\":{\"$t\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/big-4-banks-face-government-review/\",\"isPermaLink\":\"false\"},\"has_video\":\"false\",\"header_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3747/iStock_102534481_SMALL.jpg\",\"id\":57706,\"link\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/big-4-banks-face-government-review/\",\"meta_description\":\"This week will be a big one for the heads of Australia's Big Four banks who will be facing the Federal Parliament's House of Representatives Economic Committee for a review of the way in which they balance the needs of customers, shareholders and the broader community.\",\"meta_title\":\"Big 4 Banks face government review\",\"overallRating\":null,\"post_id\":\"57706\",\"pubDate\":\"Mon, 03 Oct 2016 18:04:31 +0000\",\"readingTime\":3,\"short_description\":\"This week will be a big one for the heads of Australia's Big Four banks who will be facing the Federal Parliament's House of Representatives Economic Committee for a review of the way in which they balance the needs of customers, shareholders and the broader community.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"big-4-banks-face-government-review\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3747/iStock_102534481_SMALL.jpg\",\"title\":\"Big 4 Banks face government review\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1475553871\",\"url\":\"/personal-loans/news/big-4-banks-face-government-review\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/big-4-banks-face-government-review/feed/\"},{\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"Being able to access money fast in an emergency by taking out a personal loan can be tricky if you receive Centrelink payments as part of your income. Although still possible there are some important things to know before signing up for a loan and some other options that may be more appropriate for your situation.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Can I get a personal loan if I receive Centrelink payments?\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"personal-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/655d7e0698b4208ced875c98ddae1987?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>Being able to access money fast in an emergency by taking out a personal loan can be tricky if you receive Centrelink payments as part of your income.</p>\\n<p>Although still possible there are some important things to know before signing up for a loan and some other options that may be more appropriate for your situation.</p>\\n<p><strong>What do I need to know?</strong></p>\\n<p>A big factor in whether or not you will be able to be approved for a loan is what percentage of your income is from Centrelink payments. If less than 50% of your income is from payments it may be easier to secure a loan than you think. Online lenders such as Good to Go Loans and Ferratum will lend to Centrelink customers and can be approved online, sometimes without a credit check, depending on the amount.</p>\\n<p>Of course these sorts of loans come with major interest rates and you could end up paying more than double what you borrowed depending on how long you take to pay back the loan. Good to Go Loans estimates that if you take out a $2000 loan online and pay it back within six months you will pay an extra $960 in interest with weekly repayments of $113.85.</p>\\n<p>Also keep in mind that applying and being knocked back from too many loans will affect your credit rating negatively. To avoid this, make sure you enquire about whether they accept people who receive Centrelink payments and if your credit history will be checked before applying if you are concerned about a bad credit history. &nbsp;</p>\\n<p><strong>What are some alternatives?</strong></p>\\n<p>There are some alternatives to taking out a personal loan if you are in need of some cash that could be more appropriate for your situation.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<blockquote>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation/news/australia-s-pension-system-ranks-high-but-has-a-hazy-future\\\">Australia&#39;s pension system ranks high but has a hazy future</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation/news/can-i-use-my-super-funds-if-i-get-sick\\\">Can I use my super funds if I get sick?</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/guide\\\">Personal loans guide</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p><em>Centrelink advance</em></p>\\n<p>If you have been receiving your Centrelink payment for 3 months you may be eligible to apply for an advance on your payments if you do not have an outstanding debt to the Australian government. The number of advance payments will vary depending on the type that you receive and your personal circumstances. Speak to a representative from Centrelink for more information on this option.</p>\\n<p><em>Overdraft</em></p>\\n<p>If you have an existing good relationship with your bank and an overdraft option available on your bank account you may be able to use this as a way of accessing credit in an emergency. You will have to talk to your bank about how much money you can be approved to borrow and note that you will be charged interest on that amount, possibly at a high rate.</p>\\n<p><em>NILS</em></p>\\n<p>NILS (no interest loan scheme) are available to help low income earners with access to small amounts of credit ($300-$1200) in emergencies. The benefits of accessing credit through the scheme are that you will not be charged interest and your repayments will be planned out in a way that is affordable to you. You will only be approved for a loan under the scheme if the item falls into the essentials category such as medical procedures, broken down appliances or school supplies.</p>\\n<p>If this sounds like it best suits your needs then it is well worth pursuing this option. The only criteria to qualify are that you hold a pension/ health care card, have been residing in your current premises for 3 months or longer and you show a willingness and the ability to repay the loan over time.</p>\\n<p><em>Other options</em></p>\\n<p>If a NILS loan doesn&rsquo;t suit your needs and you are hesitant to take out a personal loan there are other options available to you in the form of programs for low income earners. These programs will assess your application against a range of criteria to see if you&rsquo;re eligible but your status as a Centrelink customer will not be a barrier to receiving a loan.</p>\\n<p>Some options include StepUP and AddsUP loans that are available through lenders such as&nbsp;Good Shepherd Microfinance. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><strong>What if the loan is for a utility bill?</strong></p>\\n<p>If the reason you need to take out a loan is to pay a utility bill then stop what you&rsquo;re doing, there&rsquo;s a better way. By law, utility providers need to have someone on hand to consult with you if you&rsquo;re facing hardship and come up with an alternative payment plan. Contact your utility provider as soon as possible if you think you will be having trouble paying your bill for the month, sort out a plan and avoid a costly high interest rate loan.&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/personal-loans-for-457-visa-holders-in-australia\\\">Personal loans for 457 visa holders</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans?nav=personal-loans\\\">Compare personal loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/bad-credit-car-loans\\\">Bad credit car loans</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/can-i-get-a-personal-loan-if-i-receive-centrelink-payments/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>Being able to access money fast in an emergency by taking out a personal loan can be tricky if you receive Centrelink payments as part of your income.</p>\\n<p>Although still possible there are some important things to know before signing up for a loan and some other options that may be more appropriate for your situation.</p>\\n<p><strong>What do I need to know?</strong></p>\\n<p>A big factor in whether or not you will be able to be approved for a loan is what percentage of your income is from Centrelink payments. If less than 50% of your income is from payments it may be easier to secure a loan than you think. Online lenders such as Good to Go Loans and Ferratum will lend to Centrelink customers and can be approved online, sometimes without a credit check, depending on the amount.</p>\\n<p>Of course these sorts of loans come with major interest rates and you could end up paying more than double what you borrowed depending on how long you take to pay back the loan. Good to Go Loans estimates that if you take out a $2000 loan online and pay it back within six months you will pay an extra $960 in interest with weekly repayments of $113.85.</p>\\n<p>Also keep in mind that applying and being knocked back from too many loans will affect your credit rating negatively. To avoid this, make sure you enquire about whether they accept people who receive Centrelink payments and if your credit history will be checked before applying if you are concerned about a bad credit history. &nbsp;</p>\\n<p><strong>What are some alternatives?</strong></p>\\n<p>There are some alternatives to taking out a personal loan if you are in need of some cash that could be more appropriate for your situation.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n</blockquote>\\n<blockquote>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation/news/australia-s-pension-system-ranks-high-but-has-a-hazy-future\\\">Australia&#39;s pension system ranks high but has a hazy future</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/superannuation/news/can-i-use-my-super-funds-if-i-get-sick\\\">Can I use my super funds if I get sick?</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/guide\\\">Personal loans guide</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p><em>Centrelink advance</em></p>\\n<p>If you have been receiving your Centrelink payment for 3 months you may be eligible to apply for an advance on your payments if you do not have an outstanding debt to the Australian government. The number of advance payments will vary depending on the type that you receive and your personal circumstances. Speak to a representative from Centrelink for more information on this option.</p>\\n<p><em>Overdraft</em></p>\\n<p>If you have an existing good relationship with your bank and an overdraft option available on your bank account you may be able to use this as a way of accessing credit in an emergency. You will have to talk to your bank about how much money you can be approved to borrow and note that you will be charged interest on that amount, possibly at a high rate.</p>\\n<p><em>NILS</em></p>\\n<p>NILS (no interest loan scheme) are available to help low income earners with access to small amounts of credit ($300-$1200) in emergencies. The benefits of accessing credit through the scheme are that you will not be charged interest and your repayments will be planned out in a way that is affordable to you. You will only be approved for a loan under the scheme if the item falls into the essentials category such as medical procedures, broken down appliances or school supplies.</p>\\n<p>If this sounds like it best suits your needs then it is well worth pursuing this option. The only criteria to qualify are that you hold a pension/ health care card, have been residing in your current premises for 3 months or longer and you show a willingness and the ability to repay the loan over time.</p>\\n<p><em>Other options</em></p>\\n<p>If a NILS loan doesn&rsquo;t suit your needs and you are hesitant to take out a personal loan there are other options available to you in the form of programs for low income earners. These programs will assess your application against a range of criteria to see if you&rsquo;re eligible but your status as a Centrelink customer will not be a barrier to receiving a loan.</p>\\n<p>Some options include StepUP and AddsUP loans that are available through lenders such as&nbsp;Good Shepherd Microfinance. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\\n<p><strong>What if the loan is for a utility bill?</strong></p>\\n<p>If the reason you need to take out a loan is to pay a utility bill then stop what you&rsquo;re doing, there&rsquo;s a better way. By law, utility providers need to have someone on hand to consult with you if you&rsquo;re facing hardship and come up with an alternative payment plan. Contact your utility provider as soon as possible if you think you will be having trouble paying your bill for the month, sort out a plan and avoid a costly high interest rate loan.&nbsp;</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/personal-loans-for-457-visa-holders-in-australia\\\">Personal loans for taking out a personal loan can be tricky if you receive Centrelink payments as part of your income. \\n\\nAlthough still possible there are some important things to know before signing up for a loan and some other options that may be more appropriate for your situation.\",\"slash:comments\":\"0\",\"slug\":\"can-i-get-a-personal-loan-if-i-receive-centrelink-payments\",\"status\":\"publish\",\"the_article_type\":\"news\",\"thumbnail_image_url\":\"http://cdn.ratecity.com.au/article/news/3664/iStock_000071253053_Small.jpg\",\"title\":\"Can I get a personal loan if I receive Centrelink payments?\",\"type\":\"article\",\"updated_at\":\"1454461770\",\"url\":\"/personal-loans/news/can-i-get-a-personal-loan-if-i-receive-centrelink-payments\",\"uses_markdown\":\"false\",\"wfw:commentRss\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/can-i-get-a-personal-loan-if-i-receive-centrelink-payments/feed/\"},{\"_yoast_wpseo_metadesc\":\"If you're a little strapped for cash in your adopted home there's good news regarding access to personal loans; it is possible. However, there are special conditions that apply that are worth noting before you commit to taking out a loan and they vary from lender to lender.\",\"_yoast_wpseo_title\":\"Personal loans for 457 visa holders in Australia\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"personal-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/655d7e0698b4208ced875c98ddae1987?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Patricia Babalis\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>If you&rsquo;re a little strapped for cash in your adopted home there&rsquo;s good news regarding access to personal loans; it is possible. However, there are special conditions that apply that are worth noting before you commit to taking out a loan and they vary from lender to lender.</p>\\n<p>When you apply for a loan Australian lenders won&rsquo;t be able to access your credit history from overseas so the good news is, if you&rsquo;ve had a rocky past that doesn&rsquo;t limit your chances of being accepted.</p>\\n<p>There are of course other restrictions and most lenders won&rsquo;t look at your application unless you have secure employment in Australia, an income of $50,000 p.a or more, an Australian bank account and the ability to repay the loan before your visa expires. You may also be limited in your choice of loan as non-residents are not eligible for all financial products and the interest rates are generally higher for the ones that are available unless you&rsquo;re securing the loan against an asset like a car.</p>\\n<p>But don&rsquo;t let this discourage you. If you meet the requirements of the lender taking out a personal or car loan can be quite easy. Some of Australia&rsquo;s biggest banks have loans on offer for visa holders from the <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Commonwealth Bank</a> to St George and if you&rsquo;re visiting from England ex-pat forums seem to have their money on <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\" class=\\\"rc-keyword\\\">Westpac</a> for approving 457 visa holder loans in a fast and easy way.</p>\\n<p>Failing acceptance of a loan directly by a bank there are still options available to you. Using a third party consultant could be an option in securing the extra cash you need. Company&rsquo;s such as FastLane Finance or Gold Vision Financial Services offer to approach lenders for you and use their experience and connections in the finance industry to secure you a loan with a reasonable interest rate.</p>\\n<p>The advantage of going through a third party lender is that they can approach multiple lenders and take the hard work out of searching for a loan. The downside is that you will be charged a fee for their services so make sure you clarify up front how much the fee will be so you can calculate it into your total costs.</p>\\n<p>Keep in mind also that these companies generally work on a commission basis. While it is illegal for them to offer you a product that is unsuitable to your needs it is still important to be wary of the loans being offered to you. If the interest rate seems ridiculously high and they are charging exorbitant fees then those are clear signs to stay away. As a guide the average interest rate for an unsecured loan in 2015 was 13.79 per cent.</p>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/personal-loans-vs-credit-cards\\\">Personal loans vs. Credit cards</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/loans-with-no-interest-attached\\\">Loans with no interest attached</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/news/how-to-escape-the-debt-trap\\\">How to escape the debt trap</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>Alternative credit providers are also available, such as Fair Go Finance, who can finance a loan of up to $5000 which can be applied for online. As the name suggests they are willing to assess all requests, including those of visa holders, and have criteria that can be considered more lenient than banks. This may be a good option for some visa holders if you meet the basic requirements of having an income of $500 a week and can repay the loan during the life of your visa. &nbsp;Depending on the amount you borrow and the risk you are deemed to be interest rates can vary quite a bit. The site says interest rates can range from 0 per cent to 29.9 per cent and monthly fees can be anywhere from $5-$80. &nbsp;</p>\\n<p><em>Build up your credit history in Australia</em></p>\\n<p>If you&rsquo;re having trouble getting a loan from scratch, try building up your credit history while you&rsquo;re here to give you a better chance of being accepted for a personal loan. While they might not be counting your credit history from home it will be important to show that since you&rsquo;ve come to Australia you&rsquo;ve been keeping on top of things. An easy way to do this is to show that you can keep a regular payment commitment. Paying off something small like your mobile phone bill on time and consistently is a good start.</p>\\n<p>Staying in the same job for a while will also show you have a stable place of employment and are less of a risk for lenders. Another suggestion could be to take out a credit card with the bank you wish to borrow from. Pay off your total debts on time each month and you will have more of a bargaining chip when it comes to requesting a loan.</p>\\n<p><em>Starting point</em></p>\\n<p>No matter which loan you choose to get you on your feet during your time in Australia it is always important to make sure that it is a competitive one. Don&rsquo;t feel pressured into taking on a high interest rate loan without first comparing what&rsquo;s on the market for visa holders and making some enquiries.</p>\\n<p>Here are some loans listed on RateCity that you may wish to look into to start your search for a personal loan. Keep in mind that approval for these loans is at the discretion of the provider.</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/commonwealth-bank/variable-personal-loan-unsecured\\\">Commonwealth Bank Fixed Rate Personal Loan &#8211; Unsecured</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/bank-of-melbourne/unsecured-fixed-personal-loan\\\">Bank of Melbourne Personal Loan &#8211; Unsecured</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/st-george-bank/unsecured-fixed-personal-loan\\\">St George Personal Loan &#8211; Unsecured</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n<blockquote>\\n<p>Related links</p>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans?nav=personal-loans\\\">Compare personal loans</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/calculator?nav=personal-loans-calculator\\\">Personal loans calculator</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/guide?nav=personal-loans-guide\\\">Personal loans guide</a></li>\\n</ul>\\n</blockquote>\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/personal-loans-for-457-visa-holders-in-australia/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>If you&rsquo;re a little strapped for cash in your adopted home there&rsquo;s good news regarding access to personal loans; it is possible. Personal loans vs. credit cards\",\"article_type\":\"news\",\"article_vertical\":\"personal-loans\",\"author_description\":null,\"author_image\":\"http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/d42bd80f1c68d3c2cd9d46501aaedba6?s=96&d=mm&r=g\",\"author_job_title\":null,\"author_name\":\"Laine Gordon\",\"author_twitter\":null,\"body\":\"<p>If you need additional funds for any reason, a personal loan can be customised to suit your needs.</p>\\n<p><iframe allowfullscreen=\\\"\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" height=\\\"315\\\" src=\\\"//www.youtube.com/embed/MJQe4TfnddM?rel=0\\\" width=\\\"560\\\"></iframe></p>\\n<p>You can borrow a sum and repay it weekly, fortnightly or monthly over a loan term from a year to several years. It can be a much faster way to cover your costs than added them to your home loan or putting in on your credit card.</p>\\n<p>Typically personal loans have lower interest rates and fees than many credit cards, store cards and other lending schemes so it can be a more cost-effective and manageable way to get the things you want.</p>\\n<p>Unlike a credit card, with a personal loan you agree to repay the balance within an agreed timeframe, which can be great if you need some discipline to clearing debt. It can also save you a lot of money in interest!</p>\\n<p>Like cards, personal loans have definite upsides.&nbsp; The time and paperwork involved in applying for a loan also makes impulse buys less likely, and while you won&rsquo;t get the benefit of interest-free days, the combination of cheaper rates, fixed repayments and a set term can make personal loans a better value option for some people.</p>\\n<p>To learn more about personal loans click through to our complete <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/guide\\\">step-by-step guides</a>. Next step &#8211; <a href=\\\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eHNOx_x22c8&list=TLzRQ4zRHSFv4_uXiADXtO6dm2_8iFuTB7&index=3\\\">what type of personal loan do you need?</a>&nbsp;</p>\",\"comments\":\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/video-guide-personal-loans-vs-credit-cards/#respond\",\"content:encoded\":\"<p>If you need additional funds for any reason, a personal loan can be customised to suit your needs.</p>\\n<p><iframe allowfullscreen=\\\"\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" height=\\\"315\\\" src=\\\"//www.youtube.com/embed/MJQe4TfnddM?rel=0\\\" width=\\\"560\\\"></iframe></p>\\n<p>You can borrow a sum and repay it weekly, fortnightly or monthly over a loan term from a year to several years. It can be a much faster way to cover your costs than added them to your home loan or putting in on your credit card.</p>\\n<p>Typically personal loans have lower interest rates and fees than many credit cards, store cards and other lending schemes so it can be a more cost-effective and manageable way to get the things you want.</p>\\n<p>Unlike a credit card, with a personal loan you agree to repay the balance within an agreed timeframe, which can be great if you need some discipline to clearing debt. It can also save you a lot of money in interest!</p>\\n<p>Like cards, personal loans have definite upsides.&nbsp; The time and paperwork involved in applying for a loan also makes impulse buys less likely, and while you won&rsquo;t get the benefit of interest-free days, the combination of cheaper rates, fixed repayments and a set term can make personal loans a better value option for some people.</p>\\n<p>To learn more about personal loans click through to our complete <a href=\\\"http://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/guide\\\">step-by-step guides</a>.
